from the rural economy to urbanization
The independent modern Greek state
began its historical course in 1830,
after a decade of hard work,
major catastrophes and human
losses. The consolidation of order, the element-
manual even state operation and
the principle of reconstruction and eco-
legal development have their starting point
in 1833, after its installation
Bavarian dynasty in Greece. The
problem faced by the country no
it was just repairing the damage
that the multi-year war and anarchy
had caused. Almost all structures and
the functions of society, in the eco-
legal space in particular, were obsolete
and were in complete discrepancy
with the progress that the states of the West-
Europe had already succeeded in-
with that. These states were already living it
industrial revolution and the post-
production and economics
of their forces. Greece was
still in the East, where the industry-
Chania was unknown, the transport was carried out
were born with primitive means and the
works were done by methods which
they were known - most - by her
era of Hesiod.
INTRODUCTION
Page 12
11
from the rural economy to urbanization
Greece was not only poor, with outdated production structures. It was
also small in size and oligopolistic. The line Amvrakikou-Pagasi-
It was the borders of the new Greek state. From its islands
Only the Northern Sporades and the Cyclades belonged to the Aegean in Greece. The cor-
Roumeli and Morias were part of the country, as in the revolutionary years.
In 1864 the Ionian Islands were added and in 1881 Thessaly. So the north
borders reached Olympus and Macedonia.
The population density ranged from 15 (1828) to 43 (1911).
per square kilometer, when in many Western European countries
the same numbers were three digits. The images that come to us from that time-
and testify to the exhaustion of place and people. Around the cities
the lands were bare, exhausted by overgrazing and logging and
the fields looked like a wasteland, due to the extensive fallow land, with the
Together with the historians of this period of pain, let us be moved
on the tops of the mountains of Greece ... let's look around ...
What despair! ... Ruins everywhere! Amorphous volumes and ruins that still smoke-
live, tearful women, families without bread! We are looking for them in vain
there are no cities or villages! At the foot of the Parthenon, under the light-
tostefano of the glorious name of Athens, huts are lying, half a stone,
half wood. In front of them pass paths, not roads, and these still are
messy and muddy passages! No modern monument! Holy Mar-
Mara only, haunted by the shadows of the old! Here, dried plantations,
uprooted, set on fire. There vineyards and olive groves destroyed. Nobody
road, no proof of operation of a previous administration! All
must be done from the beginning! It all has to start with nothing! And that
"Everything" must be done by a handful of people, the few who can
to lead, to teach, to create the Nation! What work is worth it?
gloves! And some would like to see this done
always paved, shaped! Where and when they arrived just a few years ago
West to achieve such a miracle?
The economic situation in Greece
at the dawn of their independence
From the book, Pierre A. Moraïtinis, La Grèce telle qu'elle est, Paris, Athènes, Berlin,
1877 (reprinted by D.N. Karavias, 1987) Avant-propos, p. 7-8.
A. THE GREEK ECONOMY AFTER THE REVOLUTION
1. Demographic data
a. The population

which farmers struggled to improve their yields. The fences-
to orchards very little improved the sense of abandonment that exuded
landscape.
Nevertheless, the population was growing rapidly, never before
to exhaust the margins of demographic development in such a sparsely populated
lost country. Financial opportunities were limited and production-
scarcity surpluses. In times of instability, destruction would easily come.
φή. The naval blockade by the Anglo-French, in 1854, during
of the Crimean War, caused famine, disease and human losses,
confirming the country's small potential.

in the period that concerns us, with the industrial, commercial, financial,
urban centers of the West. For European measures the cities of small Greece-
they looked more like big villages. The movement of people from
outdoor in urban centers did not aim exclusively at installation in
urban space, where the slow development of productive activities does not

from the rural economy to urbanization
15
it gave newcomers many opportunities. The migrations of the rural
population to the ports of the Eastern Mediterranean and the Black Sea-
to the Danube, southern Russia, Asia Minor, and Egypt;
phenomenon. Towards the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th, they opened
the roads to America. The raisin crisis of that time caused
large influx of migrants across the Atlantic.
P. olles decades after independence, Greece still
it looks more like the East than the West, even though the
last there was the question, the desired, the point of reference all this
the years. The powerful development centers, the "locomotives" of the ecosystem, were absent.
legal and technical progress. After all, how could they be, when
everything necessary and necessary for creation was absent
their; The country did not have significant raw materials, it did not have a surplus of specialists.
cheap or even cheap labor, the accumulation of capital, private
and public, was scarce and the internal market limited to insignificant.
In addition, the country was competing with itself. Outside its borders there was
They had strong centers of Hellenism, spiritual, economic, productive, which
many times they dominated their space but also in wider areas.
Greeks, Greek capital and wealth existed and developed from
Ukraine to Sudan, from the Danube to the Caucasus and from Izmir
to Cilicia. For the Greeks of these areas the small Greek kingdom-
It has been a bad memory for many years, probably a poor one and maybe
unrelated relative. Their own successes seemed entirely foreign to them.
gray with the stagnation and poverty of small Greece. He had to
make economic and political conditions difficult for them towards the end
mainly of the 19th century, to discover the importance of their poverty
homeland, as a safe haven and as a field for economic development
riots.
In the meantime, his progress outside the national borders of Hellenism was oscillating
the small kingdom. It reinforced the idea that the existing state was only one
unfinished construction, the foundations just for something bigger. The "Great Idea"
which proceeded from this perception, created expectations for the whole-
drawing on the national vision, which required a significant expansion
2. The productive forces inside and out
from Greece and the "Great Idea"
Page 17
16
from the rural economy to urbanization
borders. The strong presence of this national ideology had implications
in the political and economic spheres, especially in times of trouble
they looked like open wounds, in the case of Crete or, later, of Ma-
cedar. The Greek governments were not interested,
in these conditions, exclusively in internal affairs, in the eco-
legal recovery and bridging the gap with the West. All this together
they were seen with the national vision, increasing the cost of efforts and
often making economic initiatives a harbinger of national crises.
Page 18
17
from the rural economy to urbanization
The economic size of the country, the small population, the limited market
active possibility of its inhabitants, the absence of production units
large-scale enclosing, throughout the 19th century, the internal trade-
very low traffic 1 . Only in its last decades
century in the larger cities created a worthwhile commercial movement-
which, however, was largely supplied by imported cat-
sedimentary products.
For the same reasons, the country's trade was linked to abroad, by
the first years of independence. So when we look at trade
of Greece until 1913, we basically mean foreign trade. And as well
the latter was almost permanently passive for the country, that is, Greece
he bought from abroad much more than he sold there, the basic one
The problem was the balance of payments, that is, the relationship between their value
imports and exports. Nevertheless, the importance of trade was me-
"Festivals are commercial gatherings in cities or rural areas.
we are held year after year in a certain season, in let us gather from the para-
text cities merchants to sell their goods, or others to
purchase of another city or municipality in which the festival is held.
At the time, domestic trade was restricted.
Such gatherings have some privileges and imperfections, and existence
they became necessary, but after the internal trade was full
freedom, which not only lost their importance but also
are beaten by some economists as you strengthen the market.
These festivals are still taking place by B. Decree and lasting
from 3-8 days. According to a resolution of the Governor of February 4 -
In 1830, until today, a tax is levied on festivals
imported goods, “two palm trees on wholesale cargo,
four on the fine ", during the expression of the resolution, and the tax
This is recorded in the budgets of the municipalities as regular revenue.
Those from the festivals and the buildings erected in them po-
roi of the various municipalities belonged in 1859 to drchm. 29,836.
Today, every year, celebrations are held throughout the State
number ".

B. GREEK ECONOMY DURING THE 19th CENTURY
1. Trade
1
Page 19
18
from the rural economy to urbanization
milk. Not only did it contribute to tackling the food problem
of the country, but at the same time it was the most reliable source of income
for public funds. Customs revenue was really one
significant percentage of public revenue.
The development of foreign trade followed a pace similar to that
the overall improvement of national economic figures but also with them
growth rates of international trade. Statistically, its increase
The value of the transactions is impressive. In 1851 the total value
of the country's imports and exports was about 36,000,000 gold drachmas
which increased to 235,000,000 in 1901 and to 315,000,000 in 1911.
Of course, we must not forget that in the same period Greece expanded with
the annexation of the Ionian Islands and Thessaly and that its population
increased by 2.5 times.
If we take into account the productive potential of Greece during
of the first century of its independence, we should not be surprised by the event-
most of its foreign trade was agricultural
products. In exports , more than 2/3 (in value) of the total was
argicultural products. In fact, the general trend was to expand
percentage of agricultural exports, which came to represent-
3/4 of total exports fall in the 1900-1910 decade. In the category
This first place was occupied by raisins, which in itself were close in value
1/2 of total exports. Olive oil followed with a big difference
and, after 1900, wine.
In addition to the above species, small quantities of plant products were exported.
for industrial processing, cotton, for example, in its day
American Civil War or the steadily rising smoke, however
still accounted for a small percentage of exports (2-3%). Until
In 1880 there was also a significant commercial movement in treated leather,
which, however, almost disappeared later. In the first category
materials, exports were completed by mining products, which from the end
of the 19th century were close to 1/5 of the total value of exports. Was going
mainly for lead, for manganese ores, for emery and thera
Earth. Exports of industrial products were literally insignificant.
In imports, agricultural items consistently represented 1/3 (in value)
of the total. In the first place were cereals, especially wheat,
as domestic production was unable to cover food needs
populations of the population. The imported industrial products dominated
fabrics and yarns, while mineral rates gradually increased
(coal), timber, chemicals and machinery.
Page 20
19
from the rural economy to urbanization
The countries with which Greece has developed trade during this period
Most of them were the industrialized states of Western Europe. THE
England absorbed almost all of the raisin exports but also one
significant percentage of ores (lead). France but also small-
more European states, such as e.g. Belgium, they followed. On the contrary, the
trade relations with the Ottoman Empire, although existing,
were in the first place in terms of volume and value.

from the rural economy to urbanization
Greek commercial activity was not limited to its borders
Greek state. Strong Greek trading houses had expanded him
long their activities in the areas around Greece. In the South
Russia, in the countries through which the Danube passes, in Constantinople-
city ​​and other ports of the Ottoman Empire, in Smyrna and
Alexandria, Greek trade activities developed
angularly in terms of the activities not only of domestic traders, but
and the trading houses of the powerful industrial states of the West.
In the course of the 18th century, major shipping observed
commercial activity in many coastal areas of Greece
space and islands. This activity was favored by various co-
and, in particular, Russia's exit from the Black Sea and trade
developed in the ports of the region (eg in Odessa) and Mesogei-
ου. With the treaty of Kyuchuk Kainartzis (1774) between Russia and
In the Ottoman Empire, Christian-Greek ships were protected
by Russian power and thus favored the rapid development of activities-
of their. A little later, with the French Revolution and the Napoleons
wars, Greek shipping was particularly favored. The break-up of the mainland
blockade imposed by the British navy on French ports
It brought huge profits, while the disappearance of French ships
from the Eastern Mediterranean created gaps, which rushed to exploit
the Greeks.
Difficult years followed, culminating in the decade of Greek
Revolution (1821-1830). During the conflict, the Greek trade-
The fleet was turned into a battlefield, and trade routes were closed
Traditional maritime centers experienced disaster (Psara, Galaxidi) or
decline. There is little left of the thriving pre-revolutionary shipping
but. The most important of these was the predisposition to the sea and knowledge
of maritime affairs.
In the Greek state, in place of the old centers that declined, re-
turned out to be new. The most important of these was Syros, which during
of the Revolution received waves of refugees, mainly from Chios. The strategy-
location of the island, in the center of the Aegean and just above the routes
connecting the Straits and the Black Sea with the Mediterranean roads
of trade, contributed to the creation of a very strong - not only for the Greeks -
2. Commercial shipping
Page 22
21
from the rural economy to urbanization
meters - shipping center. An important role in this development is played by
built the dynamic presence and activity of the Greek communities in
main commercial centers of the region: in the ports of Southern Russia, in
estuaries of the Danube, in Istanbul, in Smyrna and later in
Egypt.
During the 19th century, Greek shipping, despite periods of crisis
which passed and despite the competition of high cost and technical requirements
steamships followed an upward trend. Number and capacity-
its ships did not stop growing. In 1840 Greek ships had con-
mental capacity of 100,000 tons, while in 1866 they exceeded 300,000
tones. This development was not self-evident. There have been strong fluctuations
in the period during which the Greek sailing ships were replaced by
steamships. During the same period, many of the national public works took place
for the service of shipping activity. Ports made
and a beacon system was created, which made it much safer
navigation in the Greek seas.
Sailboats in a Greek port
Page 23
22
from the rural economy to urbanization
The initiatives and the organized efforts for the entry of the Greek-
Victory shipping in the steam era began after the mid-19th century.
The funds needed for construction or purchase and maintenance
of steamships were significant, with the result that the para-
shipping relations applicable to sailing ships and to be sought
funds through companies and strong business schemes. The state, the
banks (the National Bank in particular) and expatriate expatriates
were actively involved in these initiatives. Nevertheless, the limited availability
Capitalism and increased business risk have suspended it
development of Greek steamship. Her presence began to be felt
only in the last decade of the 19th century. Its 97 Greek steamships
1890 became 191 in 1901 and 389 in 1912. This development was based on
dominance of Greek businessmen in transport in the Delta region
Danube but also in the movement in the river itself.
World War I, the devastation it caused, but also the great ones
You say economic and political changes brought to the states of the Black Sea-
shower, they changed the data once again. In 1919 the Greek trade-
The fleet had more than doubled since 1914. In fact, it was needed
a new beginning.

from the rural economy to urbanization
A Po the many problems the Ottoman occupation bequeathed to the new
Greek state, stood out for its size, importance and complexity
His question is the question of "national lands". "National lands" were the real estate, the
Property properties of the Ottomans in the areas that came under control
of the Greek state. This land belonged either to the Ottoman state or to
Muslim institutions either to individuals, as property or as prefecture right
(exploitation).
These properties became the property of the Greek state.
I am right. " For the Greek revolutionary governments it was
first and, in essence, the only capital during the war, that's why
were used as a mortgage to enter into loans or as collateral
revenue, through their sale. The extent of these lands can be calculated
3. The distribution of national lands

from the rural economy to urbanization
only approximate, as the land-related ottoman-
The status quo was complicated, as were the inventory mechanisms.
elements. It is estimated that the area of ​​national estates was rising
wholesale to 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 acres.
The distribution of "national lands", although a general desire,
There were many problems in practice. Many of the owners of the estates
before that they had the right to exploit the land from the pre-revolutionary
for years. In other words, they cultivated the fields for many generations, yielding
a percentage (approximately 15%) to the nominal owner, as well as the tax on
of production, the tenth. They definitely had strong property rights
on earth and it was difficult for the state to ask them to redeem it-
paying a high price. The acquisition, moreover, presupposed
net title deeds, ie determination of the anti- to be redeemed
text, which was non-existent in the Ottoman space where they existed
usually overlapping rights on earth *.
On the other hand, in Central Greece, a significant part of the national
of land, which was not under the control of the revolutionaries at the end of the war,
passed directly into the hands of individuals with direct redemption by the Ottomans
their owners, even at a low price. Thus, the state lost its opportunity
mediation and revenue generation. They were also not uncommon
encroachments, especially in times of turmoil and crisis, encroachments that may
schools could be proven in lands with questionable certificates-
property. In the area of ​​land ownership, Ottoman law differed
significantly from the Byzantine-Roman, which adopted the free Greek
state. Adapting real data to this change allows
great margins for all kinds of irregularities.
More generally, however, trends have led to the fragmentation of national ge-
in small or medium-sized properties and not in the collection of large estates
in the hands of a few capitalists. This may have been due to the lack of adults
capital but also in the trend of acquiring real estate in cities,
in Athens in particular. The acquisition of large land ownership was not in the
intentions of the rich, which softened the contradictions and did not allow
to develop significant social tensions around their problem
national lands. At the same time, the creation of small, vulnerable properties
in crises, exposed to market moods and tax pressures,
favored the development of a civil protection system: local po-
They managed to reduce the pressure, intervening
in government mechanisms. It was an analogous role.
with that of the Protestants during the pre-revolutionary period.
Page 26
25
from the rural economy to urbanization
The problem was finally resolved with legislation
during the period 1870-1871. The aim of the legislation was to ensure
Priority is given to landless villagers, with the provision of land, necessary-
her for their survival. At the same time, the state was trying to ensure
through the sale process, the largest possible revenue, which
they would breathe new life into the ongoing budget impasse. The goals were anti-
and in fact only the first was achieved satisfactorily
degree. According to the relevant legislation, the beneficiary farmers
they could buy as much land as they wanted, with a maximum of 80 acres
for dry lands and 40 acres for irrigated. From 1870 to 1911
2,650,000 acres were distributed with 370,000 concessions, which
shows that the ambitions or capabilities of farmers to acquire cultivar-
Landscaping was limited but also the fragmentation of the land already
large. It should be noted that for areas marked as
plantations, olive trees and vineyards, the average area of ​​в.. в.. property was
clearly smaller than those intended for cereal cultivation.
But it was an important distribution of arable land, especially if
compared to the 600,000 acres of national lands that had been distributed before
abbot years, from 1833 to 1870. However, only about 50% of it
in return for the allotted lands eventually paid to the state by them
buyers of this national property.
The absence of heavy industry in Greece limited the interest in
subsoil exploitation. Activities in this area either
aimed at exporting or serving the limited-
needs. For the latter, the activities of the quarries and the pa-
building materials had the first say. For exports, the weight
fell into mining products that the powerful industrial states of the West
Europeans used them as raw materials in their metallurgy. The products
these were exported raw, in the form of ore, or after
manual only processing.
Greece, even in its limited dimensions of the 19th century, had
satisfactory variety of deposits, but usually in small quantities. THE
encouraging their methodical exploitation in the early 1990s
1860 with legislation that allowed the "assignment" of mining rights
on favorable terms, caused the rapid development of the industry. At the same time
4. The exploitation of mines
Page 27
26
from the rural economy to urbanization
The interest in mining and construction materials had increased due to
various circumstances, such as e.g. the works for the opening of its canal
Suez (completed in 1869) but also the opening of the canal itself.
which has upgraded the entire Eastern Mediterranean.
The most famous mining area has been, as in
antiquity, Lavrio. In 1866 a French-Italian began its work there
company (Serpieri-Rou) with the aim of extracting ore not only from
underground deposits but also from the "slag", the materials that had accumulated-
during the centuries of exploitation of the mines in antiquity
reality. The technology of the time allowed the extraction of ore from
these residues. Silver and lead mining experienced significant ant-
and added to the Greek exports products worth many millions-
drachmas.
Among the other farms were those of Milos (sulfur), Na-
xou (emery) and Thira (Theraic land *, used as a builder-
material in large projects). With the building development that the country experienced
After the 1870s, new materials emerged, such as the
marble. The use of the wonderful marbles that the country had took
significant dimensions in the late 19th century.
In this category of economic activity we can include
and salts, a source of significant public revenue over the past decade-
in the 19th century.
With the establishment of the independent Greek state, the issue of creation
creation of a central bank, but also a worthy banking system
of those operating in Western European countries was
central point in government planning. The establishment of banking institutions-
It would not only serve the needs of the government, its management
government borrowing, banknote issuance, etc., but it would provide a solution
to the chronic problem of the credit needs of the economy. It would ensure
that is, in business initiatives the necessary funds on terms
organized market and not usury.
The country's credit system was really in its infancy.
independence, in a primitive state. It was connected to the trade-
agricultural products and especially with raisin exports. The
Merchants also operated as creditors, with interest-bearing provisions and terms.
5. The creation of a banking system
Page 28
27
from the rural economy to urbanization
Lending was, for the most part, to producers and creators.
it created conditions for exploitation, as it was essentially one
way of pre-purchasing the upcoming production, with unfavorable for the producer
terms. At the same time other branches of production were deprived of the necessary
credit for their development, and thus limited business-
initiatives. This situation was contrary to the intentions and the
state policies and discouraged Greek capital abroad.
Efforts to remove all such obstacles have been intense
came from many sides. They did not aim so much at eliminating it-
engraving, as in the parallel creation of a more modern credit
system, capable of serving the interests of special social groups-
δων.
The big step was taken in 1841, with the establishment of the National Bank. The heads
They came mainly from abroad for its establishment, while it was intense

in the late 19th century

the presence of state actors in the founding proceedings. The main meto-
The bank's heir was the capitalist Einardos, the Greek state (20% of it)

personalities from the field of economics and politics. Foundation-
of her and the first commander was George Stavrou. In the following sections
Bank capital gains began to take place capitalists, embo-
mainly, of the Greek area (Skouzes, Rallis, etc.). Its activity
in the early stages it was rather without a clear orientation, as the conditions
which prevailed in the Greek economy could not be changed
at a fast pace. Its great advantage and at the same time the main source
her income was the publishing right, her ability to issue a bank-
bills, ie banknotes, that is, on behalf of the Greek state.
The latter even strengthened or imposed their circulation.
Gradually, the Bank's operations spread from Athens to
main provincial towns (Ermoupolis 1845, Patras 1846 etc.), a fact that
helped deal with the negative effects of interest-
glyphic system. The bank won the trust of the Greek society
let, which resulted in the successive enlargements of its shareholder
capital. Despite the spread of the banking system and appearance
new banking institutions, the National Bank remained for many decades
the dominant banking complex in Greece.

The emergence and development of industry in Greece during the 19th century
century showed little in common with what was happening in the field
this in Western and Central Europe, which was briefly called Bio-
mechanical revolution. The development of industry in the small Greek state
was constantly present in discussions, economic and political analyzes-
but usually as a plan or intention, rarely as an application. The radiation
of the achievements of the European states was constantly brought to the fore
issue of industrial development, but the absence of the necessary for it
development of the industry conditioned the intentions to deadlocks-
δο.
The appearance of production units, which could be characterized
industrial, began in the first decades of independence with detachment-
a schematic, perhaps opportunistic way. These units were intended to serve-
addressing local needs related to agricultural processing

of Metaxourgeio

products. This was mainly a development of traditional flour mills,
oil mills, tanneries and spinning mills. The units though
these were not the starting point for creating a more complex industry-
bands but, in most cases, remained
stagnant and limited in economic size. The hesitation
This was probably due to the small size of the domestic market, their pressure
imported products but also in the lack of numerous, specialized and
cheap labor.
It took about forty years to acquire it
national independence to observe a first attempt at their development
industrial activities in the country. Around 1870 there was one
wave of industrial enterprise establishment, more than a hundred, while
At the same time, there was a tendency to increase the potential of the already existing ones.
hash units. But very quickly, this attempt lost its momentum
and related activities returned to recession and stagnation.
Terms began to change only in the last years of the 19th century
and, above all, in the early years of the 20th. Then an industrial one was created

potentially relatively stable, multidimensional, with heavy growth trends
industry, metallurgy, shipbuilding and cement industry-

The industry, like other sectors of the economy, has suffered from a shortage.
capital distribution and the dispersal of the multitude of existing activities,
from the suffocatingly limited - territorial and population - economic base-
proliferation, from lack of raw materials and chronic shortage of workers
hands. One could add to the above the lack of education
technical but also general. Inadequate training limited application
innovation and the consequent technological development.
Nor the annexation of the Ionian Islands (1864) and Thessaly (1881) but-
again the above restrictive conditions. The data change came later
in 1912-1913, with the integration of large areas and populations. And then
but the chronic weaknesses of Greek industry continued to hamper
its emergence as the driving force of the Greek economy. Weak to
withstanding external competition, the industry remained committed to
secondary activities, seeking its salvation in the intervention-
state, with tariff or other support measures.
By 1830, the infrastructure of the Greek state was still primitive. Ge-
forts, carriageways, ports, aqueducts, public buildings, everything
support the economic and administrative functioning of the state, whether or not
they weren't at all, or they were in bad shape. Under these conditions
It was only natural that the administration should be interested in it
construction of the necessary, according to European standards, projects. The
intentions, which were also very good in this area, clashed with the anti-
conditions that prevailed, and in particular the inability to find them
necessary financial resources. Moreover, it is known that the Greek state
started with a heavy budget burden, that is, the service of the da-
young people who had gathered abroad during the Struggle but also
later, in the difficult times of its state formation.
In land transportation but also in most of the public works
that the country needed, the lack of private interest was a given-
as investments in these key infrastructures were not very profitable
times. The state, either directly or through the municipalities, tried to overthrow
overcome these difficulties on his own. His activity was
rather subdued, at least until the 1870s, as money
7. Public works
Page 33
32
from the rural economy to urbanization
were missing and the methods adopted were not popular (for example,
farmers' chores in road construction).
The congestion of the road network took the first place among the nationals and the-
priorities towards the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th.
Economic growth, the fastest pace of urbanization, creation
of the central railway axes and the development of the internal trade-
were factors that promoted the construction of a road network. To
inhibitory factors should include high costs
the construction of roads in mountainous terrains but also the "competition" of the tha-
of Latvian transport that dominated transport near the coast,
that is, in a very large part of the country.
Of the other public works, the most important was the drying of large ones
areas covered by lake and swamp waters. Beyond the fact
that drying provided rich arable land was the only way
fighting malaria, a disease that was a scourge for
rural Greece until the middle of the 20th century. Many drainage projects
took place in the country, with the most important being the drying up of Lake Kopaida in
Boeotia.
In addition to the railway network, the largest technical project that cat-
built at this time was the opening of the Corinth Canal. The
The project was started in 1881 by an overly optimistic French technical company.
After many technical and financial adventures, the project is completed.
The opening of the canal
of Corinth

during this period.
The most characteristic of the changes brought about by the industrial revolution-
In the developed countries of the 19th century was the emergence, the spread
and finally the dominance of the railway in land transportation. The iron-
Road network solved the problem of transporting large volumes of products
at low cost, at distances now measured on the state scale
and continents. The industrial revolution, increased production and creation
Great cities could not proceed without this
new possibility that ensured the supply of cities with food, ta
factories with raw materials and the market with products. Under the circumstances
these, it was not surprising that the railway became the symbol of the young and-
and synonymous with development during the 19th century.
In the smaller and more economically backward countries, the acquisition of si-
network network presented from a very early age as an important pre-
intention to enter the field of developed countries. The relevant
With the construction of a railway network, discussions began in our country
just a few years after its independence, perhaps in 1835. But insurmountable
difficulties have limited these discussions for many decades in their field
theoretical analyzes and simple desires. The construction of the railway-
Infrastructure was a very expensive affair and required capital
that the small Greek state could not save. On the other
the attraction of foreign capital, enterprises or credit institutions,
you assumed that the network to be built would be efficient, it would ensure
that is, the transport of raw materials, vital for industry, and consumption-
goods, which local markets would be able to absorb. In
There was neither Greece nor the other. So the interest of foreigners
or expatriate investors remained very small. In addition, its proximity
sea, in most parts of the country, did not help things,
as maritime transport limited rail efficiency
network.

years, from 1880 onwards. The big boost was given to the first prime ministers-

the Greek state slowed down the construction of the project in its decade
1890 and the network was completed only in 1909. For the most part
network was metric, with lines only one meter wide, at the time the
international standards provided for lines 1.56 meters wide. That's what I mean
The network was designed to serve mainly local needs, without
ambitions to be part of the international network.
The state undertook most of the cost of the project and shouldered
set up most of the borrowing, which was done mainly by foreign creditors-
institutions. Individuals participated with a smaller percentage (about 30%), in
a work whose efficiency was highly questionable. Really, the si-
Railway network was called upon to serve the trafficking of farmers mainly
products and from the beginning of its operation it presented a serious lag-
revenue in relation to the optimistic calculations that led
in its creation. This fact also led to the cessation of further
rail investment.
There is no doubt that the railway network has offered a lot to a country
which he had never before met a reliable land transportation network. Pre-
It also brought many services during the war, after allowing it
rapid mobilization and supply of the Greek army. I don't own
However, it has brought development and industrialization to the areas where
arrived. It failed to meet all development expectations.
were thrown at him. To do so would have to cause change
social and economic structures. And, of course, a transport network
school can achieve such radical changes.

meter of the operation of the Greek state. That was natural for one
a state that started from scratch and did not inherit from the previous one
organized fiscal system. Adventures are known
the loans of the Struggle in the London money market as well as the conclusion
new loans, which accompanied the arrival of the Bavarians in 1832. The Ottoman c-
denials denied the repayment of the revolutionary loans, a fact
which isolated the country from European money markets until 1861.
The change in growth rates from the 1860s onwards has led
necessarily on new borrowing. The country's limited resources, combined-
with the extraordinary expenses imposed by the ongoing national crises, they made

and the obligation of Greece to pay exorbitant bills of war
Compensation in the Ottoman Empire raised the issue on new grounds.

Germany, Russia, Italy) undertook the management of basic government revenues.

The purpose of this mandatory management was to meet the obligations
of the country's impulses to the Ottoman Empire, that is, its payment
war reparations amounting to 92,000,000 drachmas and their service
other loans. The International Committee, which began its operation in 1898,
faced current needs with a large loan, granted to me
the guarantee of the Forces. Then, in addition to her main role, that is,
In addition to securing the repayment of loans, it also worked
as a technical advisory body, generally contributing to their improvement
performance of the Greek economy.
The results were positive and became visible a few years later. The
The return of the Forces increased the creditworthiness of the state, while the
control freed fiscal mechanisms from its malfunctions
past. In 1910, despite the problems in the external balance pay-
due to the raisin crisis and despite the fact that their repayment
loans still absorbed 1/3 of national income, public-
economically they could be described as healthy, the budgets were
slightly surplus and the economic potential of the state clearly
increased. This positive development allowed the reforms of the former
governments of Eleftherios Venizelos, the war preparation and the
participation in the Balkan wars, without the dramatic effects that
the military mobilizations of the past were in the economic field.

drones had spread to many parts of the Eastern Mediterranean and
of the Black Sea. In some areas, in fact, in Egypt, No-

activities in Greek hands were particularly important
for the domestic economy. For the small Greek state that suffocated in
its limited geographical boundaries, the existence of these powerful expatriates-
of teams was definitely a hope, a golden reserve.
However, the relations of the Greeks of the Diaspora with the small Greek kingdom

and high performance that characterized European economies up to

growth seasons in the markets of the major states of the Eastern Mediterranean.

Discussions on the use of expatriate opportunities
generalized in the 1860s, when the change of dynasty and pres-
institutions, the first expansion of the Greek state, with the integration-
of the Ionian Islands, and the enormous cost of involvement in the Cretan re-
of 1866-1869 led to the search for attraction policies
of expatriates to Greece. These policies were initially meager
Results. At the same time, however, the Ottoman Empire
the constitutional reforms of Tanzimat (1856) 1 that provided
polluted rights of the Christians of the empire. Reforms
these, combined with the new economic conditions that prevailed in
many areas of the Ottoman Empire were clearly larger
opportunities for expatriates from those that Greece could offer.
The first cowardly signs of cooperation between the Greek state and the Greeks
Expatriates appeared in the 1870s. This development is possible
due to the crisis of 1873, which reduced European yields
capital and caused their transfer to the east, in search
The term Tanzimat describes a long period of reform
efforts in the Ottoman Empire. As the most important moment
of this effort is considered the publication, on February 6, 1856,
in Istanbul by the Sultan of a "Hatt-i Humayun" (Self-
state script) that ratified the older constitutional reforms-
in the Ottoman Empire and especially Gul's proclamations
Hane * (1839). These reforms, which took place under their pressure
European powers secured the Crimean War the day after
equality between the religious groups of the empire and,
consequently, they strengthened their economic, social and political position
Christians, especially Greeks. Many of her powerful Greeks
Empire saw in these developments an important opportunity to expand-
of their influence in the Ottoman space, which removed it
their interest from the small and humble - during the Crimean
war - Greek kingdom.

A successful purchase was made based on the use of opportunities for high profits. THE

state, was a first class opportunity for expatriate capital-
χους. Shortly afterwards, investments in trade and mining followed

of the public.
The main feature of these investments was the opportunistic character-
and their liquidity. The main concern seems to be the possibility
rapid depreciation and reinvestment of funds abroad, in
first indication for more profitable placements. The Greek market did not give
so many promises to make long-term appointments
points. The easy convertibility of the drachma strengthened these short-lived pe-
expatriate funds from the country. The characterization of this
of economic behavior as speculative is not far from it
truth. In the Eastern Mediterranean, on the outskirts of the hard core-
of capitalist development, capital operated on the basis of hunting
opportunity, quick performance, speculation, in short.
The behavior of the expatriate capitalists in the beginning was more stable
of the 20th century, after the Neo-Turkish movement, the Balkan Wars
and the rearrangements brought by World War I. The rise of the national
stocks, blows to foreign economic activity, policies
developments in Russia, the end of the Ottoman Empire and creation
of Kemalist Turkey cut off the traditional ones in the most absolute way
activities of Greek capitalists in the Eastern Mediterranean. Enough
of them then preferred the transport of business, industrial,
their commercial or stock market activities in the Greek state.
In the meantime, however, that same state has changed form and potential
had been differentiated.

a stable basis for the development of the independent Greek state. This
but that does not mean that his presence was not significant. The opportunistic

C. ECONOMIC EVOLUTIONS AGAINST THE 20TH CENTURY
1. The agricultural issue
Page 44
43
from the rural economy to urbanization
by wealthy Greeks abroad who, in addition to the fact that
observed the anachronistic institution of the colligs, exercised policies and public-
victorious pressures to profit from wheat production. I seek-
that is to say, the imposition of high tariffs on wheat imported from Russia,
so that they can set as high prices as possible for the domestic-
in fact, sometimes causing artificial deficiencies.
These practices have created tensions and led to the enactment of laws
in 1907, which allowed the respective Greek government to release
he owns large properties so that he can distribute them to landless people. THE
Their application proved to be a difficult case and the friction caused-
they even caused conflicts, the most important of which took place in the village
Killerer (1910). Developments progressed slowly until the end of the Balkans
wars (1913), so the issue became more complicated, as within the new boundaries
There were now large Muslim landowners in the country.
The decisive step towards the completion of agricultural reform-
It took place during the turbulent years of World War I and the "national
division ". In 1917 the government of Eleftherios Venizelos in Thessaloniki
decided to complete the reform. The goal was twofold:
the support and multiplication of Greek land properties in the ne-
Harvest
Page 45
44
from the rural economy to urbanization
the acquired areas and on the other hand the rehabilitation of the refugees and the
prevention of social tensions in the rural area. Based on these laws
Expropriation of large agricultural properties became possible
immediately after the war years, when the need to rehabilitate refugees
corner was at the center of state interest.
The redistribution reached 85% of the arable land
Macedonia and 68% in Thessaly. In the whole of its arable land
country this percentage rose to 40%. After a few years, under the pi-

and led the country's agricultural economy to a state of micro-ownership.

cause for oppression and arbitrariness. And the long struggle of the uneducated on the ruins
and the destruction of political autonomy, he issued in the installation-
Government of the desert and people and animals, and houses, plains

We have made great progress from the autonomy of Greece based on

2. The first steps of the labor movement
The differences of the agricultural problem in Greece, in relation to the neighbor-
or other European countries, due to historical peculiarities
of Greek development. The same goes for the labor movement. At the end
In the 19th century, we find socialist and workers' socialist groups in Greece
groupings. Their political and social influence was clearly less
from the one that carried out similar movements in industrialized countries in the West
but also in Balkan (eg Bulgaria). The absence of large modern industries
units led to this delay together with others
factors. In the major public works of the period, a significant percentage of it
labor force came from abroad (in the opening of the directorate-
Many Italians worked in Corinth) or were temporary, short-lived
employment. A more stable workforce worked in the mining companies.
manipulations, where the first purely workers' uprisings took place (Lav-
rio, 1896). In the ideological field, the predominance of the Great Idea was an obstacle
the development and dissemination of ideologies with social and class content.
This situation lasted until the end of the Balkan wars. The integration
Thessaloniki in Greece, a city with important - for the measures
of the region - industrial background and cosmopolitan character, apo-
made a reference point for the labor movement. The great multinational labor-
The city organization, the Federation, with leading socialists from
open to new ideas Jewish community of the city, was an important channel-
for the spread of socialist and workers' ideology in the country.
During World War I, the pressure exerted by the el-
Greek society, its involvement in international affairs and its impact on Russia
revolution led the labor and socialist movement rapidly
maturation. Towards the end of the war, the General Confederation was founded
Greek Workers (GSEE) which included sectoral and local unions, and the
Page 48
47
from the rural economy to urbanization
Socialist Workers' Party of Greece (SEKE), which a little later joined
He joined the Third Communist International and was renamed the Communist Party
Party of Greece.
There are few new factories. We will talk about them below. Δί-
In these modern factories we still find spinners, weavers
and craftsmen with few tools whose work is almost exclusively hand-
rocking. They work for endless hours in sad dark buildings, where
they do not even find a place to sit, or sanitary facilities. They leave at night
from their dirty hands work to come back the next morning,
in exactly the same situation, to start their work again.
The dark and sickly atmosphere in which they toil for hours, does not meet
mixed with any kind of comfort in their family life. The pitiful and
the sick face of many workers proves the overly hard work
imposed on them. The bright sun of Greece rarely penetrates them
unhealthy factories, especially in those of Trikala and Kalamata, where
the air does not find even a way out to renew the damaged steam-
spheres of places where food is prepared, such as bread, pasta, oil-
oil or raisins, along with other species.
The working day in Greece is long, longer than anywhere else.
No worker imagines the good and beneficial that their day would bring
eight working hours. They know nothing but the working ten, at least
while usually their work lasts 12 or 14 hours, without any kind of allowance
or additional fee. The strikes were virtually unknown until 1909. Alone
There have been three memorable strikes since then
and concerned the capital. But the public paid little attention to them
the riots and the strikers felt that their efforts were costly.
They haven't tried again since.
The unions have made some progress in the last few years, and almost all of them
industries have their own unions and fraternities ... Women do not become
accepted as members of the unions.
There is no law in Greece that obliges employers to seek
chase the workers who were the victims of the accident, and the workers themselves are
too poor to be insured for risks. In some cases the
the landlord undertakes to assist the workers in it at his own expense or
to pay them the salaries they lost due to an illness. The Greeks
they are by nature good and compassionate ...
The government must issue a special law on child labor. In many
all factories, especially in Thessaly, Arcadia and Messinia, surprised-
and from the young age of children who were forced to work, boys 8 to
the Workers' Treaties in Greece
Page 49
48
from the rural economy to urbanization
10 years old and girls 6 or 7 years old. Their fees, though small, are
welcomed by their families, because they complete the meager family-
youth income. But it is not unfortunate to think that they are so small
children work incarcerated for 10 or 12 hours in such an atmosphere and with such
working conditions?
(Percy Martin, La Grèce nouvelle, Paris, Libraire
oriental et americaine, 1913, pp. 176-177).
3. The economic conditions during the period 1910-1922
In the period 1910-1922, during which Greece was in constant
war readiness, a new political conception emerged, expressing
stood with Eleftherios Venizelos and was briefly called "Venizelism". Ei-
yes it is difficult to define in a few words what exactly this policy was, in
However, the economic sector seems to have considered Venizelism to be Greek
state as a lever for the expression and development of Hellenism. The Greek state
that is, it had to pursue the integration of Hellenism abroad
and, with a single national and state status, to claim its place in
then modern world. This required not only institutional modernization, but
would make the state efficient and reliable, but also more general
commitment to the idea of ​​developing the productive forces of the nation.
Venizelos was not alone in the process of formation and implementation
of new options. He gathered around him an active bourgeoisie that ext.
it was still rich in the entire basin of the eastern Mediterranean
and which aspired to dominate politically in the area where it spread them
its economic activities. During this period, there was still a force-
Greek economic presence in the ports of southern Russia, in the basin
of the Danube and the interior of Romania, in Pontus and Asia Minor
coast, in Istanbul and Izmir, Thessaloniki, Egypt,
Sudan, Alexandria. All this wealth could be secured
only through the creation of a strong national center, a region-
capable of intervening and protecting their interests
of its citizens. It was a very critical request, at a time when
which many nationalist movements made their presence felt. For
These are the reasons for the Great Idea and its conditions - its modernization
state - were strong ideological, political and economic foundations
for claiming Greater Greece with chances of success. Feature-
It is static that in these years of great effort the budgets
of the state were usually surplus. In 1911 the revenues of the budget-
Page 50
49
from the rural economy to urbanization
The cost was only 240,000,000 and the expenses only 181,000,000 drachmas, despite the increase-
military spending.
In 1910 the progress of the national economy was evident. The agricultural crisis
was dealt with by overseas migration, which, at the time
she took on great proportions. Immigration to the United States has not only eased
the social tensions created by the raisin crisis but very quickly
has boosted the rural economy through very significant remittances
of immigrants.
The cost of the Balkan wars was significant, but it did not shake it
national economy, as was the case with the military mobilizations of the 19th
century. In addition, in this case, Greece came out on top
from the war. Incorporate rich areas (Epirus, West and Central-
Macedonia, Aegean Islands, Crete) and millions of new residents. The
Its lands increased by about 70% (from 65,000 to 108,800 square kilometers) and
its population is 80% (from 2,700,000 to 4,800,000 inhabitants). The main thing-
But these were the new economic prospects. The newly acquired lands were
mostly lowland and irrigated, which created excellent
prospects for agricultural production. The main problem was the presence
strong minority groups in these areas. In the relatively homogeneous Epi-
For example, next to the 166,000 Greeks there were, in 1914, 38,000
Muslims (mostly of Albanian descent) and a few thousand Jews.
However, Greece has definitely become a force to be reckoned with and trust-
The spirit that inspired the money and credit markets increased significantly. THE
country was ready to dedicate itself to the difficult task of integrating young people
areas, when the First World War broke out in the summer of 1914.

from the rural economy to urbanization
Greece 's participation in World War I came under pressure
schools and complicated conditions. The clash of the palace with Venice-
zeal, the Divide, as it was called, its pointless and costly mobilization
1915, the creation of the government of National Defense in Thessaloniki and the
division of the country into two essential states, the allied blockade and
Conflicts certainly had great economic and social costs and
undermined many of the gains of the previous period. When I
the intervention of the Allies, the country was united in 1917 under Venizelos,
it was impossible to assume, without external assistance, the cost of the co-
archetype in war. The Allies then proceeded with a peculiar borrowing
of the country, which would have painful consequences in the future.
France, the United Kingdom and the United States have approved major loans in the first place
to Greece: 12,000,000 pounds, 300,000,000 French francs and
US $ 50,000,000. But borrowing was theoretical. These amounts
they were not disbursed or given to Greece. They were considered a cover for it
issuance of an additional banknote, with which the Venizelos government will
funded its military effort. A kind of stock, i.e.
oily, in gold and in foreign currency, but not under control
of the country. Greece, however, financed the war in this way.
Her participation in the Macedonian front, the campaign in Ukraine and
Crimea, and the first phase of military engagement in Asia Minor.
The consequences of this peculiar monetary balance were not long in coming
they appear.
In November 1920, Venizelos' allied government lost them
elections and power were taken over by the pro-royalist parties that rushed to
return to the Allies undesirable King Constantine. The Sym-
battles, in retaliation, rushed to withdraw the banknote cover
and so a significant portion of the monetary circulation was found without
encounter. In addition, from 1918 onwards, the government balance sheet was closed
passive, while at the same time the presence in Asia Minor has turned into hard
and costly war. In March 1922 fiscal data arrived
as if in a complete impasse, which was dealt with in an unexpected way-
πο. A few months before the collapse of the Greek Front in Mikra
Asia, the government has made an original internal forced loan,
by splitting the banknote. The left part was still there
circulates at 50% of the listed value, while the right was exchanged for
Public confessions. The operation was a success, the state
gained 1,200,000,000 drachmas and the experiment was repeated in 1926. Of course, o
4. The First World War
Page 52
51
from the rural economy to urbanization
This monetary maneuver was not able to overtake Asia Minor
disaster and its dire consequences.
The catastrophe of 1922 changed the course of Greek society.
The central parameter, at the end of the long-running war between
trips, was the arrival and restoration of very important current
refugees. It is estimated that, after the Asia Minor catastrophe, they reached the
Greek state 1,230,000 Greek Christians and 45,000 Armenian refugees.
In their place, 610,000 Muslims living in Greece have left
for Turkey. It goes without saying that this human wave overturned them all
the balances and data of the Greek economy and society. One hundred
years after the Revolution of 1821, the Greek state was forced into one
new start.
The arrival of the refugees, apart from the fact that it was an unprecedented one
human tragedy, functioned as a catalyst in the dynamics of Greek
society. The chronic shortcomings of the Greek administration had to, for para-
5. Economic life during the period 1922-1936
Refugees immediately after their arrival in Greece
Page 53
52
from the rural economy to urbanization
sample, to be overcome quickly, to avoid a total disaster.
Already, in 1923 and 1924, the deaths from the disease-plagues of the time,
tuberculosis and malaria, multiplied, making it necessary and
urgent effective interventions. Political instability, its hatreds
division, the proclamation of democracy, army interventions and apo-
Coup experiments obscure the question of its effectiveness
state and administration. In fact, the reaction of the state
mechanism was rather sufficient in relation to the size of the problem.
Make the most of the capital you actually have:
Muslim fortunes estimated at five to ten billion-
millions of drachmas. At the same time, external assistance worked in a complementary
in the most effective way.
The Greece of the interwar period (1919-1939), despite the cost of Asia Minor
disaster, had acquired a number of advantages, which allowed
its positive economic course. Unlike many of its neighboring states it had
homogenized nationally, as minorities now represented less
of 7% of the total population. She had completed her agricultural conversion.
regulation and had promoted its urbanization: 1/3 of the population lived
now in large urban centers. At the same time, under the weight of pressure
it had improved its infrastructure and adopted development policies. With
in short he had solved many of the problems that followed for a long time
long rest of the Balkan states. Finally, we could
to add positively the gathering of Greeks in the context of the national
the state and the elimination of Greek cosmopolitanism that often
was a reason to treat Greece as a secondary field of development
economic activities. Greece's development has now interested everyone
the Greeks.
In addition, the refugees had brought with them their knowledge, their culture
and a strong willingness to work. In addition to successful or unsuccessful pre-
the authorities' efforts to rehabilitate the uprooted, the foundation of the whole
effort was the willingness of people to work hard to re-
to recreate what they lost in the catastrophe.
6. The Greek economy during the interwar period
Page 54
53
from the rural economy to urbanization
The rapid changes caused in the country by the consequences of Mi-
wine war, highlighted the need for significant investment
in the country's infrastructure. The urban complex of Athens, for para-
sample, exceeded, with the arrival of refugees, 1,000,000 inhabitants and,
of course, it could no longer be supplied with what was dated by them
Roman times Hadrian's Aqueduct. The solution to the problem was taken over by
1925 The American company OLEN, with the construction of the dam and its
artificial lake in Marathon. At about the same time the British company
PAUER undertook the installation of power generation units
in the capital but also the creation of a modern network of urban farmers-
convoys, based on electric trams and buses. Investments were made
on the telephone network from German companies, on the streets and in the
torrential downpour, which until then often caused floods and
catastrophes in the Attica basin.
Similar efforts were made in the infrastructure of the rest of the country, with
geo-improvement projects, which have resulted in an increase in cultivation-
territories.
In 1927, on the occasion of Greece's request to the League of Nations for
providing an additional loan, raised the issue of creating a
state debt bank, which would undertake debt management, on
issuance of banknotes and the uniform application of government budget-
policy. Despite the reactions of the National Bank and under the pi-
In May 1927, the Bank of Greece was established with the help of foreign consultants.
which started operating a year later. He succeeded very quickly
stable drachma exchange rates with foreign currencies, supporting the issue
banknotes in its gold and foreign exchange reserves and secured
living the convertibility of the national currency into gold. This success
led public finances in a period of euphoria, improved gun-
The state's ability to increase foreign exchange inflows and investments
and caused a strong dynamic that allowed important policies-
his government's latest institutional, institutional and economic initiatives
Eleftheriou Venizelou (1928-1932). This period lasted until the beginning
of 1932, when the consequences of the great economic crisis appeared in the country
crisis, which began in New York in 1929.
7. The big investments
8. The Bank of Greece
Page 55
54
from the rural economy to urbanization
The global economic crisis has reached Greece at a time of "prosperity"
let". "Prosperity" meant that the confidence of the Greeks in a good
More financial future had been restored, the dark times of the decade
1920s seemed to be moving away, wounds were closing, poverty was limited
and the Greek state seemed to be planning the future with greater autonomy.
confidence and optimism.
Greek government's efforts to prevent crisis exhausted-
like the country's reserves of gold and foreign exchange. In the spring of 1932,
however, the government could not avoid suspending the conversion-
the national currency, as well as the suspension of external services
final loans. Thus was inaugurated a period of strong state intervention.
economic issues, especially foreign trade, and a
protectionist policy, aimed at the self-sufficiency of the country. Greece has entered
in turn in the field of closed economy, where transactions continue
they were driven more by bureaucratic processes than by free ones
financial agreements.
In the foreign trade, the method of settlement gradually advanced.
Climbing. In other words, international transactions were not made on the basis of
reversible exchange rate but based on transnational agreements that cost-
like the products to be exchanged and made sure to balance their value
imports with the corresponding exports, in the context of special accounts.
For a country like Greece, where foreign trade was intense
deficient, this process, in addition to the negative, had positive elements
χεια.
The most significant effects, however, of these developments were in the po-
field. The powerful centralized states that emerged from them
processes, provoked the emergence and domination of integrals
movements and regimes in many European countries. As the
the crisis decade, the 1930s, more and more states
dictatorial or fascist regimes. Greece did not escape the ge-
rule of thumb. On August 4, 1936, Ioannis Metaxas, with his tolerance
palace, proceeded with the overthrow of the parliamentary regime and
in the imposition of a dictatorship.

The customer relationship is a voluntary bipolar exchange relationship between
in social institutions of unequal social and economic power, which in-
undertaken to undertake mutual obligations to provide some different-
services, without this network of obligations being included in
a given legal or definitely institutionalized system of evaluations
rules of conduct and corresponding sanctions.
Party: union of citizens who have been grouped together due to common culture
views, interests and goals, in order to conquer through the ka-
maintaining political leadership positions so much power within a state ... that
to be able to carry out their political purposes.

A. EXTERNAL PERSONALITY
AND CUSTOMER RELATIONS (1821-1843)
1. Customer networks during Turkish rule
K Ata the pre-revolutionary period, for objective reasons, Elli-
they were unable to form political parties. There was
but another form of support for their interests, customer di-
keys 1 , in the organization of which the following reasons led:
• competition between persons to seize power,
• the insufficient provision of protection by the Ottoman administration to
its nationals in cases of arbitrariness,
• the absence of a social welfare system, which created
a sense of uncertainty in people.
The above reasons led the citizens to resort to non-state
institutions that would provide them with basic security. The first for-
flow was the wider family. Each family was connected horizontally with al-
You say families and vertically with patrons-protectors and their families, that
they had a higher social status. In the Peloponnese, for example, during
During the period 1715-1821, two large patronage networks were developed, at the top
whose families were selected. Among them prevailed
intense competition for influence at all levels of public-
and for the occupation of public places. Institutions in Central Greece
of the patronage were great. In the islands, moreover, in the leadership of the di-
The families of the big shipowners were in patronage.
Subsequent parties 2 are not a simple evolution of the homeland networks.
1
2

60
The Transformation and LeitYourgia as a political party in GREECE
Politics was, among other things, an important economic activity.
expediency: that is, it was a way of life that sought him and the ex-
they were insured by various, sometimes unorthodox sources. The belief that the
conquering a position enabled its holder to promote,
more than the general good, his personal interests meta-
was brought and maintained in the state mechanism, when with its success
The revolution itself became the object of competition between them
of Greeks. Legitimacy towards the family, which as a group
social had taken precedence over the nation, the staff
interest also made the person often aim at exploitation
of the state machine for the benefit of his relatives and friends, on
to his opponents.
Ioannis Petropoulos - Aikaterini
Koumarianou: IEE, IG, p. 27.
nias. During the Turkish occupation, the political context was a given and indisputable.
the: Ottoman rule. The issues on which they could express themselves
disagreements and differing views were either the claim of public office
or dealing with the little things of everyday life, more
"Technical" texture, such as e.g. public works issues. The bodies of the patron
let them have no say in matters relating to legislation or foreign affairs
policy, and therefore the patronage networks did not form different ones
political views 3 . In general, patronage networks did not work down
on the same terms and did not meet the same needs as
parties.
As long as the Greeks were slaves, they generally maintained a common position.
against the conqueror. When the expulsion of the Turks began,
like the conflicts between the like-minded until then. The main issue
it was about who and how would manage the power. A series of events,
related to the formation of different views on this issue,
led to a stage of formation of the first political parties. The
These events are connected with the descent of Dimitrios Ypsilantis in the inter-
Nestorian Peloponnese, as the power of attorney of Alexander's brother,
General Commissioner of the Friendly Society, in order to take over the leadership
of the Revolution. When Dim. Ypsilantis arrived in Hydra, the Peloponnese-
They had already appointed local government bodies on their own. THE
Ypsilantis wanted to impose his own "General Organization of the Peloponnese-
Your ", which would allow him to concentrate military and political power.

5. Sovereignty is inherent in the Nation: all power comes from it, and

7. All Greeks are equal before the law.
36. The sovereignty of the Nation is divided into three powers: Legislative, Legal
ceremonial and judicial.
37. Legislation constructs laws.
38. The Legislature ratifies them under Article 73 and executes them.
39. The Court adapts them.
40. Legislative power belongs in particular to the House of Representatives
of the people, which is called Parliament.
41. The legislature belongs to a single, so-called Governor,
various Secretaries of State under him.
42. The Judiciary in the various courts.
Kapodistrias ... proceeded methodically to the election of persons for
filling senior government positions. First try to re-
act with persons capable of successfully responding to serious sit-
near them, but at the same time to satisfy as fair as possible
personal ambitions: finally tried to satisfy the three parties-
as well as the various regions of the country, in order to avoid dissatisfaction-
schemes and misunderstandings both at home and abroad.

Around these parties, as well as a third, the Russian, rallied
the proxies in the Third National Assembly 6 .
The existence of the first parties was now a given. This, after all, seems to be
It is also evident from Kapodistrias' move to man a consultant
instrument, the "Panhellenic", with representatives of all three factions, pre-
text to ensure internal peace 7 .
The first three Greek parties were named each (by the opponents-
of his) with the name of a great Power. Their name implied that
these were centers of service to the interests of these Powers
in Greece. It has been argued that the core of these parties
favored foreign consulates in the Ottoman Empire-
around which others, who were expecting, rallied
provide post-revolutionary easy personal advancement and protection
from opponents. However, this view is not confirmed by the facts.
the. The attitude of the parties was not shaped by the choices of the Powers
but from the pursuit of the problems faced by the under-
states that were often opposed to the pursuit of power.

who had studied or lived in

their nationalist and democratic
ideas. They felt the need for a state
their law, which would secure them
their property and business

English leaders and followers
party started from the thought that
had matured since the early decades

He was waiting for Britain's support in its territorial claims
Greece, while Britain took a clear position in favor of the integrity of Otho-
Manichaean Empire. The Greek politician believed that the dissolution was progressing
of the Ottoman Empire would force England to choose the alliance-
Greece in the region, as a barrier to Russia's expansionist plans.
The English party, therefore, considered that the Greeks should form
a strong state body and to anticipate developments in the Ottoman Empire
empire.
The choices of the English party were also influenced by the perception that
Britain was a model for the development of the internal situation
of the country. As the fundamental principles of the political system, the English party
considered the parliamentary representative system and their distinction
powers, principles which he supported throughout his release
fight. Mavrokordatos initially wanted the state organization to be appointed.
with a written constitution, but later changed his position and saw
the constitution as the final act of a series of internal reforms.

party was widely believed to have liberated the unredeemed

clearly formulated in the National Assembly the "Great Idea": The Kingdom
it was only a small poor part of Greece. The most important thing-
It was occupied by the Ottomans and all the forces of the nation had to
allocated for the release of this section.
The French party's program, in terms of domestic policy, was
vague. The satisfaction of the demands of the war veterans was the
only clear claim. The main political goal of the party was to

The Transformation and LeitYourgia as a political party in GREECE
cessation of the rights of the people towards monarchical power, with the pa-
drafting a constitution, and establishing a strong executive branch.
During the Bavarian period, the French party fought against it
of xenophobia in the army and administration and demanded manning
with Greek executives.
The French party supported the policy of expanding territorial boundaries
of the state, expressing primarily the interests of the naughty, the
who could only make a living from the war. Certainly,
The concern of refugees from unresolved areas was their release
of their particular homeland. Because of this policy, it was also called "national
party".
Its members saw France as a natural ally, primarily because
they believed that only France, which was less mixed than all the others
foreign forces in the affairs of the eastern Mediterranean, would help El-
oil, without wanting to affect her choices. Many party supporters
they had an imaginary image of France, which they regarded as their model.
c. The Russian party
In contrast to his relatively vague positions and confused ideology
French party, the Russian was characterized by stable political positions.
The similarity with the other two parties was that in the Great
A force in which they based their hopes on foreign policy, re-
they also knew a model for the internal organization of the country. Russia
could be accepted by a large section of the population because it was the
unique Great Power with an Orthodox Christian doctrine.
A feature of the Russian party was its highly conservative stance
in all its options. The foundation of social order was therefore religion.
plain. The legitimacy of power was based on it. He saw the Church
in constant danger and fighting cosmopolitanism and any
distance from traditions. Xenophobia, as well as its denial
Enlightenment and Western education were their dominant perceptions
of its members. In order to reach wider strata, he addressed
often in the religious sentiment of the Greeks. With this party co-
were overthrown, especially during the time of the country's rule by Ka-
pawnbroker, those who had suffered greatly during the Revolution and
during the civil wars: landless people, small landowners, militants
and low-ranking officers, monks, and civil servants appointed-
even by Kapodistrias and after his murder they were fired. All of them

B. HANDMADE AND DEVELOPMENT (1844-1880)
1. The Constitution of 1844
The revolution of September 3, 1843 catalyzed the formation.
phase of political affairs. Political and ideological perceptions
of the parties were expressed more clearly and the parties began
to play a more active role in the country's political life. During
of the discussions on the constitution, the differences between them became clearer.
However, all three parties supported the constitution. Even the
Russian considered the adoption of a constitution the only solution, since it was not
Otto may be overthrown. So what is required during the process is
education of the constitution was the restriction of the king's powers.
The dynamic presence of parties in the country's political life proves-
and from the fact that their three leaders led the work of the Nation-
Page 72
71
The Transformation and LeitYourgia as a political party in GREECE
The revolution of September 3, 1843, as depicted in folk lithography of the time.
(Athens, Benaki Museum)
assembly during 1843-1844. These leaders managed to avoid them
extreme positions, to impose themselves on the radical groups of their parties
and take joint decisions on constitutional arrangements. The com-
factions agreed to the need to secede constitutionally
some fundamental rights: equality before the law, prohibition
slavery, the inviolability of the family asylum, freedom of opinion
and type, property protection, free education. All anti-
persons realized that there were values ​​and rights they had to
protected from the arbitrariness of state power. It was a weakness
the fact that the right to assemble and co-exist was not constitutionally guaranteed.
get involved, which could bring obstacles to party formation-
mechanisms.
The constitution also defined the royal powers. Among the great-
the king's participation in the exercise of legislative power was another
and the head of state and army. But he had no action

During the period of the Crimean War 13 the English and French parties lost-
Were you going to ratify friendly elections? Straightforward and very troublesome-
you were misrepresented or described as insignificant irregularities: and the
Violence, this attitude, was called a fair defense, and injustice, immorality, lying
do, justice, moderation, truth. And those words changed meaning:
The violation of the polls was called a contraction of the boards, and you
polka dot oil and ballot boxes, the licking of the seals at random
crushing, the notaries on the voting committees and the apo-
The chosen ones of this people ... The law now had to sleep, now
it does not wake up, it is never interpreted literally, and never in a sense
and sometimes to be distorted and the clear, the purest, the most explicit
provisions. What political and moral irrelevance!
The cause of the Crimean War (1853-1856) was the conflict between the Orthodox
and Catholic monks to control the holy places in Jerusalem.
Russia and France intervened and a general conflict ensued.
with the participation of England, Turkey and Austria in the anti-Russian
front. Russia was defeated and forced to give up some
territories, while its international prestige has declined significantly.
