like the confidence of their fans, after the violent behavior of England
and France against Greece, with the naval blockade of the country. It had
preceded by the Patsifiko 14 case , which had complicated their relations
countries. The Russian party had some temporary gains from this. But the defeat
Russia's involvement in the Crimean War has contributed to the party's weakening,
which gradually disappeared from the political scene.
The decline of foreign parties coincides with the emergence of a new one
generation of people with completely different mentalities and backgrounds. The
leading figures of foreign parties had experienced the Revolution-
and their mentality, their ideals, their views were formed
in the pre-revolutionary period. For the next generation, the Revolution
belonged to history. This generation was experiencing rapid changes due to the frequent ones
political changes and economic and technical development, which follows
they were experiencing unprecedented rhythms. Economic and social change had
as a consequence the fundamental change in the perception of life. People
they stopped living like their ancestors. The urban population has increased, o
which was closer to the decision-making centers and had a bigger one
possibility of updating on developments. The impression was also impressive.
illiteracy in the male population. The relatively fast spread
of education increased social tensions. The demands of these people
were dried. Even the semi-educated began to criticize his dysfunctions
state and delay in relation to Western countries, while intensified
the desire to participate in political affairs. The new generation did not have the experience-
of the previous one (Turkish occupation, revolution, regency, help of
Forces at critical moments) and distanced itself from the controversy
which dominated the previous generation and by the parties that
they were blocking.
In April 1849 an Athenian mob looted his British home
citizenship of the Jew Don Patsifiko. He demanded excessive compensation
and called on the British government to intervene
embassy. The British government made a show of strength and imposed it
1850 naval blockade of Greece, with the requirement to settle the
the case of Patsifiko and some other British nationals. After
France and Russia reacted strongly to the blockade.

4. The National Assembly of 1862-1864
The rebels have announced the election of representatives for the National Assembly,
which would vote for a new constitution. 15 Elections were held in November
1862. Most of the elected representatives came from a local-
ballot papers, without party interventions. This is another proof
that the "foreign" parties had gone bankrupt. In the National Assembly
the nuclei of the two major factions, the plains and the mountains, were preserved.
NDV as they named.
The leaders were led by Dimitrios Voulgaris, who undermined them
parliamentary institutions. With interventions in the army he tried to create
creation of a body of "Praetorians" * to ensure his stay in
power. Political groups and institutions stood in the way of his pursuit. THE
A Bulgarian found followers among those who had been illegally appointed
in the army or in the public, and they were afraid of losing their position in case-
Conditions of Parliamentary Legitimacy, Unemployed
urine and micro-growers. The mountains were made up of several
teams (under D. Grivas and K. Kanaris) with the common goal of resisting
field policy. They found supporters among small farmers,
farmers, traders and shipowners.
The people actively participated in the formation of these two factions. Mi-
other political formations had a greater impact: The National Committee ,
under Epamineondas Deligiorgis, who supported the development of the community-
parliamentarism and modernization of the country, economic development and with-
reforms in the administration and the army, cultural spread in Otho-
Manichaean Empire. The Eclectic was a diverse faction of outsiders
politicians, scholars and officers, with moderate positions, which try-
He wanted to mediate between the other factions and support a stable
governments.
The sufferings of the Homeland ceased. The provinces and the capital
After the army was defeated, they put an end to them. As a common expression
of the Hellenic Nation as a whole is proclaimed and voted:
The reign of Otto is abolished. An interim government is recommended
such as the government of the state until the convening of the National Assembly,
consisting of the following citizens: Dimitrios Voulgaris President, Consta-
Dinou Kanari, Venizelou Roufou. National Constituent Assembly is convened
immediately for the drafting of the State and election of a ruler.
Cheer for the nation! Long live Patrice!
He was born in Athens in 1862 and died on the tenth of October

Grigorios Dafnis: IEE, IGD, p. 295.
says the government should come from the parliamentary majority.
What was not clearly defined, because it was taken for granted, was that the ba-
He had to give the order to form a government to his deputy
party that had the confidence of the majority of Parliament. George
took advantage of this ambiguity to appoint governments of choice
, until the adoption of the principle affirmed in 1875. The idea belonged to
then young politician Charilaos Trikoupis, who publicly claimed that alone
The solution to the problem of political instability was to form two great ones
parties of power, according to the standard of England. To make this happen
possibly, the king had to assign the task of forming a government
only to a politician who clearly had the "declared" confidence of the majority
Member of Parliament. This would deprive minority parties of the opportunity.
If they formed a government, it would unite them with the big ones
and would result in more stable majority governments. The king,
under pressure from the opposition and the revolutionary upheaval of the people,
finally adopted the view of Trikoupis, which is a crossroads in politics
history of the country, as it led to a change in the political landscape 17 .
Royal speech at the Parliament,
August 11, 1875.

A rule of law is a state in which the organization and operation of all
institutions and areas of state power are regulated by rules
of positive law, that is, by laws that the state itself has enacted.
Reinhart Beck: Sachwörterbuch der Politik, Stuttgart 1986, p. 795.
C. JUSTICE AND EXCURSION (1880-1909)
1. The consolidation of bipartisanship
T the period between 1875 and 1880 is a transitional period. At
elections of 1875 and 1879 no party won parliament-
majority. A few years later, in 1884, his two major parties
Trikoupis and Diligiannis controlled 92.2% of the seats in Parliament. The
parliamentary system and bipartisanship were established.
As early as 1875, the Trikoup party presented a systematic pro-
letter of modernization of the country, quite close to the perceptions of Kou-
Moundourou, which provided:
• Establishment of the rule of law 18 ,
• rationalization of management, mainly by determining qualifications
civil servants, in order to limit favoritism,
• development of the economy and mainly strengthening of agriculture,
• Improving defense and infrastructure, mainly transport-
network of the country.
The following efforts were made to implement this program:
1. organizational changes and improvement of the state's finances, with the
increase taxes and lend and
2. Providing incentives for private investment investment.
The Trikoupis consistently followed this program, which, however
resulted in the exhaustion of taxpayers and excessive
budget burden. In 1893 the state declared bankruptcy.
Until the 1870s, the state was the main employer, which
provided jobs in public and social development,
as long as it provided its top officials with almost no income
exceeded the income of all other members of society. Large no-
people turned to the state for a seat in the public-
σιο. With the new conditions that emerged from the monetization of the economy-
Let social strata be created that did not require an appointment but
taking measures that would promote the promotion of their interests. Φο-
Charilaos Trikoupis was in charge of these requests.
18
Page 82
81
Opponents of Trikoupis' policy
MPs rallied around him
Th. Diligiannis, who to a large extent
expressed political views contrary to
those of Ch. Trikoupis. Diligiannis does not
accepted the separation of powers and
aimed at concentration and control
them from the party. Trikoupis considered
the state as the lever of economic re-
folding and sought to modernize with
any costs, while Diligiannis put forward
the demand for social justice, with
reducing taxes and providing opportunities
to his protégés for occupation
public places. In the lands of Thessaly,
dominated by large property,
the Trikoupians supported them greatly
owners, while the Diligianni effort-
they managed, without finally succeeding, to

what measures to improve their position.
Diligiannis criticized the social cost
of modernization and supported a state
social solidarity. His party
he hated the adventurous stock market
capital and supported a slow financial
development based on traditional
productive activities.

relationships and services.
The electoral system did not require a single party to vote, but
enabled all candidates to vote positively or negatively. On-
A voter could vote in favor of a candidate in whom
He had an obligation, but at the same time he could vote in favor of

Cartoon from later times (1915),
which shows how to choose with
beads. (Athens, Museum “Historical Memory
Eleftheriou Venizelou ")
In each polling station there were as many ballots as the candidates in the pe-
radius. Each ballot box, made of white iron, was internally divided into
two parts that corresponded externally to two colors, black and white.
The right side on the front had the word "Yes" in capital letters,
was white, the left, which had the word "No" also in capital letters, was black-
ro. At the top of each ballot was a tube placed at an angle of 25.
degrees, which was 27 inches long and 12 inches in diameter. The voter had to
to go through all the polls and get from the employee, who stood-
when in front of everyone and she had to shout which candidate she was
ballot box, a small lead ball, the ball. As soon as he took it, he picked it up
hand, holding it between the thumb and forefinger to show that
it was one and only one, and then he would put his hand into the tube and throw it away
in the partition corresponding to "Yes" or "No".
19
Grigorios Dafnis: IEE, IGD, p. 241.
The process of voting
Page 85

The Transformation and LeitYourgia as a political party in GREECE
Candidate MPs came almost exclusively from the middle
and the upper social strata, as in the previous period.
Many were lawyers and civil servants. Unlike the candidates-
The party members also came from the lower classes.
The organization of the parties was evident only at the leadership level.
The most important position after the leader was held by the parliamentary group.
The deputies had an important position, because due to the large majority that
It took Parliament to have a quorum and make decisions, MPs
and only with their absence (or threat) could they exercise great-
pressure on the party leadership. Thus, the party's central organization does not
had the opportunity to refuse the deputies the fulfillment of wishes, e.g.
appointments or favorable arrangements in favor of their constituency.
Unlike the time of Otto and the Bulgarian, governments do not
they systematically used coercive methods to persuade them
voters. This rule was violated by some civil servants or fanatics.
fans in the villages. Rarely have there been allegations of vote-buying.
However, patronage, in the form of appointments, transfers, loans, etc. and the
Systematic corruption through the administrative mechanism was frequent
phenomenon.
Unlike other European countries, in the last quarter of the century it did not
class parties emerged *. In Greece many socio-economic anti-
positions were softened through customer relations and with the large, co-
gray with other countries, social mobility. The two major parties do not
tried to give a local or social-class stigma. It is observed
also relative autonomy of the political elite from society. But all
parties were particularly aimed at the peasants, who were the major-
most of the active population.
K Ata period of governing the country by Charilaos Trikou-
The vision for a modern state that would be financially sound
bent and strong on the international stage, it didn't happen. Despite the tax
reasonable burden on citizens, the state was led to bankruptcy. Bourgeois and
intellectuals were increasingly frustrated with the general situation;
attitude and inefficiency of the state, which was characterized

D. RENEWAL - DECLARATION (1909-1922)
1. The Liberal Party
P. Before the elections of August 8, 1910 had not established any
new big party to support reforms which pro-
were fed in 1909/1910. Independent candidates were the bearers of the new ideas,
who either alone or together with others, on independent ballots, claim-
they were voting for those dissatisfied with the old electoral parties. They
independent politicians, with the general slogan of "recovery", depending on
the candidate area and the population to which they were addressed,
meant either the implementation of the demands of the unions, as expressed-
staged rallies in 1909, or the resolution of the peasant issue,
by providing land to landless people. In some constituencies they did
Socialist candidacy and for the first time the socialist appeared-
democratic * "Sociological Society". The old parties participated in
elections as a coalition and finally won the most seats in the Parliament
exp. Out of the 362 seats, 211 secured, while 29 seats won independently
belonging to the political space of the old parties and 122 independent
modernizers.
The modernists rallied around the face of the Cretan leader
Eleftheriou Venizelou, who was elected without participating in the election
match. Venizelos' first public appearance as a Greek politician
was held on September 5, 1910 with a speech at 22 Syntagma Square , in
which made programmatic statements, in which it supported moderates
reforms. It aimed at modernizing the political system, with

fell ... into an instrument of oppression at the hands of the factions. Administration-

balancing the interests of all social strata. Basic
Positions of his program were social peace, the alleviation of cat-
higher social strata, the modernization of the state mechanism,
in order to make it more efficient, and military equipment
for the realization of national claims. Also, despite their pressure
his supporters, supported the revision of the existing constitution and
not the new vote. He did not raise a state issue. He announced the establishment
a party of principles, which would be the bearer of reforms. Party
It was formally founded on August 22, 1910, by members of the National Assembly.
Venizelos was ordered to form a government after her resignation
Dragoumi Government (October 6, 1910). Because, however, he faced pre-
missiles by securing a vote of confidence, in consultation with the base-
Georgios AI proceeded with the dissolution of the Parliament and the announcement of new elections
of land. This step upset the old parties which, considering
unconstitutional king's move, they decided not to participate
in the elections of November 1910. In these the Liberals won the co-
embarrassing majority of seats. 307, a total of 362. Venizelos was now
free to proceed with his reform work.
In the first half of 1911, 53 amendments were passed by Parliament
non-fundamental provisions of the constitution. There have been no radical changes, but
on the contrary, the position of the monarchy was strengthened and the king was allowed, in spite of it
constitutional prohibition, to participate in the review process.
The most important amendments concerned the safeguarding of discrimination
of power, the incompatibility between military and civil service
property on the one hand and parliamentary office on the other, and permanence
judicial and civil servants.

146 deputies, while the other parties only 36. In these elections it appeared that the

because the innovations that were proposed gave birth to the hope for a solution
significant social problems.
As for the structure of the Venizelos party, this was to a large extent
single faces. Venizelos, with a strong position in Parliament and great
prestige, he had everything under his control, as did Trikoupis. The links
Liberals who were founded did not play a special role in the
education of the party's policy and did not differ significantly from the topi-
groups of friends who formed the traditional parties. In 1912 it began to
the party is reorganized, with the establishment of the Liberal Club in Athens
and in some other constituencies. The Venizelists had created in
mind an imaginary party, without the smallness and discord of the old po-

Lithuanian elite, but that had nothing to do with reality. The leadership had to
necessarily take into account social and local interests as well
rivalries between executives, as was the case with any other party.
Oh s anti-Venizelists considered opposition parties. Despite the
disputes between them were united by a conservative pro-
Orientation. However, they did not want to return to the pre-1909 era.
Therefore, in this respect they did not differ in principle from the Liberals. Die-
but they also went beyond the planned reforms and methods
policy. The anti-Venizelists hated constant intervention
of the state, because, among other things, it would have the effect of strengthening
of the executive branch. They did not have a long-term policy, on the contrary,
they focused on solving current problems. The
anti-Venezuelan parties have developed into parties defending the interests of
who were in danger from the policy of the Liberals. The conflict with
he led the Liberals to more conservative positions. From
anti-Venezuelan parties, the most uncompromising were the parties of Dimitrios Rallis
and Kyriakoulis Mavromichalis, while the party of Georgios Theotokis was more
compromising.
The Rally party was opposed to modernization. It was against the power-
of the executive branch, as it was formed at the end of the 19th
century and as required by the reformist policy of the Liberals.
He argued that Parliament should have a strong position in the political system.
but. In the face of the king, however, he saw the symbol of national unity
exceeding the country's borders. It was addressed mainly to the met-
smooth and lower layers of cities as well as micro-growers,
as the Liberals' economic policy seemed to favor,
mainly the upper urban strata. It called for increased production and
job creation, so that with economic growth they can be found
money for equipment, to fight corruption and patronage
parties. However, the Rally Party did not have a structured program.
but for economic growth.
The National Party of K. Mavromichalis did not differ from the rally. The representatives
his troops were trying to take advantage of their leader's participation
in political affairs after the 1909 movement. They supported "Anorthosis",
which, in their estimation, the Venizelists could not implement.
G. Theotokis' party was more moderate than the other two and demanded that

correct what he considered the Liberals' mistakes. He agreed with her
at all costs increased equipment and demanded tax breaks for
micro-participants. From the Goudi movement to the constitutional crisis
of 1915, among the anti-Venizelist parties the Theotokos party had the me-
better electoral base, and so was the core of the Anti-Venezuelan.
The left parties were initially groups with socialist ideas, usually
foreign to the social base on which they wanted to address, and
faced difficulties in reconciliation and party mobilization.
More serious than all these groups was the Sociological Society, the
which was started by some intellectuals as a leftist reformist
association, with the aim of propagating political positions and then to
establish a party. He sought equality for all members of society,
socialization of the means of production and distribution of goods accordingly
everyone's needs, which could be implemented gradually-
economic reform and constitutional change. To achieve
If these goals were to be achieved, workers had to be organized professionally
associations and found a party. Indeed, in the middle of 1910 the Sociologists
They founded the People's Party, led by Alexandros Papanastasiou. Basic
His programmatic statements were the reform of the political system
and the imposition of social justice principles. In the second election of 1910
7 party candidates were elected, who provided critical support
to the Liberals.
As early as 1912, after his sweeping election victory, Venizelos was
dominant of the political game, without substantial parliamentary anti-
state. In 1913, King George II was succeeded by Constantius.
Dinos, to whom Venizelos, a year earlier, granted the office
of the general. Until 1915, the two powerful personalities did not come
in conflict. Opposition parties have stated they will not run in the by-elections
right to impose its own view on foreign policy, para-
seeing that this was unconstitutional. This strengthened the enemies
of parliamentary democracy, above all a circle of anti-democrats
officers.

even in illegal means (eg delivery of confidential diplomacy
documents to the Germans). In 1915 she twice resigned
government.

the Liberals did not participate, as they considered the king's energy
as a violation of the constitution. Manifestations of violence and fanaticism
as a gap between the two factions and hatred prevailed. Whoever it was
against the war, he immediately aroused the suspicion of the Venizelists that he was
against parliamentary democracy, against national interests. The
Anti-Venezuelan people saw violent agents in the face of the Venizelists
Entente, who fought the king, destroyed the unity of the nation and
endangered the state. The two parties differed less and less.

The j high unemployment rates and poor working and living conditions
of workers led to their intense politicization, during the second-
in the 1920s. Conditions gave the impression that the rich
they became richer and the poor poorer. In 1918, the Soviet Union was founded .
Hellenic Workers' Party of Greece (SEKE) from a socialist congress. King
The positions of his program were democracy, the provision of suffrage.
but to women, proportional electoral system, nationalization of adults
wealth-producing sources. On foreign policy, he called for peace
without the annexation of territories, based on their right to self-determination
peoples. The disputes over disputed lands would be resolved
with referendums.

The S.E.K.E. it was the most strictly organized party. Until 1919 it was in favor

The Transformation and LeitYourgia as a political party in GREECE
With the Asia Minor catastrophe (1922) the developed economies were lost.
small and cultural areas of Asia Minor and Eastern Thrace-
κης. This was the last act of the Great Idea. No party
it no longer promoted the choice of territorial expansion and war.
This major change has caused an identity crisis in Greece, given
that the Great Idea was for almost a century the foundation on which many
other people based the reason for the existence of the state. The majority of pre-
Refugees sided with the Liberals, believing that the Anti-Venezuelan
who were responsible for the disaster.
The constant degradation of the living standards of large parts of the population
affected the development of the parties during this period. When
foreign policy has become the focus of interest,
Conflicts of economic interests came to the fore
and social character. To many people (regardless of politics-
Residents of the burning Smyrna are trying to board boats and escape.
The Asia Minor catastrophe and the influx of refugees have catalyzed the country's political life.
E. EXCLUSION AND INTERVENTIONS (1923-1936)
1. The consequences of the Asia Minor catastrophe

The fatigue was caused by the permanent political instability and the looting.
exacerbation cultivated by party staffs and coups
officers 23 . To this was added the dissatisfaction with the conflicts of interest.
political, economic and social structures, as well as for the plethora
of different political ideologies. So Metaxas didn't have to
to use force to impose his dictatorship in 1936.
Dissatisfied situations cause crisis of parliamentary legitimacy
system. Its roots were in the division of the decade 1910-20,
But the crisis peaked the following season, when it was undermined
confidence in the effectiveness of the political system, which
1. September 1922, by the Venizelist N. Plastiras. Requests: His resignation
Constantinou, immediate dissolution of the National Assembly, formation of a supra-party
government entrusted to it by the Entente and the strengthening of the Thrace-
front. As part of the movement, the trial of the six took place.
2. October 1923, from a mixture of anti-Venezuelan, Venizelos that were in
smens, kings who feared the imposition of the unruly demo-
state, under the leadership of Generals Gargalidis and Leonardopoulos. Ai-
issues: dissolution of the previous movement, appointment of a new government
to hold elections. It was sent almost immediately. The cinemas of '22
proceeded to clear the army of 1,284 anti-Venizelists
officers, whom they accused of participating in the 1923 movement.
They pressed and finally succeeded King George II of Greece and
they discussed the issue of non-monarchical democracy.
3. June 1925, by Th. Pangalos. Excuse: save the country from Ms.
administration. He remained in power until August 1926, at first
as Prime Minister and then as President of the Republic.
4. August 1926, by G. Kondylis. He overthrew Pangalos, promised before
announcing elections within 45 days, in which he would not take part.
The movement was completed before the elections of November 7, 1926, para-
giving power to politicians.
5. March 1933, by Plastiras, in order to prevent the People's Party from
take power after the election victory. He did not manage to establish himself
his own government, but suppressed.
6. March 1935, by Venizelist officers. Objective: to prevent dictatorship
by Kondylis, establishment of a government with a program: their liquidation
armed forces by anti-Venizelists, reform of the regime-
the. It collapsed after a few days.
7. October 1935, by Kondylis. Objective: abolition of the non-royal di-
democracy. It lasted until November 1935 and was disbanded upon arrival
of King George II.
23 military movements during the period 1922-1936.

The Transformation and LeitYourgia as a political party in GREECE
is the foundation of legality in modern societies. Two items and
they blurred the physiognomy of the political life of this period: the perpetual
military intervention in politics and the use of force in the exercise of po-
liturgical.
Officials claimed first place in domestic politics
as they considered the army to be a supra-party body. They felt
dissatisfaction with social differences, they hated
the political way of dealing with and settling social conflicts-
negotiations and compromises, which were considered synonymous
corruption and lack of principles.
Immediately after the defeat in the Asia Minor campaign, they intervened in politics.
officers who were leading military corps returning to life
from the front (N. Plastiras, St. Gonatas, etc.). What sharpened politics
The situation was the trial and death sentence of five of its top politicians
anti-Venezuelan faction and the commander of the army of Central Asia, with the
category of ultimate betrayal. The charge was unfounded, but the cat-
The refugees were executed in order to appease the refugees and the
army. Venizelos' telegram, which indirectly recommended the cancellation

Venizelos' intervention would have an effect 24 .
The desire for professional security of Venizelists and anti-Venizelists
officers created a dynamic of continuous military intervention
in politics. In parallel with the parties, "groups" were formed.
officers or acting officers, who were increasingly trying
to bring Parliament and governments under control and ultimately
to impose anti-parliamentary systems of government. The parties with me
they had difficulty escaping the suffocating siege and very often

The party leaderships were now in a great mood for defeat.
the constitution and the strengthening of repression mechanisms, for the following
reasons:
1. They sought to neutralize the political opponent by any means possible.
2. They were obliged to come to terms with "groups" of officers
select them and accept their requests.
3. They believed that complex social and economic problems would be solved.
better a strong executive power and

Democratic Union, under Al. Papanastasiou. He supported the abbey

for both sexes, decentralization, local government and administration

but.

They changed the size of constituencies and used a majority
or proportional electoral system, according to their needs.
And during this period, the main program goal of the Liberals
It was, as in the past, the modernization of the country, according to
to European standards. Liberal supporters were the bourgeois ep-
entrepreneurs (who were looking for conditions of stability, modern and
effective institutions), the refugees and the farmers in whom he had
granted land.
In political practice the Liberals were faced with two years before
missiles: the relationship of political power with officers, and everything-
stoic. The constant controversy within the party over issues
these caused contradictory choices. About the regime, other followers
they were in favor of the regent and others in favor of the reigning democracy.
As for the party's relationship with the officers, on the one hand
it was understood that their politicization posed risks to it
state, but on the other hand the phenomenon had acquired such dynamics,
supported the distribution of land to refugees and farmers. It was against the establishment
senate.
Liberal Party. The leader of Ioannis Metaxas was an enemy

and chanted slogans in favor of reconciliation.
ratings. He rejected the Senate as an anti-popular institution. It was presented as

the state of the non-royal democracy was established 26 . In place of the ba-
The President of the Republic, elected by the Parliament and the

During the period 1928-1932 the Government of the Liberals has to show
significant achievements in terms of the country's economic recovery, the
education and foreign policy. In the 1932 elections, however, the Liberals
they suffered heavy losses and lost the vast majority of its seats
Parliament. In the new elections in 1933, the coalition of the People's Party prevailed.
the.
3rd phase: 1933-1935
Plastiras, with the tolerance of Venizelos, attempted a military movement, the-
seeking to prevent the People's Party from forming a government. Plastiras
shared the concerns of Venezuelan officers who saw them
their professional development is endangered if it formed a government
the People's Party. The movement was suppressed, but in political life it intensified again.
the presence of the tactic of violence. In addition to the military began
and politicians to justify the use of force again. The Tsaldari government, which
emerged from the 1933 election, attempted to follow a mild path
and announced that it would not adopt the tactics of arbitrary prosecutions
opponents, but would rely only on independent justice. Three months,
but after the Plastira movement, an attempt was made to assassinate Venizelos.
This sharpened the spirits and fanaticism in both camps.
It culminated in the demobilization of Venizelist officers.
This has caused insecurity among Venizelists, politicians and the military.
The anti-Venizelist officers, the more they strengthened their positions, the more they exercised
pressure on Tsaldaris to end negotiations with the Liberals. The

Intense contradictions between the two parties have both led to fear
that each aims to dissolve the other.
Conspiracy circles of various officers were formed during this period.
shades, which functioned as pressure groups in institutional terms.
gana and waited to find the opportunity for surgery. Venizelos goes ahead-
in March 1935 to a failed military movement, aiming
again in clearing the army and police of the royals.
It was this failed movement that gave the government a hand in it
pressure from officers on the other side, to toughen its stance: dismantle it

neuralgia. The Liberals abstained from the June 9, 1935 elections
On October 10, 1935, Kondylis attempted a military movement, targeting it
restoration of the kingdom.
4th phase: 1935-1936
The referendum of November 3, 1935 put an end to the unruly
democracy with a rate of 97.6%, a product of unprecedented fraud and terrorism.
After the arrival of the king, the regime of Kondylis withdrew from it
power. George II, with the support of royal officers,
personal policy followed. He dissolved the National Assembly and announced
elections for January 26, 1936. In the new Parliament, the Anti-Venezuelans had one
headquarters more than their opponents and no one could form-

The Transformation and LeitYourgia as a political party in GREECE
EPILOGUE
The Metaxas regime ruled authoritarianly. In essence, there was one
police regime with fascist tendencies, but did not manage to overthrow him
state mechanism as a whole, as was the case in Germany
and Italy. He confronted his opponents, especially the Communists,
whom he tried to exterminate, by imprisonment and deportation. Απαγο-
flowed, among other things, freedom of speech and freedom of assembly
stand and cooperate.
After the conquest of Greece by the Axis powers, the Greek
The people organized a strong national resistance and made great sacrifices.
The end of the war was followed by the most catastrophic civil war
met the country in which the bourgeois faction emerged victorious
parties. The political situation was slow to normalize. The shadow of the civil war
war weighed on the country's political life until the dictatorship of the pres-
mayor in 1967, which put an end to the stagnant young post-war
democracy.
The situation changed radically after the fall of the dictatorship in 1974. With a lot
fast-paced undemocratic democratic state, the div-
The country's past has been overcome, and the country has embarked on a process of
synchronization and renewal.

Page 114

IN GREECE

security and fear that prevails-

but these actions in a gen-

the period 1914-1922. The pre-

country and the Aegean were a consequence
of the failure of the release-

A. THE REFUGEE ISSUE
DURING THE GREEK REVOLUTION (1821-1827)
1. Refugees from Asia Minor,
Istanbul and Cyprus
M after uprising of maritime islands and Samos, the fovi- Turks
were considered that the dense Greek element of the western Asia Minor para-
lion would not remain inactive. The effervescence that prevailed in Greek
cities of Asia Minor, the daring raids of Samians and Psarians on
coasts of Asia Minor and the appearance of Greek ships near Kydonia (Ai-
suitcase) and Smyrna expelled the Turks in measures of terror
Greek populations. The violence of the Turks in Istanbul
functioned as a danger signal for several wealthy Greeks of Kydos-
who, for safety's sake, rushed to safety
opposite Lesvos. This was followed by the destruction of the city of Kydonia by
Turkish troops in early June 1821, which led them to frighten-
its residents on a riotous escape to Psara, while a number of fugitives from
looted villages around Kydonia resorted to Lesvos.
Further south, in Izmir, when the residents were informed of the tragic fate
of Kydonia, boarded merchant ships and dispersed in inter-
once islands of the Aegean Sea and the Peloponnese.
The persecuted from inside also took refuge in Psara and Samos
Asia Minor, trying to escape persecution and attacks
naughty *.
Refugees of the same period can also be included
refugees from Istanbul and Cyprus. The first, mainly Fa-
Nariots, already before the riots in the city, began to flock to the re-
seduced Greece, where very quickly distinguished themselves in political organization-
of the rebellious nation. Many Cypriots to avoid persecution
of the Turks, took refuge in the Consulates of the Great Powers and then
were transported by foreign ships to ports in Italy and France.
In the Third National Assembly (1826-1827) various groups of refugees had
Sheltered in Free Greece Attempted to Assert Her Request
their installation and especially their permanent installation. That's why they sought it
their representation in the Assembly. Of the Asia Minor, only the Smyr-
were activated in this direction. They asked the Co-
freedom: a) to be represented in it and b) to determine a place for it
creation of a settlement of the scattered free Smyrnaeans. Only
Page 119
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
118
the request of the place was initially accepted. It was decided to give space to
Isthmus area to create a city called "Nea Smyrni".
The Assembly referred the matter to Parliament, which, however, did not promote it.
The refugees from Asia Minor during the Revolution faced it
survival problems, especially Kydonians 1 . The need to secure them
basic living conditions, but also their geographical distribution, it seems that they do not
they were left with the opportunity to claim political representation and
administrative bodies of revolutionary Greece. His offer, however
Asia Minor element in the spiritual life and popular culture of the new-
most Hellenism was important.
T the refugee stream from the northern Greek provinces, Thessaly, Make-
vibrations and continent, started almost simultaneously with the migratory flow-
but from Asia Minor. However, it continued during the second year of the Revolution.
also, in two main directions: a) from Thessaly and Macedonia
to the Northern Sporades and b) from Epirus and Agrafa to the West
Solid and especially Messolonghi.
In the Northern Sporades (Skiathos, Skopelos, Skyros) and the Trikeri of Magni-
Residents of Thessaly and Central Macedonia initially took refuge.
Kedonia, after the advance of the Turkish troops and the failure
of the revolutionary movement in Magnesia and Halkidiki (spring 1821). The
The following year, after the repression of the movement on Mount Olympus, they resorted to

Sporades, many fighters and chiefs from Macedonia and Olympus.
A small number then headed to the Cyclades and some individually-
living in Central Greece.
Refugee overcrowding in the Sporades brought poverty and confusion
anarchy. Local authorities found themselves weak, not just caring for them
needy and hungry newcomers, but also to maintain order,
as some of them turned to robbery and piracy. Krou-
The refugees from Olympus, in particular, were particularly violent.
dominated by the rulers of the islands and the terror of the natives 2 .
Large waves of refugees from Epirus headed to Western Ste-
rea, to avoid Turkish retaliation, after the repression of the movement-
but in the summer of 1821. Crowds gathered in Messolonghi. Last
The Souliotes arrived in the early 1823, through the Ionian Islands, after the
solution to the siege of Souli.
The Soulian refugees arrived at a time when Mesolonghi
for, after the expulsion of the Turks from the Western Continent, it had now been burdened
too much. The locals were very upset about this constant influx of pre-
refugee populations. To relieve the city, the Parliament granted
to the Souliotes Zapanti, northwest of Agrinio. Organized though
local reactions thwarted the planned land concession for
refugee settlement. Despite the failure, this decision is her
first idea to rehabilitate refugees in the years of the Struggle and brought

in the foreground the question of exploiting the "national lands" that were to be
later occupied by the modern Greek state.
From the refugees from Epirus, the Souliotes were the first to succeed-
They went to the Third National Assembly, where they raised the issue of the concession
place for permanent installation.
From the very first year of the Revolution, armed Cretans took refuge
gan, initially in small numbers, in the Cyclades. After the destruction of Kasos
from the Egyptian fleet in 1824, the Cassians and the Cretans who had
resorted there, headed to other Aegean islands. The arrival of the Cretans
caused unrest in the central Aegean. Until the middle of the decade, the
All Cretan refugees had become dominant to the detriment of the homelands. Another
A group of Cretan refugees of 1823-1824 took refuge in the Peloponnese. In
Argolida, the government took care of their nutrition and care.
b. The Chios refugees
After the destruction of Chios and the mass transfer of its inhabitants to
Fish, a problem arose from the large number of refugees who flooded it
island. The Psarians showed care again, giving to the Chians before
handicrafts. The inseparable created was treated as
and earlier, with the transfer of a large number of Chians to the Cyclades and the
Peloponnese. In general, the mood of the Cyclades towards them was friendly and
the Chians adapted easily.
Those transported to the Peloponnese were found in the burning Corinth
They will be hungry and without any care. Some landed in Pei-
They went to Athens from there. The government has taken care of everyone
them: provided housing and accommodation and covered the cost
the maintenance of the poor, widows and orphans. Then inter-
distributed the refugees to surrounding villages and towns and asked them
privileged to take care of them. However, the treatment measures weakened in
a month, because the government had to save resources for the preparation-
defense of the defense, in view of the upcoming campaign of Dramalis.
The nostalgia for their particular homeland and the hardships of exile
they stimulated the desire of the Chians to return to their island, even if that
was under Turkish occupation. From October 1822, many began
3. Refugees from the Aegean islands and Crete
a. Cretans and Cassian refugees
Page 122
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
121
to return. Those who remained, unlike other refugees, worked
throughout the Revolution, not for restoration in places where
they had appealed, but for recapture of their island. The failed ep-
operation of Faviero (1827-1828), prepared by Chian refugees
To this end, he put an end to these efforts and gave birth to a new one
wave of Chios refugees to Samos and the Cyclades.
c. The Psarian refugees
In June 1824, it was time for the Psarians to flee.
About 3,600 left the ruined island for other islands
of the Aegean sea. Few fled to Nafplio.
In the Cyclades, where they were mainly directed, they were not dealt with everywhere
in the same way. They were welcomed in Tinos, whose community
immediately rushed to maintain them. From there, most moved
in neighboring Syros or later returned to their homes. In Paros and the
Andros faced problems with the locals. On the contrary, the people of Spetses
they treated them mercifully, forgetting the old rivalries
of the two maritime islands. But when the Psarians showed a willingness to leave
Standing permanently in Spetses, the people of Spetses reacted. Thus the Psarians re-
they were forced to relocate and, with government permission, settle in
Monemvasia.
The government took care of their housing, set them to collect a share
from the taxes of the area and compiled a list of the prisoners Psaria-
for their acquisition. Nevertheless, the Psarians of Monemvasia consider
as if their plight had not been adequately addressed
dramatically with the outbreak of a deadly epidemic. Most Psarians
they later left Monemvasia and scattered again in the Cyclades.
In Aegina, more than anywhere else, they found the place of permanence
installation they sought. They developed great activity in the public
issues of the island, but also in the affairs of the nation in general. Ίδρυσαν
school, spread their customs and until the middle of the century kept it
their community system.
In the Third National Assembly, the Psarians asked for a delay in determining
place of their refugee settlement. Having secured space in practice
installation in Aegina was not pressed, like others.
d. The refugee settlement of Ermoupolis, Syros
It is worth looking in more detail at the creation of Ermoupolis in Syros.
Page 123
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
122
It is a representative sample of the establishment and development of an independent and
prosperous refugee settlement during the Revolution, which-
which was based on the initiative of its residents, without government assistance.
The area, which in 1825 was renamed Ermoupolis by the refugees eco-
From 1821 to 1824, Greek refugees began to gather there
from all parts of Greece: Asia Minor, Psarians, Cretans and mainly Chians.
The congestion that had occurred on the neighboring islands, the location of the port and the
a neutral stance taken by the island in the early years of the Revolution
called the crowd. The local Syrians lived in Ano
Syros, far from the beach, where the newcomers gathered.
Soon the increased influx of refugees caused caution-
and then the reactions of the locals, mainly due to real estate
disputes. The difference was further fueled by the doctrine difference between them
Catholics and Orthodox refugees.
In general , the refugee issue during the Revolution is not
was methodically located by the Greek political leadership. Where

B. THE REFUGEE ISSUE AGAINST
THE CAPODISTRIAN AREA (1828-1831)
1. Caring for refugees
The inability of revolutionary governments to deal systematically
with the refugee issue bequeathed another thorny problem-
but to Governor Ioannis Kapodistrias. In a ruined Greece, in which
Poverty and anarchy prevailed and its borders were still an object
of international definition, Kapodistrias found himself in a multitude of problems-
of. For Kapodistrias, the formation of a basic state body preceded-
the restoration of the security climate in the country and the finding of an economy-
mixed resources. The issue of refugees was not treated as independent,
but was part of a broader plan.
In principle, there had to be provision for immediate care for the elderly
number of the needy and the victims of the war as a whole, domestic and
refugees facing an immediate survival problem. Upon his arrival
in Aegina, Kapodistrias gave orders to compile lists of pre-
refugees and to temporarily meet their urgent needs. With the foundation-
The Aegina Orphanage provided food to 2,000 refugees
land that had been collected on the island. Important step for recovery
of poor refugees and at the same time the decongestion of cities was
the effort to establish agricultural settlements. Intention of the Governor
was to restore the needy masses and at the same time to strengthen the para-
Gogi class of small farmers. This meant repairing the coast-
and therefore concerned the disputed issue of the use of "national"
of the real estate ”, of the only substantial capital that the government had and
which many were eyeing.
The first agricultural settlement was established on the outskirts of the city of Nav-
pli, who had gathered an overwhelming refugee population, and took
the name "Welfare", to indicate the Governor's policy of care. The
The plan, which was successfully implemented, also provided for a temporary concession
public land to refugees, for cultivation. According to the model of "Providence-
Let 's try to establish other agricultural settlements with the same motives
(Apathia Porou and Ano Examili Corinth), but without success.
The refugee rehabilitation policy was also linked to the goal
of Kapodistrias for dealing with anarchy and consolidating feeling
security in the country. Installation would discourage clutter
from the temptation of illegality, which was on the rise and would
Page 126
125
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
lassa. A typical example is refugees from the area
of Olympus, who eventually settled peacefully in Eleusis. Yet
and the organization of an army reflected to some extent this policy, since
enabled the Souliotes and Makedotes to join him.
refugee refugees and stop engaging in robbery.
The Fourth National Assembly, which met in Argos in 1829, decided
inventory of private and "national lands" (land registry) and
set the conditions for the distribution of 200,000 acres of national land with temporary ones
titles. The governor later set the conditions for establishing cities
or suburbs. The demand for the distribution of national land to landless people was a concern
to legislate the governments of the Revolution. But only with Kapo-
serious efforts were made to satisfy this demand
which concerned a large part of the population and which had been treated positively
from previous National Assemblies. The reactions, of course, were not lacking.
It is characteristic that in the draft law on the election of proxies
at the Assembly, which was submitted by the "Panhellenic" to the Governor,
the right to vote to the "heterogeneous" and the landlord was not recognized.
new. Kapodistrias rejected the relevant provision and recognized the right
vote in these categories.
The Fourth National Assembly gave the opportunity to the various refugees
groups to raise the issue of their restoration, especially to those who
Their particular homeland was not included in the borders of the Greek state.
The requests concerned the issue of permanent establishment and the new so-
heavy issue of war reparations. Others, still continuing to
see in their return, they demanded diplomatic action for the en-
accumulation of their territories in the new Greek state. For her part, the
The National Assembly suggested to the government the satisfaction of the various
requests expressed in refugee reports. But the last one
remained captive to the great needs and financial problems that
the country was facing.
For the Chian refugees, the issue of compensation came first, and together-
judgments of debt settlement left by failed campaign

strengthened the anti-pagan faction there. About ten years later, the
most Kydonian refugees had returned to Central Asia, taking
courage from the policy of amnesty and privileges announced by the Ottomans-
government.

they live again in their homelands. Others demanded their release and unification

refugee groups. But the main thing is that the government did not promote
the refugee requests made to the Fourth National Assembly, despite the
Commission Reports on Reports. Nor did the Governor hesitate to
come into conflict with groups of refugees. One such example was the opposite.
his request to the Souliotes for a refugee settlement, because it existed
the fear of unrest from the concentration of a large number of gunmen in one
part. Thus, in his attempt to secure resources for the state and to
to ensure his cohesion, he found no ally the refugees.
At the Fifth National Assembly of Nafplio, which met in 1832, after the assassination
Kapodistrias' assassination, various refugee groups rushed to put up
again their demands. In the general anarchy, for all now it preceded it
theme of the installation site. In particular, the Souliotes, the Psarians and the Thes-
lounges requested specific areas. Chios also asked for a place, as the ex-
their lusts had made them forget their old dilemmas. Souliotes, Cretans,
Macedonians continued to push and move menacingly. His murder
Kapodistrias had not solved any of their problems, but he had created them
much for the newly formed state.

It was planned to establish new refugee settlements
revealed the state's intentions to strengthen national cohesion.
The Ottoman state even looked to the refugee element, as the
educated refugees, mainly from Asia Minor and Istanbul,
better covered the needs of the state administration.

Macedonians and Cretan refugees for their rehabilitation.

living city of Piraeus, to build their houses there 4 .

the years of the Ottonian period provoked reactions. The presence
educated refugees in public places and their distinction in politics
life caused great discomfort to other Greeks. They blamed them
expatriate refugees in general because they found that while they were fighting
to liberate the country, they were now marginalized by the neo-mete-
mind. This attitude indicated the existence of a deeper competition, the
which was caused by the coexistence of the local Greek element (indigenous)

Ioannis Makrygiannis (Athens Attorney General, self-destructive)
supported the exclusion of non-aliens from public office: “From him
Pariosity, we ravaged our house . patriotism now reaches us.

the conditions for obtaining the status of Greek citizen. Reason
was a proposal submitted to the National Assembly and which requested it
removal from public office of all those who had settled in
Greece after the Revolution, limiting jobs for them
fighters and their families. In the discussion that followed, others
Powers demand a constitutional ban on the occupation of public places
of the heterosexuals (hence the dismissal of those who already held
positions), while others vehemently opposed any constitutional arrangement
which would establish distinctions between Greeks 6 . In the end, the problem was not solved
with a constitutional regulation, but it was decided to have a relevant one in the future
legislative act. The issue of staffing the public - the qualifications -
Ladi of the civil servant - was regulated by the Second Resolution, which stipulated that
Civil servants may be: a) natives of Greek territory
and those who fought in it until the end of 1827 or came and settled-
were taken during the same period, b) those who were proven to have taken part in hostilities
events of the Revolution until 1829.
In the third phase of the dispute between natives and non-natives, the interest
focused on the issue of the conditions for the election of deputies. The problem
it focused on whether their special representation should continue
expatriates settled in Greece as separate groups (their point of view
heterosexuals), or they should be integrated electorally in the provinces
living, ending a separation of the past that he did not have
meaning (view of the autochthonous). The prevailing regulation was co-
basic, allowing refugees / heterosexuals the right to privacy
Representation in Parliament, if in the meantime they had established a separate council-
adequate population.
During the discussions in the National Assembly, from both sides
There were strong popular reactions, some of which resulted in
distractions. Eventually, the expatriate heterogeneous as a whole, after the vote
of the measures that excluded them for a period from the public and border-
They were obliged to accept their separate representation
settings.
The issue of the rights of foreigners in the National Assembly showed
the deepest dimension that existed in the society of the time. The problem
He was highly regarded by the public and attracted his interest
foreign factor. In particular, the issue of separate parliamentary anti-
Protesting of the heterosexuals provoked the protests of the Ottomans
empire. What is certain is that with this controversy the pre-
coexistence missiles of the local Greek and the newcomer expatriate
element in the small newly formed state.

D. OFFERS AND ALYTROTIC MOVEMENTS
DURING THE 19th CENTURY
In e throughout the 19th century, liberation movements erupted
in Turkish-occupied mainland Greece and Crete, at the instigation
or tolerance of the Greek state. In the redemptive movements they gave the present
armed Macedonians, Epirotes and Cretan refugees who had settled
from the time of the Revolution in free Greece. These upheavals
caused new refugee flows, with the largest being the Cretan re-
of 1866-69. These have contributed to the steady increase
of the country's population (doubled from 1840 to 1880). In several
cases, however, of refugees from areas which
were at war, returning after a short time
in their particular homelands, when things were calm.
In 1854 the Crimean War gave birth to hopes for the Greeks that the
time of the liberation of Epirus, Thessaly and Macedonia.
Revolutionary corps from Greece infiltrated these provinces and called
like the inhabitants revolt. But the movements failed. The guerrillas
who returned to Greece were followed by civilians. When the cat-
The refugees returned to their homes.
However, the Crimean War also affected refugees in Athens. THE
cholera epidemic, brought by the French occupation troops, spread
quickly in the capital. The epidemic hit the southern part hard
city, where refugees from the Turkish settlements lived in miserable conditions-
Greek parts, which had arrived in Athens after their cessation
Greek-Turkish relations (March 1854). To restore all
refugees of 1854, a refugee settlement was established in the village of Anivitsa
of Fthiotida.
The Russo-Turkish War (1877-1878) revived the dream of recovery
of Epirus, Thessaly and Macedonia. Greece tried to
strengthen the defense of Greek rights with revolutionary care
movements in these provinces. In January 1878 it was founded in
Athens the Macedonian Committee, with the aim of organizing a revolution in Macedonia
jellyfish. Again the Macedonian refugees of Nea Pella, and others of Evia,
responded to the Commission's efforts to mobilize troops
1. Thessaly, Epirus, Macedonia
Page 136
135
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
power. The revolution broke out in Olympus, Pieria and Halkidiki
and ended with a truce between the Greek revolutionaries and the Turks. Pol-
All revolutionaries went to safety in free Greece. A bit later,
some of them returned to their areas.
The last stream of (internal) refugees was created by the Greek-Turkish
The war of 1897. The retreat of the Greek army, after the cat-
Larissa, followed by a general exit of the civilian population, which
he left in a panic. The Treaty of Constantinople provided
regulations on the Thessalian border line with minor improvements in their favor
Turks. There were no inhabited areas in these lands, except
a village, Koutsoufliani, which its inhabitants abandoned and settled.
settled further south on Greek soil.
A small number of Cretans had taken refuge in free Greece in 1841,
after the failure of a movement in Crete. The Cretan revolution, however
of 1866-1869 was the one that caused the largest refugee wave in
second half of the 19th century. The first Cretan families arrived in July
of 1866 in Piraeus and Syros via Kythira. At the same time it was established
in Athens the Central Committee in favor of the Cretans, which together with the corresponding
of Syros undertook to strengthen the Cretan struggle. For the same purpose, and
especially for the treatment of civilian refugees, were established abroad
various committees, such as that of London, which, in collaboration with the
"English-Greek Committee" in Athens, took care of 4,500 refugees
angle.
By mid-1867, a relatively small number of civilians had fled
from Crete, where living problems were high. Some foreign
ships carrying them then stopped transporting women for months-
girls, after protests by the Ottoman Empire. The big
refugee wave erupted the following year. In February 1868 they had
about 10,000 refugees arrive in Athens. Within the same time
They floated daily in large groups, mostly civilians, in
bad situation. The state, as it was found, was unable to support steadily
the Cretan revolution, so it failed to deal with the acute refugee
problem.
In the following decades the refugee movement was associated with crises
of the Cretan question was of a much smaller scale and had a temporary
2. Crete

character. In 1895 the Cretan was shaken again. But the facts of it
period (1895-1898), which were decisive for the fate of the island, no pre-
they called a wave of great flight.

INTRODUCTION
OFFERS IN GREECE
AGAINST THE 20TH CENTURY
The number of refugees, the
who fled to Greece
in the 19th century, it wasn't much
large. On the contrary, the first de-
waves of the 20th century the waves
of refugees arriving at
Greece was more frequent and multifaceted;
more numbers. The cause was the war
conflicts and hostility between
of the states of the Balkan Peninsula-
island, as a consequence of the general
competition in the area. Cut off
peak in all traffic
of sacrifices was his uprooting
Hellenism of Asia Minor and its
Eastern Thrace in 1922. The met-
large number of refugees and
the final character that the
expulsion from the ancestral homes
forced the Greek state to
take more systematic measures for
care and rehabilitation-
in their new homeland.
The first Greeks who passed
massively the borders in the 20th century were
residents of Eastern Romulia,
Bulgaria region marked
Greek population. The necessary
immigration to Greece
1906 was a consequence of violence
sons of the Bulgarians, because of him
Greece-Bulgaria competition
for predominance in the Ottoman
sovereignty Macedonia (Macedonian
Race). At the same time Greeks
Romanians evicted,
due to the escalation that knew her
at the same time the Koutsovlach issue
but, which affected the relations of El-
oil-Romania.
After the signing of the treaty
of Bucharest in August
of 1913, with which he finished
when the Balkan wars, Greeks
from Bulgaria, as well as from
Western Thrace and the part of the East
of Macedonia, who had
ratified in Bulgaria as well
from areas that had been granted
in Serbia, they arrived in Greece.
At that time, the first one arrived
immigration from Russia.
Greeks of the Caucasus region,
with the announcement of the attachment
of fertile Macedonia, began
to immigrate to Greece, with
the hope that I will give them-
like land. Some of them I succeed-
as if to settle in the Center-
Macedonia. Immigration
electricity was stopped by surgery
of the Greek government.

the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
A. OFFERS
DURING PERIOD 1914-1922
1. The persecution of 1914 (the first persecution)
The Greek presence in Asia Minor has been long. The dense against
antiquity and Byzantine times Greek populations thin-
It was felt after the 12th century, mainly due to the mass Islamizations.
However, during the 18th and 19th centuries they were again strengthened by migrations from
mainly Greek space. During this period, in addition to the increase in el-
Greek population, there was an economic rise of the Greeks, spiritual
flourishing and remarkable community and educational organization. In areas with
Greek population, communities, associations, schools and prosperity were established
institutions with high radiation.
The national awakening of the Turks, which had begun in the late 19th century
century, strengthened after the territorial collapse of the Ottoman Empire-
ρια. Turkish nationalism contributed to hostile treatment of minorities
who lived in the Ottoman Empire. They were targeted
mainly Greeks and Armenians, as they had gathered it in their hands
most of the country's trade and industry. The pending
also on the issue of the awarding of the islands of the eastern Aegean to
Greece has worsened Greek-Turkish relations.
In the first months of 1914, a large number of Muslims emigrated.
of Serbia, Bulgaria and Greece to Asia Minor, which
were generally instigated by the Turkish government. That gave it
pretext to the Turkish government, combined with the impending entry
of Turkey in the First World War, to expel the Greeks. First victim
but there were the Greeks of Eastern Thrace, who were expelled from
their hearths in early 1914. In May the persecution expanded to
West Asia Minor, under the pretext of evacuating the area opposite
the islands of the Eastern Aegean, for military reasons. The whole business
It was led by the Germans, allies of the Turks. The evacuation-
It was first methodized with an anti-Greek campaign of the Turkish type and
oppression of Greeks to be forced into "voluntary" immigration. In
many cases of looting and murder against El-
lions.
The Ecumenical Patriarchate declared the Orthodox Church persecuted and
suspended the operation of churches and schools. Greece reacted
and took diplomatic action to start negotiations-
Page 140
139
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
"We were trapped in wagons carrying horses. Only
once a day they would open for us to go for our physical needs. From
Of the 480 men on that mission, only 310 reached their destination
their. One hundred and seventy threw it on the street. The guard was alone
ten men - he rolled his eyes to take a bite and walk -
stick our bogs. For those fukarades, they were devils
unexpected treasure the rich bogs of one hundred and seventy Greeks,
where the motherly affection and the splendor * of despair had been stacked
the best houses had in clothes and food. How many of them?
if they broke it, they would be able to reach their homes alive! ... "
7
on the way to the labor battalions (careless drummer)
D. Sotiriou, Damned Soils, (18th edition), Athens 1982, pp. 102-103.
for the voluntary exchange of Greek Orthodox Turks in Turkey and Mosul-
mothers of Greece. A Joint Committee was set up in June to regulate them
on the exchange, but it did not work due to its entry
Turkey in World War I, in October 1914.
The oppression suffered by the Greeks took the following forms:
• Extraordinary charges and checks were imposed for his needs
war.
• Obstacles were placed in their commercial activities.
• Populations of villages or wider areas were displaced by them
coasts to the interior of Asia Minor.
• Men over the age of 45, who did not enlist in the army, manned the battalions
work *. Where many died of hardship, hunger and disease 7 . Those who are
At the age of 20-45, they were able to redeem their military
service. Those who did not pay were classified as greedy. After the abolition-
Thousands were killed and hundreds more injured in what became known as the Cold War
those arrested were executed.
The actions of the Turks caused a great wave of flight to Greece.
δα. In the houses abandoned by the Greeks, the Turkish authorities installed
Muslim immigrants from Serbia, Bulgaria, Albania and
Hellas. The persecution and deportations of the Greek element continued, with
but less intense, and in the following years, until the end of the war-
in 1918, and expanded to other areas (Marmaras, Pontus, etc.).
The number of refugees who arrived in Greece during this period amounted to many
thousands.
Page 141
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
140
2. Other refugee flows
P. arallila with the arrival of refugees from Turkey, refugees e-
in 1916 from Eastern Macedonia, which they had occupied
the Bulgarians as allies of the Germans. After the end of hostilities,
In 1918, they returned to their homes and the “Reconstruction Service
Macedonia ”for their reinstatement.
In November 1919, the Treaty of Neighborhood was signed, which provided for it
concession of Western Thrace from Bulgaria to Greece. In the treaty
Attached was the “Agreement on Migration between Greece
and Bulgaria. " Based on this, about 50,000 left Greece
Bulgarians and about 30,000 Greeks from Bulgaria (about 20,000 more
non-Greeks had emigrated before the treaty was signed).
The period 1919-1921, due to the Russian Revolution and the occupation
Russian provinces by the Turks, much of the Greeks of Russia
took refuge in the ports of the Black Sea and from there penetrated into
Hellas. The Greeks were followed by Armenians and Russians.
Greek refugees also came from northern Epirus during this period.
(mainly in 1914), Romania (in 1919 from areas that were pe-
the Italian-occupied Southwest Asia Minor)
(1919), Aydin and the interior of Asia Minor (1919), as well as from
Italian-occupied Dodecanese (occasionally from 1912 onwards).
In total, by 1920, about 800,000 had taken refuge in Greece
refugees. They either arrived alone or were taken care of
means allocated for this purpose by the state (animals, vehicles, carriage-
data, ships). A large number of refugees gathered in Athens and
Piraeus, Thessaloniki and Macedonia in general, and its islands
Eastern Aegean (Lesvos, Chios, Samos). A smaller number was directed
in Crete (Heraklion, Chania), Volos, Patras, Kalamata and the islands
of the Saronic Gulf.
In the beginning, the treatment of refugees was mostly a voluntary task.
λοντων. Committees were set up by the Ministry of the Interior with a project
the distribution of food, clothing and the provision of basic financial assistance
morality. Proceeds came from fundraisers, donations and a small government grant.
administration. In July 1914, an organization was founded in Thessaloniki, with the aim
3. The care (1914-1921)
Page 142
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
141
immediate care and then the settlement of refugees in
abandoned Turkish and Bulgarian villages of Central and East-
of Macedonia. Food, temporary shelter and medical care were provided.
until the refugees find work or get an agricultural lot.
During the period of National Divide (1916-1917) the Venizelos government
founded the "Highest Care Directorate" in Thessaloniki. On July
of 1917 (Venizelos had prevailed and King Constantine had
abolished Greece) the Ministry of Health was established. For the first time the-
care was also taken for the families of the reservists who were there
on the front and for the families of the war victims.
Although Greece was in a war (World War I)
mo) and the economic conditions were adverse, the care for the refugees
was more organized from 1917 to 1921. According to data
of the services of the Ministry of Health, received inter-
about 450,000 refugees.
Refugee care included:
• Distribution of financial aid. Private allowance was given to priests, teachers
as well as diligent students.
Refugee students of the 1st Primary School for Girls of Lavrio
with their teachers (first persecution)
Page 143
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
142
• Food distribution. Meals were organized daily by the state or
Patriotic Foundation in neighborhoods of cities where many were gathered
other refugees.
• Provision of medical care. Doctors, pharmacists and midwives were appointed,
exclusively for refugees.
• Administration of drugs and hospitalization, public or special education
illuminated for the care of refugees.
• Housing in temporary accommodation (tents or stables), in public and
in commissioned or leased private buildings.
• Provision of clothing and bedding.
• Help to find a job.
• Free movement, group or individual, to find housing and work or for
return to the areas of the previous installation.
The return of refugees to Asia Minor has begun
months of 1918 after the end of the war for Turkey. Him

143
In October 1918, a Patriarchal Commission was set up in Istanbul.
in order to organize the repatriation of the displaced, with the help-
of the Patriarchate and the Greek government. The return was made
in part, with the care of the Ministry of Health, and was initially allowed
to return the most affluent and refugees coming from certain-
only areas of West Asia Minor. Most returned to
their hearths after the landing of the Greek army in Smyrna, in May
1919. By the end of 1920 the majority of refugees had returned
in Asia Minor and Eastern Thrace.
The conditions they found in their homeland were bad, as were many
houses, churches and schools were partially or completely destroyed. Also in
in some areas, houses of Greeks had been settled by Muslims before
pulses from the Balkan countries. In the context of the High Commission of Smyrna
The "Return and Care Service" was established, which helped
those returning to their homes and occupations.
But the peaceful days did not last long. A few months later, Av-
In 1922, they would take refuge again.

B. THE SMALL CONSTRUCTION
1. The output
The national aspirations of the Greeks of Asia Minor seemed to be happening
reality. Greek army landed in Izmir on the 15th
May 1919. The Greek presence soon spread to other areas,
around the occupied zone. The Treaty was signed in July 1920
of Sevres, which, among other things, stipulated that the area of ​​Smyrna would be located
under Greek administration and occupation for five years. After the period
This could be decided by the residents in a referendum.
the region in Greece. In November of the same year their party
Liberals lost the election and King Constantine returned
in GREECE. This gave the Allies an opportunity to express themselves clearly.
rather their change of attitude towards Greece. At the same time the national
The Turkish movement led by Mustafa Kemal was constantly taking place
stronger both abroad and inside Turkey. The little one
Siat war ended in August 1922 with his defeat and retreat
Greek army. Thousands of refugees, following the army, began to flee
arrive in Greece 8 .
Already, before August 1922, Greek populations of Asia Minor-
As (Pontus, Cilicia, Cappadocia) they had left their homes and had
resort to Smyrna or Greece. After the destruction of Smyrna series
they had Vourla, Ayvalik and Moschonissia. Persecutions also took place in
northwest Asia Minor (Propontis and elsewhere). Captive soldiers and
local men aged 18-45 gathered in camps and formed
captives and hostages marching inland Asia Minor. Many
The rest of us waited for three days, until we got into boats and bars.
we made for Mytilene. Until the Turkish army steps on its feet
in the village, they would take boats and take us. Back and forth in Mytilene no
they accepted us. It is not a rich place . from a ax [= harvest] pe-
remains. We were tortured, we slept badly, we ate badly, a great misfortune
we suffered. And who did not weep for the dead? And who did not suffer and who

In the beginning, the state dealt with the means at its disposal -
Refugee needs and pressures: nutrition, temporary housing,
medical care. Individuals, individual or organized, were also mobilized.
Decisive, especially for medical care and the provision of medicines,
There has been activity in Greece of foreign charities.
Fundraisers were held, snacks were arranged and an effort was made
for daily distribution of bread, clothing and other items first
of necessity.
With the arrival of the refugees, the temporary housing project took over
Ministry of Health, reinforced by emergency personnel. Subsequently
the Refugee Care Fund (founded in November 1922) erected
wooden stumps for housing refugees. Many emerged
improvised constructions that served as temporary accommodation (huts,
shacks, tents) around the cities, in squares or in their empty plots
cities. There was no space left unused: schools,
We stayed in the steamers for fifteen days. Then we arrived in Piraeus. From
in Piraeus I only know the wires. I kept the wires for twenty days.
νε. Aman, they resented us a lot, they tortured us a lot. They put us in order.
The little ones and the old women were cutting our roots. I cried, I shouted: - Look for me,
look at me, I don't have lice! They forced me to cut my hair. They made me like a zucchini.
A long time later, I was ashamed to go shopping.
They stripped us. Whatever we wore in the oven, they put it on. Shoes
we didn't have to wear it then. They gave us food to eat. We had it with us.
But in quarantine it was a big resilience, a big sefiliki [= malice].
It lasted twenty days.
From Ai-Giorgis, from Piraeus, they put us in the steamer, in Thessaly-
London brought us. They took us out and left us. In the alleys of Thes-
they left us in the living room. We were thrown in the alleys of Thessaloniki.
So lying down, in the alleys. People would pass by and see us. Aman,
resilience!
A man, a great man, passed by. He threw us a five. I caught her
five, I shouted, I cried: - We have money! We have something to eat! I left-
with our houses, we left so many vineyards! We are not beggars!

A tangle was sitting.
People were passing by. They saw us from afar. They did not come to us:

We stayed in Mersina for a week on the wires ... then came the steamer
and he took us. During the trip, there was a storm and the women were fainting
their fear. You heard voices, cries. I had my husband with me, her
my mother and my three children, Charalambos, Dimitris and Marika,
from one to six years old. Fortunately, I did not suffer anything . I left the kids in a go-
of the steamer near my mother and I was carrying water to the unconscious
women. Some people did not suffer from the suffering they suffered and
they died in the steamer . they tied them with irons and threw them into the sea.
We finally arrived in Piraeus. Others went down there . we continued it
trip to Kavala. They took us to Chinar Dere, near today
Nea Karvali. We stayed there for two years under the bags. The world no-
he was dying and dying every day. My husband died, so did the child
Charalambos. At night the jackals would come and dig the graves
and they ate the dead. We did not know such savages in our village . εί-
ha, yes, something like that big teeth ...
Ah! It would be better if there was no exchange, if we lived in Kenatala. Six there
We worked for months, sat for six months and ate. But again he could
to do that, not to leave? What would we do among the Turks? Here
at least, we are in a Christian nation.
