For the first time, most refugees tolerated adverse conditions.
living cases, considering their stay in Greece temporary. Pi-
they believed that the day of return would not be long in coming. The sense of this person-
The delay delayed, in combination with other factors, the social
and their economic integration and identification with the indigenous population. After
The signing of the Lausanne Convention, refugees began to realize-
who realized that the dream of return was not going to come true. In the-
They have now improved their living conditions and integration
in the new homeland 11 .
On July 24, 1923, the Treaty of Lausanne was signed. Six
months ago, on January 30, 1923, Greek-Turkish was signed
3. The Lausanne Convention and the Exchange of Populations
Page 151
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
150
Convention, which regulated the exchange of populations between Greece and
Of Turkey. The obligatory exchange between the Greeks was foreseen.
glorious inhabitants of Turkey and the Muslim inhabitants of Greece.
This would apply both to those who remained in their homes and to them.
minds who had already taken refuge in the co-religious country. In fact, the exchange
applied retroactively for all movements made from the day it was advertised
World War I broke out (October 18, 1912). From this exchange
the Greek Orthodox of Constantinople, Imbros and
Tenedos and the Muslims of Western Thrace.
Exchangeable, according to the exchange contract:
• they would renounce the old citizenship and acquire the citizenship of the land-
in which they would settle,
• had the right to transfer their movable property,
• had the right to receive from the state in which they immigrated as a de-
property damage of equal value with the immovable property they left
becoming
• would be facilitated in their movement by the Joint Exchange Committee-
land 12 .
This population exchange agreement differed from the previous ones.
It was establishing for the first time the mass movement of populations and had
CONTRACT
I concerned the exchange of Greek-Turkish populations and Proto-
Kolon, signed on January 30, 1923. The Government of the Great
The Turkish National Assembly and the Greek Government agreed
on the following terms.
Article 1.
From May 1, 1923, the obligatory exchange of their will takes place
Turkish nationals of the Greek Orthodox religion, settled
on Turkish territory, and Greek Muslim nationals
religion, settled on Greek soil.
These persons will not be able to come and settle
new in Turkey or respectively in Greece, without the permission of the Turkish Ky-
government or the Greek Government.
Article 2
We will not be included in the exchange provided in the first article.
take: a) the Greek inhabitants of Constantinople, b) the Muslim inhabitants
of Western Thrace
The Greeks are all considered to be Greek residents of Constantinople
already established before October 30, 1918, in its periphery
12 the first articles of the LGBT co-operation
Page 152
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
151
Prefecture of Constantinople, as it is determined by its Law
1912.
It is considered that Muslims are all residents of Western Thrace
the Muslims settled in the area east of the border
line set out in 1913 by the Treaty of Bucharest.
Article 3
Greeks and Muslims, those who have already left since 18
October 1912 the lands, which the Greek and Turkish inhabitants wanted
mutual exchange, I will be considered included in the exchange
provided for in Article 1.
The term "immigrant" in this agreement always includes
natural and legal persons future to immigrate or have
emigrated on October 18, 1912.
Article 4
All capable males, belonging to the Greek population, of the c
Families have already left Turkish territory, prisoners are now in
Turkey, I will be the first part of the Greeks, who will be sent
in Greece in accordance with this agreement.
Article 5
Without prejudice to the provisions of Articles 9 and 10 hereof
contract, property rights and claims of Turkish El-
or Muslims in Greece, do not want any consequence of it
arising under this Exchange Agreement.
"Refugees from Asia Minor, Eastern Thrace and the Black Sea
Pontus ... consider that the Exchange of the Greek populations of Turkey
amounting to one million two hundred thousand versus three-
Thousands of Muslims in Greece ... hit the world hard
consciousness and global ethics ... that it is contrary to the most sacred
human rights, freedoms and property . that the system
of Exchange is a new and covered form of compulsory ex-
patriotism and forced expropriation that no state has

unanimity, in the pandemonium of the gathering on 21-1-1923 organized
In order to express their opposition to the mandatory exchange
13
debt, while the agreements so far provided for voluntary
migration of residents of some disputed areas.
When the signing of the Convention and its terms became known, the refugees
who were in Greece reacted strongly. In all cities of Greece-
rallies rallied, reversing their decision to trade
see its implementation 13 . But the reality, as it was
after the departure of thousands of Greeks from their ancestral homes and the art-
Turkey to accept their return, forced the Greek anti-
Page 153
152
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
the right to enforce against the will of the population. That the
Greek populations of Asia Minor, indigenous to ancient times
on the land in which they lived and on which their rights are re-
patriotic and indescribable, they did not emigrate voluntarily but
were expelled from their homes facing the scope of the massacre.
... The unredeemed Greeks gathered here and in other cities and islands
Greece decide and vote unanimously to claim the opportunity
to return to their homelands under substantial conditions
that will make this return possible
... Otherwise they denounce the injustice done to them, as one
an unprecedented insult to humanity and culture. "
person to agree. Moreover, the signing of the Convention helped
the aspirations of the leaders of the two countries (Venizelou and Kemal) to ensure
and recognizing their borders, achieving homogeneity and the unexpected;
purposeful engagement with internal reform and development. Agree
it was also the League of Nations. The refugees were left with the bitterness that the di-
and their interests were sacrificed on the altar of his interests
Greek state.
Pursuant to Article 11 of the Treaty of Lausanne, the Joint Committee was established.
Exchange headquarters based in Istanbul. It consisted of eleven members
(four Greeks, four Turks and three members-citizens neutral according to him
World War I) with the responsibility to determine how
population revaluation and real estate appraisal
exchangeable.

C. THE RESTORATION OF THE OFFERS
1. The Commission
Refugee Rehabilitation
The Greek government,
in front of the huge
the work of care
and their restoration
refugees who had to
to take over, he asked
assistance of their Society
Nations (KTE). On initiative-
of the KTE, in September
of 1923 one was founded
autonomous organism with
full legal status, h
Rehabilitation Committee
Refugees (EAP), with headquarters
Athens. Basic shipping-
Its purpose was to provide refugees with productive employment and a limit.
housing.
The Greek government provided the following to the EAP:
• the properties of the Turkish exchangers and the Bulgarians who settled-
Greece was missing, public lands, estates that were expropriated
with rural reform and monastic land (total above
8,000,000 acres).
• the amount of two loans (1924, 1928) that the Greek government had concluded
abroad,
• plots in or around cities for the construction of urban settlements,
• the technical and administrative staff of the Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Agriculture
Land of Welfare and Perception.
In order to rehabilitate the refugees, the EAP took into account the following parameters:
food:
The distinction between "bourgeois" and "farmers" . There was a concern that the
refugee employment the same or related to the one they had in their home country.
Thus, an effort was made by the EAP to install refugee farmers in
places where they could continue the crops they already knew.
Cereal growers have settled in lowland parts of Macedonia
First refugee settlement
in Lefki, Kavala
Page 155
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
154
and Western Thrace, tobacco growers in suitable lands in the East
Macedonia and Western Thrace, viticulturists in Crete and serologists in
Soufli, Edessa and elsewhere.
The place of origin . The EAP sought to bring in refugees
from the same settlement or even the wider area to settle together
on Greek soil. This is partly due to the toponyms Nea Smyrni,
New Philadelphia, New Moudania, New Alikarnassos etc. But to a few audiences
This was made possible. Most facilities included pre-
hammers of different origins.
The objective conditions . EAP distinguished the restoration of pre-
refugees in rural (providing housing and clergy in the countryside) and urban (pa-
roof flow in cities). Although most refugees practiced
Homeland "urban" professions (trade, crafts-bio-
machinery, etc.), emphasis was placed on agriculture, because:
• There were Muslim estates (mainly in Macedonia, but also in
Crete, Lesvos, Lemnos and elsewhere),
• Rural rehabilitation was faster and required lower costs,
• The Greek economy has always relied on agricultural production,
• there was the political expediency of avoiding social unrest with
creation of smallholder farmers instead of a working proletariat.
In addition, priority was given to the settlement of refugees in Ma-
Kedonia and Western Thrace as well:
◊ It was possible to use Muslim estates and estates-
the Bulgarian immigrants (according to the Neighbor Treaty). This will
made refugees self-sufficient in a short time and will
contributed to the increase in agricultural production,
◊ the demographic gap created by the departure would be filled-
Muslims and Bulgarians and the losses they caused
the ongoing wars (1912-1922). In addition, this was how border settlements were settled.
streams.
When we came to Chios we were more than the locals. I suffered-
with us, but Chios also suffered a lot. No thorns were left. Other
go for wood, another for pine cones ... The farmers were chasing us a lot-
guards and the whole world. Another begged, another went to the orchards.
Whatever everyone found, he took to live.
I stayed in Chios for a year. Then I went to Patras, Corinth and finally to Velos.

Of course, the installation of refugees was not always done according to it
above logic, nor did it follow in all cases the state counter-
receipt and check. The mobility of refugees has been great, in particular
during the first years 14 . The refugees were returning from area to area.
to find the place with the best conditions for installation. Many
refugees, although not farmers, had accepted or asked to be rehabilitated
as farmers to take advantage of EAP loans and benefits. Al-
they all again moved to the urban centers in order to present themselves as
"Bourgeois" and thus receive the compensation given to them
bourgeois exchangeable.
In addition to the EAP, refugees were involved in the rehabilitation of refugees
Refugee Care Fund (1922-1925), the Ministry of Welfare and Anti-

then I went to Alexandroupolis, to my sister, and opened a restaurant.
Soon my shop burned down and I opened another cottage. In the meantime I got sick
and I returned to Velos. I grew orchards there. But I left again
I came to Athens for better.

encountered more obstacles than rural. The number of refugees

anomalies and the poor economic situation during the 1920s
and 1930. Another problem was the wandering of the bourgeois pre-
refugees from city to city for a long time. Most
refugees in the cities in the early years worked occasionally, or do-
by "day laborers" in construction, in factories and handicrafts, or as pla-
legal retailers and retailers. Others worked as sailors.
cats and workers in public works in cities or in the countryside (irrigation and
drainage works, road construction, construction or expansion of ports, etc.).

now we entered the house, we were very happy.

we are; we were saying.

Of course, there were also wealthy refugees who could afford it.
to take care of their own housing. They were in the beginning
place to rent or buy homes in the cities and thus re-
mix with the natives. Later, they took the initiative themselves
establishment of settlements. The process was as follows: they set up a building system
cooperative, they bought an area in a privileged area and built
urban homes of good quality. Such settlements were Nea Smyrni in
Athens and Gallipoli in Piraeus. At the opposite end were the poor
refugees who had not yet been rehabilitated. Installed-
were built in huts, huts and other makeshift structures on the outskirts
old settlements, or created slums around them.
settlements. So, in miserable conditions, they were going to live for a long time
years.
The next day of Light, January 1923, we first came to Greece.
δα. As soon as we left, they waited for us ladies and gave us bread and cheese.
On the same day, they put us on the train and took us to Tripoli. Both
We stayed in Tripoli for the first few nights. ...
I was also deserted and had three children with me. ...
My son came to Tripoli to take us all to stay in Athens-
to. ... When we went out to Piraeus, we had nowhere to stay. Two nights
we slept at the station, in the countryside. We ran, we went to the Ministries and
then they took us and put us in the Strigos factory, in something ap-
cases inside, in Piraeus. There were other refugees from Smyrna
the places all.
We stayed in there for six months. Too bad, don't ask them how we lived.
The second year of exile has arrived. We were in 1924 and we listened
how settlements are made, so that we refugees can sit in Podoni-
φτη [= Ν. Ionia], in Podarades [= Perissos], in Kokkinia.
Then do you know how the houses were captured in the settlements? You went there, cre-

you. It was still endless . they didn't have tiles, they didn't have doors, pa-

found in Kokkinia and my husband. He came from the last
prisoners, because, because he was a craftsman, they kept him and worked for them.
We worked, we got tired and we made a house and raised the children
and they worked too . and here we will end our lives. The sufferings
they will never leave us.

D. THE DISMISSAL OF ANTALLAXIMS
AND THE GREEK-TURKISH APPROACH
1. The compensation of the exchangeable
As we have seen, the Convention on the Exchange of Populations between Greece and
Turkey provided for the compensation of exchangeable refugees
for the estates they left in their homelands, from the state sub-
chis 18 . The task of assessing the value of the property on both sides
The Joint Committee took over. To help the work of Greek
The General Directorate was established in 1924
Population Exchange under the Ministry of Agriculture. For the result
Its most extensive operation, Local Exchange Offices were established in some places.
sacrifices.
The work of valuing the property was progressing slowly and his discomfort
refugee world, which was in despair, was growing. Thus, adoptive-
the solution was given to give a down payment until the final repayment of the claim-
let the property abandoned in Turkey, after first the Greek
The public valued it temporarily. The National Bank undertook to
pay this advance to the exchangeable.
The temporary assessment of the assets was made on the basis of the statements submitted by
were shot at the Local Exchange Offices. Beneficiaries' applications will
were examined by special committees of refugees, compatriots of interest-
menus. If they were considered inaccurate, they were revised by one
Supreme Council. The assets for which they were also determined were also determined
compensation was paid. The advance payment would be given to those who are not
until then it has been restored.
For the final assessment of the properties abandoned in Tour-
Article 9
Real estate, agricultural or urban property, belonging to immigrants
to the communities referred to in Article 9, as well as to any of them
immigrants or communities abandoned movable property
cleared in accordance with the following provisions under mixed
modes provided for in Article 11.
The properties and the text in the lands subject to the obligation
exchange, and belong to ecclesiastical or auspicious establishments,
communities settled on the ground not subject to exchange
they also want to be cleared under these conditions.
18 This year, the Articles of Association.
Page 162
161
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
Primary Evaluation Committees and Secondary Committees have been set up.
say, for problems that might arise. Over time-
The completion of the property appraisal project seemed to be on the rise
more distant. The work was huge and in addition the whole process was subversive;
from the Turkish side.
M after the signing of the Convention population exchange and the Treaty
Lausanne's peace, Greece's relations with Turkey were tested against
intervals of tensions. After negotiations, in June 1925
the Treaty of Ankara was signed and in December 1926 their Agreement
Athens. These regulated the issues in question, but were never implemented. Him
In August 1928 the Liberal Party won the election and
The new government immediately began negotiations that lasted two
years. El. Venizelos wanted the financial disputes settled
and the recognition of territorial integrity between the two countries. Nevertheless,
In every attempt to reach out to Turkey, the obstacle stood firm
negative attitude of refugees.
On June 10, 1930, the Ankara Agreement was signed
the economic pact between the two countries. Its main points were:
• Settle the issue of the Greek Orthodox of Constantinople and their
Muslims of Thrace, as well as the "fugitives".
• He stipulated that the exchangeable Muslim properties in Greece and the el-
Greeks in Turkey came under the ownership of Elliniko and Turki-
State, respectively.
• It provided for the mutual amortization of financial obligations between them
two countries.
The agreement was completed on October 30 of the same year with the Sym-.
voice of friendship, neutrality and arbitration, the Protocol on Restriction
of maritime equipment and the Convention on Trade, Installation and Navigation
λίας. With this last contract, the citizens were given the opportunity
of each of the two states to travel or settle (with some
restrictions) on the territory of the other state.
Subsequent developments have shown that expectations from the solution given
addressed some issues with the Greek-Turkish agreements of 1930 inter-
2. The Greek-Turkish approach
Page 163
162
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
were lied to. Of course, for a long time there was no friction between them
of the two states and the borders between them were not disputed. That's it
and the main goal of the Greek Prime Minister. But the offsetting of
exchangeable, Greek and Muslim estates, caused a storm
reactions among refugees. With this agreement the much
greater wealth of the exchangeable Greek Orthodox of Turkey
equated to the corresponding property of the Muslims of Greece. The
This, combined with the withholding of 25% of the deposit
the compensation from the National Bank and the refusal to settle them
refugee debts, removed part of the refugee world from
electoral base of the Liberal Party and contributed to its defeat
in the 1932 and 1933 elections.
Pericles Lytras: The return
Page 164
163
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
E. THE INTRODUCTION OF OFFERS
IN GREECE
1. The integration of refugees
The rehabilitation and assimilation of refugees in Greece was,
by and large, the most important achievement of modern Greek
state. If one takes into account the objective difficulties, such as suffering
the country's economic situation, political circumstances over the decades
of 1920 and 1930, the incomplete state organization and, above all, the huge one
number of refugees who arrived in Greece, understands why
Refugee rehabilitation work has been described as "titanium". Great-
The whole part of this work was done from 1924 to 1928 and in that it was determined.
The operation of the EAP played a key role. The fact that it was an organization
under international control he helped her stay away from the troubled
Greek political life and therefore more effective. Of course, for her
implementation of its programs the Greek state granted it the materials-
and human resources. And if in some cases their work
in places of EAP or state committees it was done hastily, empirically and
rough or merely served immediate needs and political expediencies,
this does not diminish the importance of the overall project achieved.
Refugees were not a single entity. Among them were
differences of social origin, cultural tradition, dialect, even
and language (about 100,000 refugees were Turkish-speaking). Those who are wealthy
residents of Asia Minor or Eastern Thrace managed to bring
in Greece a large part of their property, almost immediately incorporated-
they settled in their new place of settlement and mingled with the natives. For
but the large mass of refugees, despite their rapid recovery, the
assimilation was a much slower process. The
more refugees, mentally injured and anxious at first
survival and later improvement of their lives, they often expressed para-
pains to deal with the state, but also its native inhabitants.
They accused the Greek state that with the signing of the Convention
of Lausanne and the Greek-Turkish Agreement of 1930 violated
their basic rights . that they were compensated only in part for
property they left in their homelands . that, finally, the exchangeable pe-
not always in them. Indeed, despite the existence of laws
(already before 1922) which prohibited the transfer of the Muslim
real estate, lack of land registry, non-existence, in many cases
Page 165
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
164
Map with the agricultural lands distributed to refugees and natives
during the 1920s and 1930s (Ministry of Agriculture 1938)
Page 166
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
165
falls, title deeds and difficulty in demarcation or fencing
contributed to the spread of such lands to locals. But also the
the state itself sometimes granted exchangeable property to natives
landless or in affluent institutions.
In general, there was a difference in mentality and temperament between
refugees and natives. The natives often referred to the ethos of pro-
refugees (mostly bourgeois), in their drive for fun and the cosmopolitan-
political behavior of these and their wives. Refugees on the side
they talked to them about the low educational and cultural level of the locals
and projected their Greekness, which the locals often questioned-
like.
The dimension of refugees and natives was mainly expressed:
• In economic life. There was competition in the labor market, in
land ownership and other business activities.
• In political life. Even before the provision of housing and labor, the
refugees acquired Greek citizenship and political rights. Inte-
were included in Venizelos' party both as voters and as statesmen.
MPs and ministers. The anti-Venezuelan and anti-Venezuelan culture
they hated them.
• In social life. The refugees who lived in the settlements
they were isolated, did not have frequent contact with locals and preferred to
they marry each other. The same did not happen with the refugees
settled in towns or villages. The workplace, the school, the
church and especially the neighborhood provided opportunities for communication with the locals.
Gradually, mixed marriages began to take place, which over time
there were more and more 19 .
The opposition between refugees and natives, in a few cases, took over
in the form of open conflict. The term "refugee", however, had in common
The trip lasted sixteen days. After Rhodes we caught Piraeus, then arrived
We are in Corfu. It was the eve of St. Spyridon, December 11-
1922. It was raining. We went to the beach with boats. They say: "We will take you with me
Arabs in a village ". They took us to the village of Stavros . we did four
hours until we get there. We went on foot, things just to you
mares. And to be wet all this time. ...
Others were put in the village church, others at school, others in
houses. No one asks, "Who are you, what do you want?" An indifference. Not us
they gave us nothing to eat. They didn't have anything to give us either. A "good-

for their arrival in Greece

166
they were just telling us. She was good too. Fortunately, we had bread with us. ...
They brought us to Corfu, put us in the fortress, in the shacks there.
It was Holy Saturday. An air comes and takes the shacks. What
to do; We went to the church of St. George, nearby. ...
At first we did not match the Corfiots. These other habits, al-
you say habits we. We didn't know the language, we couldn't get along-
with them. But then we made it. Many neighborhoods were built . Corfiots
took refugee girls.
(Testimony of Eleni Manailoglou from Konya).
The Exodus (published by the Center for Asia Minor Studies), vol. BD, pp. 348-349.
consciousness derogatory, for many years. The dividing line
between refugees and natives ceased to exist after the 1940s.
But also from before the first generation refugees and later the children and
their grandchildren took part in all the activities in their new homeland.
The Asia Minor catastrophe significantly affected the course of the Greek
nation in modern times. Some paralleled it with
fall of Constantinople in 1453, while others considered 1922 as af-
observance of modern Greece. The refugee issue, as a consequence of Asia Minor
disaster, was for Greece an economic, social, political
and a cultural issue of great importance, affecting all of them
areas of life of the modern Greek nation.
a. Foreign Policy
With the exchange of populations, the main source of friction with
between Greece and Turkey. Good relations between the two countries have been maintained.
at least three decades.
b. Population / ethnological composition
The population of Greece increased from about 1920 to 1928 against
20%. The degree of urbanization of the state has also greatly increased. Against
at the same time, the population of the wider area of ​​the capital di-
was forged. In fact, the creation of refugee settlements around it
Athens and Piraeus played a decisive role in shaping the unified
urban complex, as we know it today. Apart from Athens,
2. The effects of the arrival of refugees
Page 168
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
167
Piraeus and Thessaloniki, there were other urban centers that swell-
were due to the settlement of refugees in them.
The most significant were the effects of the arrival of refugees in the nation.
reasonable composition of the population of Greece. In 1920 Greece had 20% non-El-
Orthodox, while in 1928 only 6%. The Greek population of the West
Thrace and Epirus increased, while Crete, Lesvos and Lemnos evolved
were completely looted. But the main change in the ethnological composition
due to the settlement of refugees happened in macedonia. The percentage
of non-Greek Orthodox, which was 48% in 1920, fell to 12% in 1928. H.
strengthening the Greek character of Macedonia was of great importance for
maintaining the territorial integrity of Greece. Besides, sparsely populated
new areas of Northern Greece, some of them border, settlement-
even by refugees. In this way the new areas that
they united with Greece after the Balkan wars and were integrated
in the national body.
c. Economy
For a time the arrival of refugees seemed an unbearable burden for
the Greek economy. In the medium term, however, it benefited from the facility.
refugee situation.

I rode

serres

the two divisions of the countries with the largest proportions of refugees

the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
168
First of all, crops and agricultural production were restructured.
he snorted. In a decade (1922-1931) the cultivated areas of this-
increased by about 50%, agricultural production doubled and secured
cereals were sufficient. The refugees implemented the remuneration * and
multiculturalism and supported the institution of small agricultural property.
The lack of agricultural land for distribution to refugees forced it
state to undertake the construction of major land improvement projects, mainly
in Macedonia, and thus increased arable land. They were introduced
new crops or expanded the old ones (tobacco, cotton, raisins). The animal-
food and poultry farming have improved quantitatively and qualitatively. Arboriculture,
sericulture and fishing were developed by specialized refugees
in these occupations in their homeland.
The arrival of refugees has also revitalized the industry with a new, specialized
cheap and cheap labor, with the expansion of the consumer market-
and with the action of people with business skills. In the decade
1922-1932, the number of industrial units doubled. The progress
but it was not important, mainly because of the preservation of the traditional ones
their operating structures. The participation of refugees (as capitalists and
as workers) was greater in textile, carpet weaving, the
silk production, the flour industry and the production of building materials.
Refugees working in the carpet industry, on the outskirts of Athens
Page 170
the pre-election issue in GREECE (1821-1930)
169
There were many refugees who emerged as entrepreneurs, industrialists or
wholesalers. The Greeks who came from the urban centers of Mikra
Asia and Istanbul excelled compared to the natives in
entrepreneurial spirit, education, training and progressive perceptions. THE
cosmopolitan character of their lives, knowledge of foreign languages, contacts
that they had developed with Europe and the experience they had helped them,
when they settled in Greece, to organize their own businesses or
to staff businesses of others, refugees or natives.
The arrival of refugees also affected the integration of women into the energy sector.
for the population. In 1930, women made up the majority of workers
in the textile industry, the tobacco industry and the ready-made industry in-
mounds.
d. Culture
The refugees had lived in places with a cultural tradition of many centuries.
which they transferred to their new homeland. The music they brought together
influenced the way the popular strata expressed themselves and emerged
in folk music of the city (rebetika). Refugee organ players and tra-
Buddhists dominated the popular music scene until 1940. The refugees
they made their presence felt in the spiritual space as well. The writers
G. Seferis, I. Venezis, K. Politis, G. Theotokas, S. Doukas, the painter and co-
writer F. Kontoglou and musician M. Kalomiris are some of them
many Asia Minors who excelled in letters and the arts became rich
the modern Greek language and contributed to its development. In general, important
there was the offer of the refugees in the formation of today's Greek-
identity.

Page 172
171

the Cretan question
INTRODUCTION
"The phenomenon of revolution
of Crete is unique in all
history of the Greek struggle. It was one
insurgent and chain link uprising
titan, with only Greek power
of consciousness, vitality, philo-
his honesty and his rage. And this one
forces were enough not only to
The revolution itself, but also
to continue unchanged, lamp-
as in the whole Greek epic with
light of her spontaneity, almost wild
from unexplained testimonies
of which it was raised, submerged
and constantly emerging within waves
blood, I was drawing strength from
her toughest fight ... "
(Dion. Kokkinos, The Greek Revolution, vol. A, p. 611)

175
the Cretan question
A. THE STRUGGLE OF NATIONALISM
IN CRETE (1821-1830)
1. The first period (1821-1824)
a. The situation in Crete during the pre-revolutionary period
The great National Revolution of 1821 quickly spread to Crete.
despite the fact that the local conditions were extremely unfavorable for her
organization of a revolutionary movement. The long distance from the geographical
trunk of Greece and the intervening sea made it difficult
communication with the other Greek centers, the sending of supplies and weapons and
coordination of hostilities. But also in the island the conditions
of life presented peculiarities, which did not exist in the other Greece. The sign-
The biggest divisive problem was the large proportion of Muslims.
which remained stable at 30% of the total. This Muslim
The population was Turkish and Turkish-Cretan, ie Cretans
embrace Islam from the first years of its Turkish conquest
of the island. They were more fanatical than the Turks themselves
and unscrupulous persecutors and oppressors of Christians. Two powerful janissaries
battalions, of the imperial janissaries and the local janissaries they had
organized in Crete from the first years of the Turkish occupation,
they had imposed a regime of suffocating oppression on the island. They did not obey
nor in the sultan's orders. It is known that from all Greek regions-
However, only Macedonia experienced similar savagery.
Education, through which the co-education was mainly ideologically prepared
in other Greece, it was almost non-existent in Crete. The island, where
once at the forefront of the nation's spiritual rebirth,
he lived for almost two centuries in isolation and deep spiritual darkness.
Few Cretans had been initiated into the Friendly Society and were prepared
for the imminent struggle for freedom. Almost the entire Cretan population
sacrifice was completely unprepared psychologically for large-scale ap-
liberation revolution.
b. The outbreak of the revolution in Crete. The Turkish reaction
Crete's participation in the nationwide uprising was decided on the web
monastery of Panagia Thymiani in Sfakia, on April 15, 1821,
but the official start date of the Cretan race is June 14
Page 177
the Cretan question
176
1821. The same day it occurred
and the first major victory of the re-
Nazis in Loulos, Chania.
The Turkish administration of Crete-
he replied immediately with a general
mobilization of the military
of forces and by violent acts
unprecedented savagery. Cut off
the culmination was the great massacre
of Heraklion (June 24, 1821),
who stayed for many years in
memory of the people as “the great
predators ”*. Nevertheless, the re-
nystasis quickly spread to
all over Crete and fasten-
θηθη.
c. The political organization of Crete
From the beginning of the struggle, the need for political organization became apparent
coordination of military and political actions towards its general principles
Struggle in the other Greece, especially after the decisions of the First National Assembly
in Epidavros. The absence of a general leader in Crete and their ambitions
local chiefs and chiefs were hurt by war and the co-
Donation of the struggle was impossible. So it was asked by Dimitrios Ypsis-
lat, which represented the supreme revolutionary authority in Greece, to
to appoint a General Commander in Crete "to whom the interlocutors should submit
of the rooted and none superior to the other recognizing Cretan chief-
γοί ». Ypsilantis appointed Michael Komninos Aphe- as Commander-in-Chief of Crete
Douli (or Afenduliev), who gladly accepted the appointment and came down
came to Crete (November 1821) with the resounding and annoying for many
chiefs of the title of "General Commander and Lieutenant General of Crete".
Afentoulis remained in Crete for exactly one year, until November
The official seal of the General Administration
Of Crete, during the period 1821-1824
Page 178
the Cretan question
177
of 1822. He managed to reorganize the revolutionary forces and hold-
the revolution is alive and well throughout the island. The most important thing is that care-
to establish a General Assembly of the Cretans in the Armenians
(11-22 May 1822) and to vote on the "Provisional Government of Crete",
as well as the "Temporary Administration Plan of the island of Crete", with a standard of
decisions of the National Assembly of Epidaurus. The fight in Crete was evident
to evolve in parallel with the struggle of the other Greece.
d. The first great crisis of the Cretan revolution
In practice, things turned out to be much more difficult. The Sultan
found himself unable to suppress the Cretan revolution and demanded it
with the help of the regent of Egypt, Mohammed Ali, who accepted
willingly the invitation. The landing of an Egyptian army in Crete (fees
May 1822) and the first failures of the Cretans in the battlefield clone-
like the position of Afentoulis. His opposition to local leaders and
The constant questioning of his actions led to a great crisis
revolution. Afendoulis was held responsible for many wars.
luckily, he was fired by the members of a newly formed "Cretan Council"
and was imprisoned in November 1822. Her “Presidents and Plenipotentiaries
Homeland ", as the Cretans were called representatives in the National Assemblies
of the Peloponnese, demanded the appointment of a new Commander. Ioannis Kolettis
pointed to Hydraean Emmanuel Tombazis as the Commissioner of Crete, who arrived
on the island in May 1823.
The arrival of Tombazis in Crete was associated with some military successes.
and the morale of the revolutionaries was revived. One month after his arrival,
Tombazis convened a General Assembly of the Cretans in which he voted
"Organization of the unified local administration of the island of Crete", with the basic ones
principles of the Epidaurus Constitution. The Cretan struggle thus entered a new one
phase.
At the same time, however, the Turkish-Egyptian forces also regrouped. At
In early June 1823 he arrived in Crete as the new commander of the Egyptian army
Hussein Bey's army, with new military forces and plenty of warfare
material. The rapid movement of the Turkish-Egyptian army to the east, the
the destruction of villages, the siege and the sacrifice of 370 Christians in the cave
of Melidoni (January 1824) created a heavy climate of pessimism. THE
Tombazis appealed for help to the President of the Executive
Page 179
the Cretan question
178
George Kountouriotis (March 2, 1824). 1 However, help did not arrive
revolution seemed to be bent everywhere, especially after the invasion of Hu-
in Sfakia and the destruction of the province at the end of March. At 12 o'clock
In April, Tombazis left Crete, asking the Cretans to
continue the struggle with every sacrifice.
In late May 1824, Hussein declared that he had stifled the revolution
in Crete. The Turkish-Egyptian army controlled all the plains and
The struggle took the form of guerrilla warfare. Rebel groups continue fighting
to carry out night raids and sabotage against the Turks. These were the ones
infamous Good evening. Similar guerrilla groups called Zu-
The Turks also formed rides.

was founded on October 7, 1825 by him

official of the Greek Administration, forerunner
of today's "Government Gazette".

Lord, if you lose the Nation of the beautiful Crete, you will lose your right eye.
and independence doesn't want to be important ...

Page 180
the Cretan question

e. The second period of the Cretan revolution:
The period of Grambousa (1825-1828)
While it seemed that the revolution in Crete had been suppressed and limited
only in sporadic guerrilla attacks on Turkish villages and fortresses,
Cretan revolutionaries, who from time to time had taken refuge in the other Greece,
returned to the island in the summer of 1825, with the decision to re-ignite-
in the revolution. Led by Dimitrios Kallergis and Emmanou-
El Antoniadis captured the fortress of Grabousa (August 9, 1825) in
homonymous cape of Western Crete, and on the same day other revolutionaries
they captured the fortress of Kissamos. Attempt by the Turks to recover
These fortresses failed and so a new revolutionary revolution began in Crete.
period, the so-called Grambousa period (1825-1828). The revolutionaries who
fortified there, engaged mainly in piracy to secure a way-
fima and supplies, built a settlement and the church of Panagia tis Kleftrinas *
and founded a school. A temporary Steering Committee was also set up, which
It was renamed the "Cretan Council" and was the official revolutionary
beginning of Crete, and Tombazis' "Pericles" golet was bought to
carries food and supplies to the Grabousa guard.
The Treaty of London (July 6, 1827) had a direct effect on the Cretans.
things. The rumor of an imminent solution had already spread widely
Greek issue with the creation of an independent Greek state and the
English diplomacy assured that all revolutionaries would be included in it.
Greek areas. Tombazis wrote to the Cretans to rekindle
at all costs the revolution throughout Crete. From its inception
In the autumn of 1827 there were feverish movements, re-formed
static corps of volunteers from the Peloponnese and other Greece, to
support the Cretan struggle, and fierce battles were fought throughout
Crete.
f. The last period of the revolution in Crete (1828-1830)
War and political action during the last two years of the struggle
The movements of European diplomacy, which are related to the Re-
attitude in Greece and the organization of an independent Greek state, was
Naturally to affect the revolution in Crete. Ioannis Kapodistri-
let him arrive in Greece at the beginning of 1828 and immediately indulged in the organ-
state union. Trying to make maritime trade safe,
Page 181
the Cretan question
180
in accordance with the relevant requirement of the Forces and in particular of England, decision-
he stole the plunder and piracy in the Greek seas. In the State
Bousa sent Alexandros Mavrokordatos, accompanied by an Englishman and
French fleet. The ships of the revolutionaries and the fortress were destroyed
of Grabousa was handed over to the English, who also undertook the task
maritime surveillance for maritime safety. The revolutionaries
the Grabousa were disbanded and took refuge in the mountains.
Despite these failures and the adverse conditions that have developed,
the Cretans continued to keep the revolution alive throughout
Crete. Unexpected development, which created a climate of intense concern
on the island, was Kapodistrias' decision to send to Crete as a counter-
his face the baron Rainek, with recommendations for the cessation of hostilities-
sour. The Cretans refused to obey the Governor's recommendations. The
In the summer of 1828, almost all of Crete was under their control
revolutionaries. The Turks were confined to large fortresses, where
were made up of the regular Turkish army.
These events resonated with the peoples of Europe, where
There were some demonstrations of sympathy for the struggling Cretan people.
The British and French fleets blocked the Cretan coast to prevent it
landings of Turkish-Egyptian forces on the island, while Kapodistrias also
changing his policy towards the Cretans, he sent him to the island
Tombazi (November 1828), with the order to occupy Sitia, the only pe-
area of ​​Crete that still remained entirely in their absolute possession
Turks. A large operation organized for her release
failed and Sitia suffered severe retaliation from the Turks (December
1828).
From a diplomatic point of view, the Cretan Question was at that time in
liquidity situation, as there was no final decision within it
of the whole Greek problem, and the information that reached Kapodis-
They were not clear. This also explains his unstable policy on
the Cretan issue. Pressed by England, he recalled the representative
of Rainek from Crete and in his place placed the Englishman Han, who
remained in Grabousa until October 1829, when it was replaced-
He and the famous Cretan Nikolaos Renieris. The prospects are clear
now more than ever auspicious, as almost all of Crete
it was under the full control of the rebels, except for the three major ones
fortresses (Chania, Rethymno, Heraklion), to which the Turks had taken refuge.
Page 182
the Cretan question
181
The London Protocol and the blockade of Crete.
The first reactions
The hopes, which were maintained by the diplomats of the time and the common ones
Kapodistrias lived, that with the international conventions that would determine the sub-
The Greek state would justify all the revolutionary el-
Greek regions and of course Crete, were refuted. With the Protocol
of London (1830) the Great Powers, despite previous promises
They left Crete outside the borders of the newly formed Greek state,
under the absolute jurisdiction of the sultan. This solution was imposed by the English
diplomacy, which sought to persuade European public opinion that “the pro-
Crete's dependence on the Greek trunk is not essentially a factor in
the prosperity and independence of the new state. " This energy of English
diplomacy filled the Cretans with bitterness and frustration.
The bitterness of the Cretans then turned against Kapodistrias as well. In an emergency
meeting of the Cretan Council on April 22, 1830 a drama was written-
Proclamation to the Greeks, which is essentially the first
proclamation of the new historical course, which was officially named "Cretan
Question Cretoise and occupied the euro for about a century.
European diplomacy, as a new thorny aspect of the Eastern Question. The
fundamental demands for national freedom and union with Greece
have now become the constant indicators of the course of the Cretan struggles. 2
Ships of the Great Powers blocked the Cretan coast, in order to
they put peace on the island, while the "Cretan Council" did not stop them
appeals and steps to the rulers of Europe, I claim
and the internal situation of Crete. Attempt by the Cretans to re-
occupy the fortress of Grabousa and rekindle the re-
"Crete was and is an integral part of this Greece, as a co-
angled and competing with the other rebellious parts of the
principle, so that they cannot understand how in various acts
of the regulars of these respected monarchs, Crete was by no means silenced,
while it even has the destructive war within it
and the Turks are limited in their fortresses only by the Greeks-
... We find our salvation only in our weapons and
in this honest death ... ".

the Cretan question
attitude failed. On November 23, the "Cretan" met for the last time
Council "to the Margarites of Mylopotamos. Drafted one last protest-
cheese to the Governor of Greece and to the Admirals of Europe
of which it denounced the general conspiracy against it
Crete: "Everyone agrees, Turks, Christian Rulers Ministers and the Greek
Governments have conspired against the Christians of Crete today, willingly
perhaps they will give them the ultimate victim of the freedom of their other brothers ... ".
A resolution was also drafted to set up a standing committee, which will
From now on, he was monitoring the progress of the Cretan issue and will ensure
it fueled the cohesion and cooperation of the thousands of Cretans who had settled
as refugees in free Greece.
The attitude of English diplomacy towards the Cretan issue was connected
with its general policy on the Eastern Question. England considered him
control of Crete as a matter of capital importance for their support
its interests in the East. The geographical location of the island at the cross-
road of maritime communications, made it "key to the Greek archi-
of the sea ”and together with Cyprus were“ the keys of Egypt ”. The problem
of English control in Crete had already been born from the period of the na-
wars of war (1806), when England was planning its immediate occupation
island, in case France and Russia extended the zones of influence-
in the North and East. So it is obvious that her doctrine
Turkey's integrity, which has been consistently supported by British diplomacy,
aimed, among many others, at occupying Crete by force
friendly to England, as this would ensure its naval sovereignty
in the Mediterranean. That was the most serious reason why England refused.
Crete was to be included in the newly formed Greek state.
Page 184
183
the Cretan question
B. THE AREA 1830-1866
1. The period of Egyptian rule (1830-1840)
The Sultan gave Crete to the regent of Egypt Mo-
Hamlet, in return for the services he had provided
during the ten-year revolution in the Peloponnese and Crete, and
this concession was enshrined in the London Protocol. So the
Crete was passing from Turkish to Egyptian occupation, in a new period-
for "stylized slavery". The ambitious monarch of Egypt understood
the importance of the occupation of Crete for his country and aimed at
from the beginning to the perpetuation of the new situation. To avoid ex-
interventions and international entanglements, immediately took short measures for it
ensuring internal peace and establishing a regime with
superficial equality and justice, while at the same time implementing one
program of major public works on the island.
In order to carry out this program, it was necessary to
taxation in the Christian population. The new repressions forced them
Cretans to hold an intense unarmed protest in the village of Mournies
Chania. This action went down in history as the "Mourning Movement, or the
Mournidon ”(September 1833). About 7,000 unarmed Christians from all over
Provinces of Crete demonstrated their bitterness and indignation and sub-
wrote a report to the Great Powers, invoking protection
their. The reaction of the Egyptian administration was immediate and harsh. Continue
41 primates were taken and hanged.
Mohammed Ali's ambitious plans bothered many English citizens.
, who repeatedly raised the issue of the occupation of Crete or
of its detachment from Egyptian rule. Such branded proposals
took place after the Mournid movement, and in 1837, when a pro-
British Navy's readiness missile in the Eastern Mediterranean, except-
Russia's expansionist plans. The occupation and fortification of the col-
of Souda and other topical positions of the Cretan beaches were in
immediate plans of the English military. For their part, the Cretans
they began to understand that the power of arms was not enough for the solution
of the Cretan Question and that his freedom and national restoration
island was mainly a matter of European diplomacy, and more of it
English. In fact, as the new despotism in Crete seemed powerful and
Page 185
the Cretan question
184
Foreign diplomacy showed no inclination to deal with an issue that
just recently closed it, many Cretan revolutionaries and we think-
Those who had taken refuge in free Greece began to use new methods
action patterns. A committee of Cretans submitted to England on 20 November
1839 proposal for colonial occupation of the island or even for its proclamation
in an English protectorate. England, busy with other major signals
Let there be problems in the East, then he showed no inclination to move towards
this direction. In fact, it is characteristic that this philhellene is also
Minister Lord Palmerston gave the answer: "... if Crete belongs
de facto et de jure * in the Sultan, it would be impossible for Great Britain to detach-
to the island from her friend and ally Turkey and to subject it to possessions
of the Crown ". But official Greek politics also condemned and condemned
He made such moves that not only posed serious risks to her
future of Crete, but they may have caused it for itself
Greece complications, which may have led to a Greek-Turkish war.
The great crisis of the Eastern Question during the years 1839-1841, with the second
The Turkish-Egyptian war naturally affected the Cretans as well.
things. Mohamed Ali's defeat in Syria shakes Egyptian sovereign
in Crete. The Great Powers, whose opposites favored it

Page 186
the Cretan question
185
Turkey, since the doctrine of its integrity ensured the delicate balance-
European peace, decided by the Treaty of London (July 3)
1840) to detach Crete from Egypt and bring it back to
absolute sovereignty of the sultan.
These new developments gave the opportunity to the exiled Cretans
chiefs to return to Crete and organize new re-
attitude, counting on bringing them back to the table of international diplomacy
the Cretan Question. The then young Greek went down to Crete with them
politician Alexandros Koumoundouros. King Otto and the then Greek
The victorious government encouraged the revolution, which they placed inside
in the general context of the grandiose policy of the time. The so-called
"Orthodox Society", which, it should be noted, was hostile to Otto, had
plan similar uprisings in many Turkish-occupied areas.
Everyone believed that these uprisings would be affected by its evolution
Cretan revolution.
The revolution, which took place only in February 1841 (revolution-
Heiratis and Vassilogeorgi), had a limited area and was from the beginning
doomed to failure. The Greek government was in complete disarray.
Namia to help the rebels, while the Great Powers condemned
from the beginning the movement. Characteristic of the new revolutionary ideas was
the organization of the "Cretan State".
Despite its failure, this new Cretan revolution of 1841 gave it
opportunity to make demands, which only much later would find
their solution. A memorandum of the revolutionaries of Western Crete, submitted
was given to the consuls of the three Great Powers (England, France and
Russia) on April 5, 1841, for the protection of the rights of the Cretan-
of the people and for its national independence, found no response.
It is also noteworthy that during this revolution he was nominated for first-
this time by Cretan revolutionaries the solution of the autonomy of the island. The solution
this was also rejected by the Great Powers, not only because it would be one
precedent for other unredeemed Greek areas, but mainly because it will
was the beginning of new claims for the unification of Crete with Greece. For
English policy, with which the French now joined, the union with El-
oil would bring Crete to the sphere of Russian influence, and that should
in any way to prevent it.
2. The Revolution of Hairetis-Vassilogeorgis (1841)
Page 187
186
the Cretan question
The return of Crete to the sultanate (January 1841), no
changed the basic principles of the internal administration of the island. Mrs.
what revolutionary effervescence occurred in 1848, on the occasion of the Friends
I set up movements in Europe that year, but conditions did not allow it
now the outbreak of a new revolution. For military reasons, however, the sul-
Tanos transported the capital of Crete from Heraklion to Chania (1850),
so that it is close to the great port of Souda and its fleets
M. Forces.
The Crimean War was an important milestone in historical developments
(1853-1856). With the Treaty of Paris (1856) the sultan was obliged to
issue the famous Hatti Humayun (Imperial Bible), with which pa-
It was for the first time that important privileges were granted to Christian citizens
(secularism, personal freedom, securing property and its own
price).
The refusal of the Turkish authorities in Crete to apply them to the island as well
Hatti Humayun's provisions led to new revolutionary action, which is
yes known as the "Mavrogenis Movement", from the name of the Hanioti chief
Emmanuel Mavrogenis (May 14, 1858). The fear of a new revolution, in
At a time when Turkey was internationally humiliated, it forced the sultan to
negotiate with Cretan leaders. It was published on July 7, 1858
sultan's firman with which it was granted to the Christians of Crete
religious, administrative, tax and judicial privileges, as well
the right to bear arms. In addition, the privilege of the organization was granted.
of the Christian Elders, an institution of great importance for the internal
organization and life of Christian communities. The Elders
undertook the important task of social welfare and education, with
establishment of hospitals and schools.
Over the next decade, until the outbreak of his great revolution
1866, English propaganda tries to cultivate the idea in Crete
of the creation of an "island Greek state", under English protection.
It is the movement of the so-called "counter-revolutionaries", whom he also supported
encouraged the English Consul in Chania Henry Ongley. The idea did not find
hard ground, as it clashed with the universal disapproval of the Cretans
and its few supporters were isolated as traitors to the national idea.
even if they were imitated with popular satires.
3. The events of the period 1841-1866.
The Mavrogenis movement

the Cretan question
C. THE GREAT CRETAN REVOLUTION
OF 1866-1869
1. The national character of the revolution
The first major crisis of the Cretan Question after the revolution of 1821-
This took place in 1866, with a new great revolution. The revolution-
In 1866-69, the "second '21, as it was called, was the best
expression of the Cretans' desire for freedom and national restoration. The
dominant slogan "Union or Death", which replaced the old "Free
Thermia or Death ", expresses eloquently and concisely the national character
of the Cretan Question, which quickly took on great proportions and employment-
He took Greek and European diplomacy very seriously, as important
aspect of the whole Eastern Question.
Conditions were unfavorable, not only in terms of military pro-
preparations and the analogy of the forces of the revolutionaries with those of it
Turkey, but mainly in terms of the general political situation in
Greece and Europe. The Great Powers, and especially England and France
From the beginning, they were opposed to any movement that would endanger them
the integrity of the Ottoman Empire. Only Russia, which had the
starved of the Crimean War and the Treaty of Paris (1856), it seemed
to favor the revolution of Crete and to encourage it, in fact, through them
its representatives on the island.
Greek politics has been divided from the beginning. Dimitrios
Voulgaris, who liked English politics, was hesitant, while O.
Alexander Koumoundouros, a follower of Russian politics and declared
pro-Cretan, he was more determined. But the official government
of Benizelos Roufos was clearly the opposite. 3 Despite all these adversities
Crete was in constant revolutionary fever. The union's request
with Greece was submitted with an official report of their General Assembly
"The current situation in Europe and the East,
Every movement recklessly in Crete remains undeniably destructive.
The Cretans ... I have to be very careful not to get carried away by the movement
either from a misjudgment of the European situation.
or out of inconsistent advice and encouragement from impatient people
and extinct. "
Undersecretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs ΒαλαωριτΗ προσ
Ellinas proxenos in Chania n. Sakopoulos (April 16, 1866):
3
Page 189
the Cretan question
188
Cretans (May 14, 1866) in the sultan and in the Great Powers as "homo-
and constant desire "of the Cretan people.
The revolution, which erupted in August 1866, immediately took off
dimensions. In the first official revolutionary proclamation of the General Assembly
of the Cretans in the village of Askifou Sfakion (August 21, 1866)
it is clear that the revolution is the natural continuation of 1821. 4
The outbreak of a new revolution in Crete created general national excitement-
in other Greece. The "Central in favor of the Cretans" was founded in Athens
Commission "and in Syros the" Commission on Special Missions ", for aid
of the Cretan struggle with shipments of weapons, money and supplies, but also
lions who rushed from everywhere to strengthen the Cretans.
Of course, it was clear to everyone that patriotism and enthusiasm were not
were enough to compensate for the far superior Turkish forces.
But the big problem was the civilian population, which remained the most-
many times defenseless in the vengeful rage of the enemy and had to
resort to mountains or expatriation. This great revolution was imminent
to turn into a real tragedy, which was nevertheless dealt with by the Cretan
people with admirable determination and courage.
Insisting on our oath of allegiance in 1821, inspired by
the national feeling of Greek greatness and national unity and
full of hope from our legal struggle, we reject all pre-
We boldly and boldly proclaim before God and men as him
only our unanimous and lasting desire to unite after mother Greece-
see, bestowing on the Most High to bless our weapons for the full
success ...
4
General Assembly of the Cretans (1866)
Page 190
the Cretan question
189
The events of the war began in August 1866 with clashes
in the area of ​​Chania. The sultan commissioned the task of repression
of the revolution to Mustafa Pasha, who had fought in the past
Crete and had received the name "Giritlis" *. Mustafa Pasha called me
his announcement to the Cretans to lay down their arms, with the promise of Ika-
notification of their just demands. The answer was given by the General Assembly.
liberation of the Cretans. "The slogan . Union or Death " , which I deceived Crete
he announced, he gives the appropriate answer ".
The general command of the fight was taken over by veteran soldiers, while
learned priests undertook the delicate and difficult task of correspondence with
the Foreign Consuls and the diplomatic management of the struggle. It was organized
also "Provisional Government of Crete", without permanent residence. The constant meta-
The movement of its headquarters in the mountains, depending on the needs of the struggle, was the a-
to be given the name "Government of the Mountain". With mobile printing
issued proclamations to the Cretan people and official newspaper, the first
Greek-language newspaper on the island, entitled "Crete" and the subtitle "Eno-
Sis or Death ".
K Ata the first months of the revolution taking place in epic battles
all over Crete. The events of the first year culminated with the pol-
2. The outbreak of the revolution and the organization of the struggle
3. The war events. The international impact
The explosion of the Monastery of Arkadi (Athens, Gennadios Library)
Page 191
190
the Cretan question
oath and the holocaust of the historic Arkadi Monastery (November 8, 1866).
This has caused a great deal of excitement in the world community.
"The heroic monastery, the fortress-like struggle, is dying like a volcano! The
Fish are not more advanced, Messolonghi is not higher ", wrote the media
French writer Victor Hugo, one of the most ardent supporters
of the Cretan struggle. Letters, responses and articles in the international press
created a favorable climate in favor of the struggling Crete to the peoples of Ev-
Europe and America. Many foreign pro-Cretans and philhellenes came to
Crete to fight or to work as war correspondents euro-
American and American newspapers. The Cretan struggle was real
explosion of liberalism. Companies and Associations were established to support
of the Cretan struggle and especially for the protection of the tried civilian
population and the treatment of refugees, who by the thousands took refuge
in Piraeus and the Aegean islands, mainly in Syros. Volunteers from
Serbia, Italy, Hungary and other regions have called for them to come
in Crete, as well as many well-known journalists of the time. Bold
Greek sailors were sending weapons, food and supplies
and transported volunteers from the other Greece to the coast of Crete with
ships "Arkadion" and "Panellinion".
Despite the military successes of the Turks, the revolution was maintained
alive throughout Crete. The High Gate, having to face the cat-
international public outcry and the temporary reversal of the gal-
diplomacy in favor of the Cretans, made a move to impress.
In January 1867 he sent to Crete a representative of the sultan,
with two main propositions: a) the cessation of hostilities and b) the apo-
uniform in Istanbul two representatives, one Christian and one
Muslim, who would work with the High Gate to counter-
crisis management. At the same time, he recalled Mustafa Pasha and appointed him
his position as head of Crete was Omer, who had a reputation as one of them
best generals of the Ottoman Empire.
Omer arrived in Crete in March 1867 and immediately began clearing
business. However, his successes did not bring the desired
result. They simply proved that the revolutionaries were not able to oppose
beat the regular Turkish army. But the permanence of Turkish
occupation in the various areas was not possible. As soon as the Turk left -
Army, the rebels were returning from their inaccessible hideouts.
A real vicious circle had been created and the revolution had taken place.
fall into tragedy, with civilian casualties as the main victims.
Page 192
191
the Cretan question
The European diplomacy was seeking a political solution to the Cretan question.
Already the shipments of volunteers, supplies and weapons from Greece had
infuriate Turkey. With its ultimatum, Turkey at the end of December
1868 accused Greece of active involvement in the Cretan revolution
and threatens the threat of a Greek-Turkish war, which was averted
only with the intervention of the Great Powers. Greece, under their pressure
Great Powers, was forced to accept the terms of the Turkish ceremony-
write and stop sending volunteers and supplies to Crete. THE
Turkey on the other hand backed down on England's suggestions and proposed
to the revolutionaries an honest solution, with the granting of general amnesty
and new privileges to the Cretan people.
In January 1869 the events unfolded rapidly. The European di-
diplomacy had now turned definitively in favor of Turkey. The Great Powers
decided by the Treaty of Paris (January 9-20) to be banned
in Greece the formation of volunteer corps for action in Turkish
lands, as well as the supply from Greek ports of ships
to help in any way any attempt to revolt against them
possessions of the Sultan's A. M. ".
The revolution was now out of breath, without their desire being realized
Cretans for freedom and national restoration. Human losses and
material damage was incalculable for Crete, but also for Otho-
Manichaean Empire's reputation suffered an irreparable blow, as fa-
He was unable to tame an island, despite the frightening volume of forces
in men and armaments.
Or from the beginning of September 1867 the sultan had ordered a cessation
of hostilities for five weeks, proposing a general amnesty
and a political solution to the Cretan Question. Later, he sent to Crete the first-
his minister, the great vizier Aali Pasha, administrator and others
concessions, which formed the basis of a new constitutional charter
Crete, the so-called "Organic Law".
The revolutionaries rejected the Turkish proposals, but Aali Pasha
proceeded with the rapid elaboration of the Organic Law. He announced
elections in the Turkish-occupied areas and formed a coalition
4. The end of the great Cretan revolution
5. The "Organic Law of Crete"

arrival of 30 Muslims and 20
Christians, people without anyone
prestige and no enforcement, elected
with promises and bribes. So
proceeded with the vote of the Organization-
Law, which came into force
on February 3, 1868.
The basic provisions of the Organic
The law was as follows:
1) Crete was a vilayet of hers
Ottoman Empire, we manage-
by the Commander-in-Chief (Vali) Muslim-
mother, appointed by the sultan.
2) The island was divided into five administrations-
and twenty provinces.
3) In the central and provincial
administrations could appoint-
Christian employees also.
4) In the composition of the courts will
Christians and Muslims took part,
while elected councilors would participate in
Central Council of the General Administration-
and its boards of directors
prefectures and provinces.
5) The parity of the two was recognized
languages.
6) Various tax reliefs have been introduced.
These shadowy privileges of the Organic Law, which set the Cretan Life-
on a new basis, they have since become a constant reference point for all
subsequent liberation movements of the island, as autonomy.
