THE CRETAN ISSUE
193
D. THE CRETAN ISSUE AGAINST THE LAST
AREA OF TURKEY (1869-1898)
1. Crete from 1868 to 1878
The Organic Law was in force for a decade, as the new revolution
1878. Despite the triumphalism of the High Gate, which attempted to take
present the Organic Law as a gesture of goodwill and as proof
granting new privileges, this law was in fact fe-
νακή. The great injustice against the Christian element of the island was evident
immediately with the provisions on the election of representatives to the General Assembly. The
250,000 of the Christian electorate elected 38 representatives, while only a few
70,000 of the Muslim 36. Even the Jews, who were only 50 eco-
generals throughout Crete, elected 1 representative. Thus, from the beginning o
Organic Law became the subject of popular satire, which was expressed with a lot
interesting lyrics, which circulated anonymously and many
times wall-mounted on main streets of Cretan cities as para-
county wall newspapers. The popular expression “In Crete, the Organization of the do-
see the decoration "attributes the hatred that the Cretans felt for the new
this construction of the High Gate.
The Turkish authorities in Crete were literally implementing the provisions of the Or-
Ganic Law and imprisoned or exiled prominent Cretans with the slightest
suspicion. The situation in the first years after the revolution of 1866
it was truly tragic. The population had declined with the war and their co-
new expatriations, the villages were deserted, the houses were ruined and
uninhabited and the estates remained uncultivated. The High Gate made sure to
sends to Crete General Commanders fanatical Muslims, who di-
possessed by a spirit of intolerance. This spirit expressed, during the pe-
this rhyme, and the mighty "party of the Beys", contrary to any idea
concession of privileges and equating the Christian with the Muslim
element.
From 1871, Turkey entered a period of political instability, which
is considered a period of "Ottoman chaos". This period of politics
liquidity and instability revived the old English diplomacy plan-
let, for the establishment of an English protectorate in Crete. They supported the idea
the Anglophile Cretans, who, however, did not have popular support. Other states-
of the island, who were opposed to this view, promoted the idea
for the establishment of "Hegemony", according to the model of Samos. These views were there
merely theoretical in nature, since the High Gate had no disposition to
the Cretan question
Page 195
the Cretan question
194
changes, on its own initiative, the status of Crete. The first
the Turkish constitution (Midat ​​constitution) did not provide for any change in
regime of Crete, despite the intense steps of the Cretans.
The new crisis of the Eastern Question, with the explosion of the Russian-Turkish one
war in the spring of 1877, was a good opportunity for the organization-
of a new revolutionary movement in Crete. They were reorganized immediately.
Statistical Committee, a 24-member Committee for the Management of the Cretan was elected
Question and the "Cretan Center" was founded in Athens, for the gathering-
supplies and weapons. While the exiles began to descend to Crete
chiefs, Turkey's apparent defeat encourages Greek government-
of Charilaos Trikoupis to state unequivocally that he would support one
new revolution in Crete (December 27, 1877).
The revolution broke out in January 1878 and immediately took off
dimensions. Turkey's collapse in the Russo-Turkish war was immediate
effects on the evolution of the Cretan Question. Article 15 of the Treaty
of St. Stephen (February 1878) forced Turkey to complete
implementation of the Organic Law of 1868. In July 1878 the Consuls of
Great Powers in Crete imposed a truce, with the assurance that
The Cretan Question was to be addressed by the Berlin Congress, the
which would revise the Treaty of St. Stephen. The General Assembly
of the Cretans elected two representatives for the Berlin Congress but the
Greek government, because it feared that the Cretan representatives would be pressured
and accept the solution of hegemony, abandoned the constant demand of the union-
and banned them from moving to Berlin.
The decision of the Great Powers at the Berlin Congress does not differ
basically from that of Agios Stefanos. But the threat of continuation
of the revolution forced Turkey to accept England's proposal for new ones
concessions to the Cretan people. As a result of the new consultations,
The so-called "Aleppo Map", a new Convention signed by him
October 1878 in the homonymous suburb of Chania and was immediately ratified
by sultan's decree. It was a new Organic Law, which was in force
he for about a decade, until the revolution of 1889.
The main provisions of the Aleppo Charter were:
1. The Commander-in-Chief of Crete could also be a Christian. The-
2. The 1878 revolution
and the Aleppo Convention
Page 196
the Cretan question
195
The revolutions of 1878 in Thessaly, Epirus, Macedonia and Crete
Page 197
the Cretan question
196
He was five years old, with the possibility of renewal.
2. The Commander-in-Chief would have one counselor from the other religion (mum-
sultan, if he was a Christian, and a Christian, if he was a Muslim).
3. The General Assembly (= Parliament), in which they would be in the majority for the first time
Christians would have 80 members (49 Christians and 31 Muslims).
4. A Cretan Gendarmerie was established.
5. Greek was recognized as the official language of the courts and
General Assembly. Only official minutes, court decisions
and official mail would be written in both languages.
6. General amnesty granted.
7. Significant tax breaks were instituted.
8. The right to establish Philology was granted for the first time
Associations and the publication of newspapers.
The Aleppo Convention was a new step towards the solution of the Cretan Question-
but. It created a semi-autonomous provincial regime, with particular pre-
legal. The provisions of this Convention changed its form for the first time
life in Crete and reversed the situation in favor of the Christians until then.
T the result of the beneficial provisions of the Convention Chalepa
it appeared immediately. The High Gate appointed a Christian Commander-in-Chief, him
Alexandros Karatheodoris, who was succeeded by a very educated man
active man, Ioannis Fotiadis, who had both administrative and diploma-
experience, as he had served as Turkey's ambassador to Athens.
He ruled Crete until 1885, with wisdom and justice. Support her
education, with the establishment of schools, and promoted the solution of big and serious
financial problems. Philanthropists were founded in the big cities
Associations, and measures were taken to protect the antiquities of the island.
It is certain that without these measures many of the presumptions of Cretan art.
would be in foreign countries today.
The granting of the right to publish newspapers paved the way
in Cretan journalism. It is noteworthy that as early as 1880
There is a real journalistic fever in Crete, with the establishment of
Greek newspapers for the first time, with militant journalist-
who were in daily danger, threatened with imprisonment and exile
by the Turks.
But this positive image came to overshadow the party's passion for retaliation.
νισμών. During this decade, Crete experienced a period of partisan factionalism,
3. Crete in the decade 1878-1888
Page 198
the Cretan question
197
which had a very serious impact on the internal unity of Christianity
element and the smooth development of political life. Two major parties are
The Caravans * and the Barefoot * * were founded, with different views and the-
for the Cretan Question. These two parties sharpened their political passions
many times they committed acts of violence, destruction and murder. The Cretan
The issue now seems to have been forgotten in the vortex of political passions.
In 1888 the idea of ​​English protection was once again displayed,
which, however, was rejected by most politicians and the military
leaders. In the newspaper "White Mountains", Eleftherios Venizelos, a young lawyer
The then and rising star in the political establishment of Crete, wrote:
"We prefer the Turkish sovereignty over all English." It was certain
that Turkish rule in Crete would be overthrown quickly, while the shaking off
a possible English occupation would be difficult and perhaps impossible and so on.
Crete's national desire could not be justified.
In 1888 elections were called for the nomination of proxies for it
General Assembly. In these elections, the party of the Barefoot won.
The Karavanades party, which claimed the election had not taken place
smoothly, he reacted in an unexpected and reckless way. At the General Assembly
On May 6, 1889, he abruptly tabled a Resolution plan, with
which proclaimed the union of Crete with Greece. The act was judged directly
subversive, the Assembly dissolved, the Karavanadas officials resorted
They went to the mountains and declared a new armed revolution.
This untimely and frivolous action had devastating consequences for Crete.
Issue. Military law was declared on the island and there was violence.
acts and robberies to the detriment of the civilian Christian population.
At the same time, the High Gate, under the pretext that the public is in danger in Crete.
parliamentary institutions, revoked the privileges of the Map of Aleppo (December 17)
September 1889). Terrorism of recent times has returned to Crete
very heavy taxation was imposed.
The five years 1889-1894 are characterized as the most gloomy period of the tur-
democracy in Crete. Personal freedom, property and honor
of the Cretans was at the discretion of the enraged naughty Ottomans (basi-
4. The 1889 revolution and its aftermath
5. The idea of ​​the Reformation.
The revolution of 1895-1896
Page 199
the Cretan question
198
buzukon), who together with fanatical Turkish-Cretans created pa-
a climate of fear and insecurity. Night raids on villages, persecution
of the clergy, the killings and desecration of temples and monasteries were
everyday phenomenon.
During this period of great anarchy, the idea of ​​"Metapolitism-
that is, an autonomous or semi-autonomous state under it
supremacy of the sultan and under the protection of the Great Powers. Inspiration
In this idea was the Sfakian politician Manousos Koundouros, the
who believed that the prevailing conditions did not allow the union
of Crete with Greece and solutions of another type had to be methodized, i.e.
a temporary regime, which would be the prelude to it
final solution of the Cretan Question. These ideas seemed to be embraced
and the English Consul in Chania. A memo from Koundouros was submitted
to the Consuls of the Great Powers. There were three main points
memo:
1) To declare Crete an autonomous tax state subject to the sultan-
for 15 15,000 a year.
2) To appoint a Christian commander for a five-year term, without the
sultan right to terminate or replace him.
3) To re-grant with substantial improvements all the privileges of the Map
of Aleppo, which had been recalled after the 1889 revolution.
This act was considered a direct revolutionary act and the General Commissioner-
The commander ordered the arrest of the leaders of the "Metapolitism". That's how it started
the new and last period of the Cretan revolutions, which led
the Cretan Question in its solution. The "General Epa-
Cretan Assembly "and" Central "was reconstituted in Athens
in favor of the Cretan Committee ".
The atrocities committed against Christians had caused
with great intensity and obvious disposition of retaliation on the part of the re-
stator. In the face of this situation, the Great Powers intervened and
They called on Turkey to grant a new "Organic Law" which it provided
the restoration of the Map of Aleppo, with improvements in privileges. The young
This regulation was provided for the first time to the Great Powers of Europe by
intervention, to protect the civilian population from continuous
and uncontrollable violence.

result.

move on the Cretan Question. The Great Powers have decided to
in Crete, to protect the civilian population, according to him

Artillery Colonel Timoleon Vasso, who disembarked
in Crete on February 1, 1897 and with a proclamation to the Cretan People
announced the occupation of Crete by the Greek army, the catalysis
of the laws of the Ottoman Empire and the application of the Greek
of the constitution and Greek law.
This new turn of events infuriated the Great Powers, who rushed to
as if to block the Cretan coast and disembark militarily
games in Chania. Crete was officially placed under international protection for the first time.
stasis. The first military successes of the Greeks and the revolutionaries
forced the Great Powers to intervene, proposing for the first time official
but the solution of autonomy (February 17, 1897). But so many Cretans po-
Lithuanian and military leaders, as well as the Greek government, rejected it
categorically. 5
"We have always tried the regimes and the privileges that we have.
Europe has risen, but because of all this we have gained nothing but
catastrophic devastation, which was not perpetuated by Christianity
Europe to block. We have now recovered from the unfortunate experiments
which the Christian governments of Europe have largely implemented
of the most unfortunate of the oppressed peoples and therefore not
we will now commit the crime of accepting privileges and autonomy,
which will roll us again tomorrow in blood and destruction,
but we will insist until the end on OUR UNITY AFTER NOT-
THREE GREECE, and, either we will achieve this union or we will die
up to one after our women and children, and then let the
civilized Christian Europe our desolate Greek Crete, as
he wants to. "

Along with the punishment of the protagonists, the Great Powers accepted-

The road to freedom was open. On November 2, 1898, the last
A Turkish soldier left Crete for good. On November 5
1898 The Cretans lay down their arms, obeying the order of the Executor
to facilitate the smooth transfer of power to the principal
of the Great Powers Prince George, who arrived in Crete one
month later, on December 9, 1898.
The long period of Turkish rule in Crete was over. I said it-

The following historical verse of the time expresses in a simple way the popular sy-
movement for the final liberation of Crete from sultanate rule:
The times have dried up and the winds have blown,
Your armies, Sultan, from Crete, also stopped you.
In Crete you don't tread, in Crete you don't cross,
only in the Red Apple ...

the Cretan question
E. THE AREA OF AUTONOMY
AND THE UNION OF CRETE WITH GREECE
1. The organization of the Cretan State
M means an indescribable frenzy excitement of the agent
Prince George of the Great Powers took over his duties at
December 9, 1898. The French Admiral Potier, in his capacity as President
of the Council of Admirals, officially handed over to George the administration
of Crete. The ships of the International Protection Forces greeted
the flag of the Cretan State and the High Commissioner addressed the first
his sermon to the Cretan people. 7 The Cretan flag was hoisted at the fortress
of Firkas, while the Turkish was preserved only in the fortress of Souda, as a te-
Last symbol of Turkish supremacy in Crete. The island was put under
international protection.
The foreign Admirals left the next day (December 10) and immediately
He hastened the difficult task of organizing the new politician
shape, named Cretan State. A 16-member committee has been appointed
by 12 Christians and 4 Muslims, to draw up the plan of the Cretan-
of the Constitution, while at the same time the political acts proceeded, without
7
International Protection Map
"I will do my best to ensure your well-being
to be well managed, justly and impartially, to acquire without exception
true security, not guaranteed only by the rule of law and institutions
you're done ... ".
Page 208
207
the Cretan question
The flag of the Cretan state
The High Commissioner of Crete
Prince George with them
Admirals of the Great Powers, straight away
after taking office
of (December 9, 1898)
delay. Exactly one month after the installation of the High Commissioner,
The first important decree "On the formation of Cretan" was published
Meeting ”and immediately elections were called for the nomination of a proxy-
Zion. 138 Christians and 50 Muslims were elected in these elections
The Cretan Parliament began its work on February 8
1899.
The Constitution of the Cretan State, drafted according to its model
of the then Greek Constitution, after being approved by their Council
Ambassadors of the Protective Forces in Rome, immediately implemented
Earth. A few days later, the first government was formed and sworn in
of the Cretan State, in which Eleftherios was appointed Minister of Justice
Mr. Venizelos.
Page 209
the Cretan question
208
The first government of the Cretan State worked diligently and effectively
in a short time important work. It delivered very quickly
laws and decrees, cut Cretan currency (the Cretan drachma), found-
at the Cretan Bank, organized a postal service and Gendarmerie with
Italian officers and non-commissioned officers (carabinieri). It was special
care for education and public health. The big one was faced
problem of leprosy, which had taken an endemic form in cities and towns
villages of Crete, organized by the leper colony of Spinalonga (1903),
many schools were established and teachers were appointed.
A serious issue, which was also successfully addressed, was the
to the local Church. With the Organic Law of 1900, a solution was given
in thorny ecclesiastical matters, such as the relationship of her Church
Of Crete with the Ecumenical Patriarchate and the election of Metropolitan and Bishop
πων. The basic scheme, which is valid with minor modifications to date, is
a regime of semi-autonomous Church, of which the Prelate is elected
from the Ecumenical Patriarchate and the Cretan State issues its Decree
its recognition and installation.
T the positive and optimistic atmosphere of the first two years of operation
new regime began to overshadow threatening clouds, which
they were to create a serious internal crisis a little later. The Sy-
Cretan state order was too conservative and concessional-
to the Hegemon, as the High Commissioner was called, superpowers, which
they could easily lead him to despotic behavior. In addition,
the ambiguity in the precise definition of responsibilities created friction and
personal confrontations in the work of the administration. Its local factors
Of Crete, who fought for the freedom of the island and supported with enthusiasm-
The Prince was now seen with discomfort and bitterness.
Athenian advisers to George, who
they were unaware of Cretan things and the psychology of the Cretans.
But most important was the management of the national question of union
of Crete with Greece. This essential issue has been observed from the beginning
difference of opinion between Georgios and Eleftherios Venizelos. George
son believed that the solution of the national question would mature with continuous performances-

and memoirs to the Great Powers, while Venizelos, seeing them

their replacement by a local militia, with Greek officers.
The difference of opinion on the political issue did not take long to take shape
personal confrontation. Venizelos had made it clear that he was not
recognizes in Prince the right to personally manage national life
Crete: “As one of the three hundred thousand Cretans, I do not give it to you
My right, so that you alone can voluntarily regulate its national policy
my place! ” Bad advisers to George channeled copper and cocoon
fantastic texts in the Athenian newspapers against Eleftherios Venizelos,
which created a heavy climate of division.
The crisis culminated on March 18, 1901, when George fired Be-
nickel from the post of minister. To support his views on
national issue of Crete, Venizelos published in the newspaper "Kirix"
of Chania, which he himself published, five much-praised articles, with the characteristic
title "Let there be light". George pursued a policy of intransigence and pro-
4. Therissos Revolution (1905)
a. The causes and reasons
English parade
Page 211
the Cretan question
210
divided into more authoritarian measures, with the ban on liberty
and with the persecution and imprisonment of prominent members of the Cretan opposition.
also.
Under these conditions, political things in Crete were driven
in complete impasse and all efforts to reconcile opponents po-
portions were wrecked. People around Venizelos formed a coalition
dissatisfied with the authoritarian policy of the Prince and formed
a very strong "United Opposition". Confident collaborators of Venizelos
were K. Foumis and K. Manos. These three were a trinity, that
did not hesitate to engage in a dynamic confrontation with the Prince.
At the end of 1904 the term of the General Assembly expired and a proclamation
Elections were held to elect 64 deputies. According to the constitution, 10
they would even be appointed directly by the Prince. The opposition decides
in not participating in these elections, he denounced his unfree measures
Prince and called on the people to abstain. The situation escalated on 26 February.
February 1905, when the opposition trinity and 15 other eminent
statesmen drafted and signed a proclamation requesting
violation of the constitution of the Cretan State. This announcement is the
first official revolutionary text, the harbinger of his revolution
Harvest. 8
Everyone was now convinced that an armed uprising was on the doorstep. The services-
the Prince had gathered information, while the united opposition-
It was deliberately leaking information that a possible uprising would take place
it was March 14th. In the meantime, they began to gather in large numbers
"The signatories, the United Opposition in Crete,
Sin, meeting in Chania on February 26, 1905, aiming at
the fulfillment of the National Program, we decide: a) First
and our main concern, even if it has been achieved for centuries
purpose of the union of Crete after free Greece. b) Weak
In pursuit of this goal, we want to pursue a political approach.
of our homeland to free Greece, changed by
internationally in the current situation. c) Not fulfilling zero
for this purpose we want to seek the revision of the mother co-
order according to the standard of the Greek, such as exemption the place of de-
sowing. We want to pursue this program
and through armed popular rallies. In our actions we do not want
seek personal change, but when it comes to it we want to
It strikes everywhere and even with weapons, always a non-Greek ruler ".

secrecy armed groups in Therissos. Venizelos and his associates

The revolutionaries surprised the Hegemon and proclaimed the revolution in
March 10, 1905. On the morning of that day, they were found glued to the walls
streets of Chania announcements, which declared the abolition of the competent-
Let them call on the people to support their dream come true.
and advised the gendarmerie not to obey the orders of the Pri-
gippa. At the same time, representatives of the revolutionaries were scattered throughout
Crete, to transmit and propagate the revolutionary message.
Within a few days, the entire Cretan countryside was in a state of revolution.
boiling. Resolutions of support came from everywhere, while the
other actors on the island, even political opponents of Venizelos,
joined the revolution. Venizelos, who was his natural leader
of this new revolutionary movement, undertook to inform the people and them

passed the law "On the Establishment of a Body of Democrats", which would support

In Crete there were now two governments, the Commissioner in Chania and the re-

The royal environment in Athens was concerned about the developments in Crete-
and pressured the Greek government to condemn the Therissos movement. THE
Prime Minister Diligiannis invited his representatives on March 12
Athenian press and made harsh statements against Venizelos and others
his associates. However, the movement found a positive response from the public
feeling and most Athenian newspapers openly supported it.
c. The attitude of the Great Powers
and the diplomatic maneuvers of El. Venizelou
The Great Powers did not take a united stand against the revolutionaries. The
more were waiting for the developments and only Russia was openly supporting him
Prince. Russian military repeatedly fired on the positions of the co-
nastats in Therissos, but to no avail. Venizelos was right
appreciated international politics and was confident that the Great Powers were
impossible to agree on a unified stance against the movement.
One disagreement was enough to thwart their coordinated action
foreign troops. After all, the Forces could not ignore
the danger of civil war, which would be generalized in Crete on the occasion of
their own mixing. The veteran politician Ioannis Sfakianakis in a pandemic
rally in Heraklion (March 21) spoke openly about the unacceptable
foreign interference and called on the people in universal support for the re-
status. 10
Meanwhile, the revolution had gained a strong foothold throughout Crete.
A "Provisional Government of Crete" was organized in Therissos, chaired by him
"There is one of you, there is one Chris, there is one Greek, I have
such nerve construction so that it can remain intact when man-
They thought that foreign soldiers were going to beat brothers, who else
do they ask only what we have all asked for? I suggest
to express unreservedly the opinion of those present and to declare to
the Forces, that, in this case, all the Cretans wrote
soul and body after those in Therissos ".

El. Venizelos and their ministers K. Foumi and K. Manos. The government did

The crisis shifted to diplomacy and was sought politically.
solution. The representatives of the Great Powers, appreciating the situation-
formed on the island, with its popularity declining
Prince, but also with the almost universal acceptance of revolutionary ideas

This is exactly what Venizelos predicted, that the revolutionary struggle

215
she and Venizelos, always weighing the existing situation, began
to plan his retreats, to ensure the greatest possible

regime similar to that of Eastern Romulia, essentially free,

d. The end of Therissos' revolution
and the triumph of Eleftherios Venizelos' policy
The insistence of the revolutionaries on the armed struggle and its prolongation
a situation that threatened economic and political collapse
Cretan state, forced the Protecting Forces to send
strict ultimatum to the rebels on July 2, 1905. The Generals
Prosecutors of the Forces, who signed this statement,
as it is clear that they could not change the political regime of the island.
But they reaffirmed that they would bring about substantial internal reforms.
which would dramatically improve the situation, provided that within 15 days-
The revolutionaries had to lay down their arms in parallel
general amnesty.
Negotiations were tough and lasted all summer 1905.
The final agreement was signed by El. Venizelos on November 2, 1905
at the monastery of Mournia Kydonia. A general amnesty was granted and
M. Powers pledged to work out a new concession map
to the Cretan people, however, refusing to allow the union of Crete with
Greece.
Therissos' movement did not fully achieve its goals, but gave new ones
strong impetus to the Cretan Question and provoked positive developments. International
A committee that came to Crete in February 1906 undertook to examine it
status and operating conditions of the competent regime and to
submit a report. After very long and painful consultations
with El. Venizelos and with the Greek Government, the Great Powers
ended up with a new regulation of the Cretan Question. The final text of the
reforms provided for the organization of the Cretan Gendarmerie with completely
new formation, the establishment of the Cretan Militia, with Greek officers who
previously the Greek army would have resigned, and the recall
of foreign troops, after the restoration of internal peace
in Crete.
Venizelos' policy had triumphed. Immediately after, the
B΄ Constituent Assembly, for the preparation of a new constitution, and the first
Page 217
the Cretan question
216
Its act was the issuance of a unifying resolution, in an atmosphere of reconciliation.
as well as national upheaval. With a new decision, the Forces gave up
to the king of the Greeks, George I, the right to appoint the High One
Commissioner of Crete (August 14, 1906). The island had essentially become one
idiosyncratic Greek province.
Following these developments, Prince George could no longer remain
in the Commission of Crete. Despite the persistent requests of the anti-Venize-
of his friends, he submitted his resignation (September 12, 1906) and
left Crete. The king of Greece, George I, indicated that he was new
High Commissioner Alexandros Zaimis. The Cretan Question had now entered
in the phase of its final resolution.
The Alexandros Zaimis, experienced politician Firstly
the Prime Minister of Greece and later
President of the Hellenic Republic, he took over
his duties on 18 September 1906. Politics
smoothness returned to troubled Crete and a
new period of creation was inaugurated. The economy
improved, public administration reorganized
and special care was taken for the organization-
public health and education.
Most importantly, it was organized for the first time
the Militia of Crete, that is, the first
army of the island (1907), which developed into a remarkable-
land power, as later seen in the Balkans
wars 1912-1913. The presence of foreign troops
The Great Powers have also become unnecessary
decided to evacuate Crete within a year, with only one guarantee
the security of the island's Muslims. A thank you Resolution
Cretan Parliament (May 21, 1908) to the Great Powers was the official policy
act of the emancipation of Crete from the protection of the Great Powers. The
island now had to move with its own forces in the management of Crete-
Question.

D. Two major external events came back to disturb the course of
Cretan affairs: the annexation of Bosnia and Herzegovina
from Austria and the proclamation of Bulgaria as a kingdom, at the same time
annexation of Eastern Romulia. The Greek government of G. Theotokis
He pointed out to the Cretans the need for popular mobilizations for its proclamation
union with Greece. At a popular rally in Chania, it was unanimously approved
the first resolution of the union and the Cretan Government issued in turn
of the official Resolution (September 24, 1908). 11
For the official start of the new period of political life in Crete,
an interim intergovernmental government was formed. The Greek government,
in order not to provoke international complications with Turkey's reaction, apo-
went to officially recognize the union and was limited to backstage
instructions to the new Provisional Government of Crete.

THE CRETAN ISSUE
219
8. The transfer of Venizelos to Athens
and the effects on the Cretan Question
A few months after taking over the presidency of the Cretan Government
by El. Venizelos, the Military Association that controlled Greek
political affairs after the revolution in Goudi (1909), called him to
Athens to assume the post of Prime Minister of Greece (September 1910). The ex-
This port created ambiguous feelings in Crete. Most
they expressed fears of the absence of a man he knew better
from any other to move in the labyrinths of European diplomacy and
to save national affairs in critical circumstances, while others believed that
from his new position he could solve the Cretan Question faster and
safer.
But Venizelos, as Prime Minister of Greece, with his sharpest policy
sensory knew that the time crew had not yet arrived. At
Persistent appeals from Cretan compatriots also responded negatively
he seemed unhappy. His constant refusal to allow Cretans to enter
MPs in the Greek parliament provoked strong reactions in Crete-
you. The unrest broke out in late 1911 and was re-established in
island Revolutionary Assembly (January 3, 1912), while they began to organize-
and armed units.
What diplomacy failed to solve, war solved.
Immediately after the outbreak of the Balkan Wars (October 1912)
As if the Greek Parliament was open for the Cretan deputies, who became
accepted with events of indescribable patriotic enthusiasm. The president
of the Hellenic Parliament read a Resolution, according to which “Greece
accepts like the other member of the Commonwealth for a free Vassi-
also for the island of Crete ". But Venizelos did not go further,
in order not to disturb its relations with the European Powers, in view of
of the war that had begun. It was enough to send to Crete as General
Commander his friend Stefanos Dragoumis, who took over his duties
on October 12, 1912.
The events unfolded rapidly, as the defeat of Tour- was now visible.
even if. In practice, the union had taken place and only its ratification remained

Greek government.

GREEK GOVERNMENT
A. ANCIENT GREEK
RESULTS OF THE PAIN
1. Geographical identification
The Sea as a geographical entity comprising, in antiquity, the
wide coastal country of the Black Sea. According to reports
which we draw from Herodotus, Xenophon and other ancient history-
in Pontus, from a spatial point of view, the areas between the
River phase, near which today is the city of Batumi, Georgia
and Heraklion the Mouse 1 .
The internal borders extend to a depth of 200-300 km and are demarcated.
are made of the geophysical reality, the inaccessible, that is, term-
series of Skydisis, Parryadris and Antitaurus, which separate him
Point from the rest of Central Asia 2 .
The presence of Greeks in the area of ​​Pontus dates back to no.
Happiness, when in the Bronze Age the Greek seafarers
they dared to explore the dangerous sea of ​​the Black Sea with me
its remote and steep beaches. The search, mainly, for gold and
other mines led many travelers to the area, around
1000 BC, with the first organized mission to Colchis, that of Jason and
of the Argonauts. Orestes' wanderings in Poania and Pontus
Odysseus in the land of the Cimmerians, the exile of Prometheus to the Caucasus and
Hercules' journey to Pontus confirms the existence of commercial ones
roads in the Pontus region since mythical times.
Two centuries later, in 800 BC, the temporarily initially trading stations
become permanent residential centers. Miletus was the first to inaugurate it
its colonial policy in the Black Sea by founding Sinope, a city with
many advantages due to its good port and smooth communication-
with the surrounding areas. Then Sinope founded in 756 BC. the
Trapezounta , the Kromni the Pterion , the Kytoro et
Another serious reason for the creation of Greek colonies in the Black Sea
Pontus was the need to move populations from Greece and Io-
due to the demographic growth of Greek cities. Specifically,
According to the geographer Strabo, the remote area of ​​Pontus was
very productive and rich in water and crops resulting in
2. Reasons for creation
Greek colonies in Pontus
Page 225
GREEK GOVERNMENT
224
Elli
victorious p
cities of the Black Sea
Page 226
GREEK GOVERNMENT
225
a century to fill the inhospitable beaches of Ev- with Greek colonies
Foreign Pontus.
Historical evidence for the flourishing of Greek colonies in the distant Po-
They are the seventy-five colonies that have existed since the 6th century
BC, as well as the rapid commercial, maritime and cultural development
of these colonies. Sinopi, Amisos, Trebizond, Pityounta, Fana-
north, Pantikapaion, Theodosia, Hersonissos, Olvia, Dionysopolis,
Mesimvria, Anchialos, Apollonia, Istria, Odessa, etc. became polyan-
Europe and strong centers for which the testimonies regarding the residential
organization, economic activities, trade and cultural relations
with the metropolises and the indigenous peoples coming from the excavations-
and the written sources of the classical and post-classical era 3 .
For economic reasons, five coastal cities, which today belong to
Romania: Tyra, Istria, Tomis, Callatis and Dionysopolis had
create the Pentapolis federation , which effectively contributed to
dominant role of these cities in many areas, but especially in
competitive trade with other peoples. The monopoly economy and
spiritual flourishing led the federation to form a defensive army-
corps and fortification of cities 4 .
From the 5th century BC. the Crimean region was the main supplier
Trabzon during the Pitton de Tournefort
Page 227
GREEK GOVERNMENT
226
wheat of Athens. The Athenian state, to protect its trade
interests in this rich country, built military along the coast-
colonies in which he settled 600 Athenian heirs. The commercial,
economic and strategic importance for Athens for this region,
proved by the visit of Pericles in 453 BC. With this realistic
Pericles secured maritime transport with the Black Sea
do, consolidating the unimpeded import and export of products from and
to Attica 5 .
Crucial role in the consolidation of Greek colonization in the wider
The founding of Plovdiv in 341 BC played a role in the region of northern Thrace. from
the king of Macedonia Philip II, who with his prudent policy succeeded
with the harmonious coexistence of the Greeks with the native Thracian ethnic groups. THE
the same political and diplomatic attitude towards the natives was applied
and by his successors, especially by Philip II. Thanks to the resident-
their political policy, with Greek populations from coastal cities to
inland, the term Thrace acquired geographical significance 6 . Plovdiv on
During the Roman occupation it became the capital of the province of Thrace and slowly
the intermediate trade and cultural station between Sigdona
(Belgrade) and Istanbul. Essentially the Hellenized and secret-
Stagnant Thrace, due to its great geostrategic position, right-
It was considered the suburb of the Queen of the Cities of Constantinople.
In the first centuries, the colonies maintained a stable social status
and political organization of their metropolitan origin. The Greeks
The populations respectfully kept the traditions, customs and traditions
urban data and the state institutions they had brought from
metropolis. Cities had good relations with each other and multiplied
mainly in coastal areas but also inland near aquifers
faces. The historian Xenophon, in his work "Kyros Anavasis", describes me
detail the life of the Greeks in Trabzon in 401 BC, emphasizing id-
in addition to the traditional hospitality of the Greeks of Pontus 7 .
Greek trade and culture developed very early in the colonies
of Pontus, while the wealthy regions offered valuable products for
the Greek economy. The raw materials, the cereals, the wood, the flax, the
livestock, fish and later products from the rich sub-
3. Social and cultural identity of the colonies
Page 228
GREEK GOVERNMENT
227
area of ​​the area (silver, copper, iron) were used to the best of their ability
way to the benefit of both trading parties.
Until the Alexandrian years, all coastal cities, mainly Trapi-
living, remained independent, autonomous and self-governing, thanks to the co-
their policy. According to Herodotus and Xenophon, these cities
they were not essentially enslaved to the Persians, but only formally . even
during the period of the Achaemenid dynasty they were subject to tax.
During the reign of Alexander the Great, Trabzon retained its independence.
one and its prosperity, while other colonies, such as Phocaea and Miletus,
They faced many problems and ultimately changed in ruins 8 .
During the Hellenistic period, Greek cities reached their peak
of their economic development. At the same time, the relations between the Greek
element and indigenous peoples continued to be close, with beneficial results
words on the social and cultural development of the wider region.
In the second century BC. the kingdom of Pontus was founded, which he met
great fame in the years of his rule by the Mithri dynasty-
δατών. Greek was then established as the official language of communication
of the numerous and multilingual ethnicities of Central Asia. Also note
a religious comparison was made between the Olympic Twelve and
the deities of the East, as can be seen from the archeological findings
of the temples built during that period throughout Pontus 9 .
A typical example of this comparison is his cult
Persian god Mithra, who without ever gradually disappearing
Coin from Sinope of Pontus
Page 229
228
GREEK GOVERNMENT
It was worshiped and merged with the worship of the gods Helios, Apollo and Hermes.
The parallel worship of indigenous and Greek deities led to the composition
of the Greek spirit with the wisdom of the East, which was essential
characteristic of the Mithridatic kingdom and its culture.
In the first period of Roman rule, after 63 BC, when the Roman sub-
Pompey captured Trabzon, economic, commercial and political
acne flourished during the Mithridatic period, as the Greeks maintained
their freedom, independence and autonomy. The absence of the central
Roman power, which enabled Greeks to develop
They have a variety of skills, and the adoption of the administrative scheme
of the Mithridates organization strengthened the Greek tradition and the Greek
prudence. According to Pliny, democratic law and liberalism
Roman administration during the first period ensured an exceptional
profitable administrative and commercial management, resulting in financial
and cultural prosperity of cities, as evidenced by the monuments
saved. The buildings, the hostels, the tombs testify to the richness of the cities
and prove that Greek art and science cultivated a system-
in all the cities of Pontus.
In the second period of Roman rule, the application of authoritarian rule
of the conquest of Diocletian and the other Roman emperors, by him
3rd century AD, was the beginning of a critical period for Pontus. Over the years
of the viceroy Livy, Trabzon and other Greek cities stopped-
as if they were self-governing. Even Constantine the Great, who to others
sectors helped the Hellenism of the region, as a proponent of centralization
policy, merged all local governments into its central government
Istanbul.
Page 230
229
GREEK GOVERNMENT
B. THE PRESIDENTIAL HELLENISM
DURING THE BYZANTINE AREA
M after establishing Istanbul entire Sea choristi-
and in three geographical regions. The western part that was named
Merciful in honor of the mother of Constantine, he included them
cities Amaseia, Ivora, Evhaita, Andrapa, Zaliha, Sinopi and Amiso. The east
section, which included the cities of Neocaesarea, Komana, Polemo-
Nion, Kerasounta and Trebizond was named the Pontic Pontus by
the name of Commander Polemon. The third geographical section, with capital
Nikopolis and well-known cities of Sebastia, Satala and Sevastopol
Armenian, which included part of Pontus and Little Armenia,
was named Cologne .
This geographical division lasted until the years of Justinian.
During this period, the Roman cultural influence on the el-
Greek population. Hellenism and Christianity were the factors that
they influenced the administrative mechanism and created the Greek-Byzantine one
empire 10 . During the long period of Roman rule reconstruction-
the Roman walls were built. Port works, new residential buildings and
camps in the city of Trabzon, to host the First
Pontian Legion. The people of Trabzon began to realize the importance
of their city on the East-Istanbul axis and the intermediary
their role in the capital's relations with the co-religionists, allied and
client states of neighboring Georgia 11 .
The Christianity spread very early in Pontus by the apostles
Andreas and Petros with the first missionary station in Amisos. Despite the
serious problems caused by followers of other religions and the
Roman administration, Christianity managed to establish itself in all the provinces-
in Pontus. In the years of the emperors Diocletian (284-305), Galerius
(306-311) and Maximinus (305-311), Pontus spent a critical twenty years
religious persecution, resulting in many Christians fleeing
inaccessible mountain peaks in the interior of the country. However, the systematic
Persecutions not only failed to stop the spread of Christianity
but they also intensified it.
The great spiritual fathers of the Christians of Pontus were the witnesses.
hours Eugene of Trebizond, Oualerianos from Ediski, Kanidios
1. The spread of Christianity
Page 231
GREEK GOVERNMENT
230
from Tsolosaina and Akylas from Godaini, Chaldia. His contribution
Eugene, in particular, in the ultimate predominance of Christianity has been so
decisive, so that this witness is honored as the patron saint of Trabzon 12
but also as a leading religious and spiritual figure by all the El-
Poles of Pontus.
During the reign of Constantine the Great, the church of Pontus was organized.
and the "Diocese of Trabzon in the Mouse Administration" was founded, which
later it became a metropolis with fifteen dioceses. Its consolidation
Christianity essentially contributed to the founding of many Christian churches
and monasteries, headed by St. John Vazelonos , of Panagia Sou-
Melas, of St. George Peristereotas and others, who contributed cat-
Mosaic of Agios Eugenios,
patron saint of Trabzon and New Romania

231
definitively in the spread and rescue of Christianity and Hellenism 13 .
After the Great Theodosius, a part of the eastern Pontus passed to
power of the Persian dynasty. The area of ​​Trabzon and the province
of Chaldea did not recognize Persian rule. With the victory of Justinian
the Persians were expelled from Lazia and other parts of the Pontus, a fact
which contributed to the completion of the spread of Christianity in Pontus,
with the Christianization of the Jan war.
In the years of Leo III of Isaurus, Pontus regained geopolitics,
his military and economic privileged position, because the Byzantine army-
due to the constant wars with the Persians, the Turkomans and
the Arabs, had Trabzon as their supply center. Its population
Trabzon was significantly increased in the 10th century AD. century was studied
Danish trading station. As reported by two modern Arabs geo-
writers, Masoudis and Istachri, Trabzon became economical,
political and military center of Pontus, resulting in strengthening
of Hellenism 14 .
The Byzantine emperors, to strengthen their eastern co-
had given special privileges to the themed chiefs of Pontus,
following a prudent social and tax policy, which had as
The Holy Monastery of Pontus Panagia Soumela before the destruction of 1922

232
resulting in the development of feelings of devotion to extremist populations
to the Byzantine state, as well as to their particular homeland. Where-
elsewhere in the whole of Byzantium the circle was not so much cultivated
of acritic songs as much as in Pontus and Cappadocia, a fact that
confirms the substantial contribution of acrites to the preservation of tits-
borders, for as long as the privileged regime was in force. Urban market
muse singled out in bravery and virtue Digenis Akritas, whose struggles
symbolize the incessant struggle of Hellenism against those who threatened
his freedom.
The problems for the Byzantine Empire gradually appeared later
in the 11th century, as the destruction of Armenian states and deportation
Armenian tribes in Cappadocia and Cilicia favored invasions
of the Seljuks. The decisive military operation to remove the Sel-
by the emperor Romanos (1067-1071) ended in destruction
The defeat of the Battle of Manzikert (August 26, 1071), which resulted in
end the Seljuk free march. The Seljuks, unhindered
now, they have flooded Central Asia and created separate states, the sultan-
Nato of Rome with Iconium as its capital and the emirate of Danismenides with
capital of Neocaesarea. At this time of crisis, Byzantium
wore for his eastern borders and changed social and tax
his policy towards the Akrites and the themarists of Pontus. Specifically,
military bases were abolished (ie the concession of agricultural lots)
to soldiers), tax exemption and other special privileges, with
as a result, the eastern systems become powerless and vulnerable to any enemy.
nora of Byzantium. The Akrites no longer had much reason to fight
from them they left for more affluent areas or changed professions. Then re-
many of Pontus' subjects and dukes were hanged. Others
again they were forced to fight on their own to liberate the regions.
from the Seljuks and other eastern enemies, without it
economic and military assistance to Byzantium. From these struggles
the heroes and achievements of the independent Pontians are well known.
Archbishops Theodoros and Constantine Gavras and Gregory of Taronitis 15 .

and George the Trabzon, who emerged as the leading spirit-
European figures and forerunners of European Humanism.

C. THE PRESIDENTIAL HELLENISM
DURING THE YEAR
W day of the first group of ancient Greeks facilities throughout
the Black Sea, the Caucasus, Georgia, Southern Russia, Mesimvri-
Russia, the Danube region and the Bulgarian shores of the Black Sea
Pontus became their refuge throughout Ottoman rule
Greeks. It is enough to see the chronological order of the forced movements
to understand that enslaved Hellenism resorted to hospitality
co-religionist Russia survives every time it encounters serious problems
of.
The first newer mass movement took place after the occupation of the Bank-
In 1461, when thousands of Greeks took refuge in the Caucasus,
of the Antikavakas and Mediterranean Russia. In 1625 the Greek was founded
Niezin community of Ukraine by Greeks, in which the Russian art-
(due to their contribution to the commons and its economic development
area) allowed the establishment of Greek courts, the creation of aut-
of the Greek administration, the establishment of Greek schools and churches.
They were also granted tax privileges, free trade-
and other beneficial exemptions.
These privileges were granted to Greeks in other cities, such as
of Putville, Moscow and Kiev strengthened, according to Adamantios Korais,
Greek-Russian relations.
In the years of Catherine the Great many Greeks of the Ottoman Empire-
of southern Greece settled in southern Russia. During the time of the high priest
Synod of the Metropolitan Theodosia Ignatius, thanks to the privileges again of Aika-
Terinis II, the Hellenism of Crimea migrated to the shores of the Azov Sea
Sea, resulting in a densely populated Christian area.
In the new places of installation, the Greeks founded the city of Mariupol,
in honor of the Virgin Mary and 24 pure Greek villages, whose inhabitants
to this day they maintain their national consciousness, the Greek dialect
and Greek popular culture.
In addition to merchants and scholars, hospitable Russia accepted into the territory
and many militants and captains, who were classified in Russian
army, attended military schools, distinguished themselves in battles and emerged-
even senior and top executives of the Russian army. From the great cat-
The names of the Greek officers of the Russian army stand out
1. Non-Turkish occupied Hellenism
Page 237

236
of Kruts, Gorgolis, Rodophoinikis, Moussis Kritskis, Papados-
bird, Perraivos, Katsonis, Georgakis Olympiou, Karavias,
of the Highlands 17 .
At the beginning of the 19th century, the Greeks supplied almost all goods
the countries that traded in the waters of the East and had the merchants
houses not only in all major ports in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea
Sea, the Balkan Peninsula and Asia Minor, but also Moscow,
Vienna, Paris and London.
Beyond the pro-Greek movement of the Russian people, the homogeneous Russia, basically
to promote its own interests in the Balkans and exit
in the Mediterranean, played an important role in the national liberation struggle
of 1821. This fact awakened again the pre-eternal feelings of sympathy
and the hope of the enslaved Greeks for the "blonde race", the liberator
Moskovo, to which the Greek people dedicated many of their songs, fine
acquiring the Tsars new Messiahs, as “the most perfect gift from God
dropped ” 18 .
At the side of the Friendly Society, when it became known, was the pro-
Western Russian society, from Odessa to Chisinau and Kiev, which
openly supported its action. At the house of the decapitated general Mi-
Haile Orloff, in Chisinau, was frequented by members of the Friendly Society, the Russians
officers V. Raefsky, K. Ohotnikov, Generals P. Pustin and P. Pestel,
the great poet A. Pushkin, to discuss the various literary,
philosophical and mainly political issues.
The Greek communities, which existed in almost all cities of Russia,
became real hotbeds of preparation for the liberation struggle. With
pioneering Odessa and the members of the Friendly Society, the Greek merchants
ships secretly transported to Greece weapons for insurrection and money
aid. The services offered by the great man in the fight were invaluable
Greek politician of Russia and later its first Independent Governor
of Greece, Ioannis Kapodistrias, to whom the Tsar earlier
Russia's Foreign Ministry has been appointed.
The Greek revolution and a little later its Russian-Turkish war
1828-29, they became the new cause of the abandonment of the ancestral lands. Over
90,000 Pontians, who openly sided with the Russians, were forced to
they set out to leave their place, to escape the fanatics
Islamists 19 . Most went to Tsalka, Georgia, at noon
and Southern Russia. The Crimean War of 1853-56, the Revelation of the Kry-
Christians and the sympathy of Pontic Greeks for the Russians

237
cause of new forced relocations. The largest relocation of Pontians
populations in Russian areas took place immediately after the Second Russian-Turkish Po-
lemon of 1876. It is estimated that more than 100,000 left the ancestral ones
their territories to Russia. The last and most dramatic exit
took place in 1918, when the Pontic populations of the eastern, mainly, Pontus,
about 85,000 were forced to follow the Russian troops
they left, fearing massacres and other humiliations 20 .
At the beginning of the October Revolution they lived, according to statistics.
of the Greek communities of Russia and the Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs
of Greeks, about 700,000 Greeks 21 . I paid more than thirty Greek
and unpaid consulates and sub-consulates were established in the period 1890-1912, for
the best service and contact of the Greeks of Russia with the national
center, Athens. In 1917, about 50,000 students attended Greek schools
students. Greek communities, charities and philanthropists
secondary institutions, essentially assisted in the preservation of national consciousness-
of Greek popular culture, language and orientation
at the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople and not Moscow.
However, their obsession with the Greek Orthodox tradition and faith, the Greeks
They paid for it, especially after 1937, with persecution, deportation and death
convictions by the Stalinist governments 22 .
The geographical area of ​​the northwestern Black Sea was
even in the most difficult years of Bulgarian rule and
Ottoman Empire an important center of spiritual, economic
and commercial activity of the Greek element. Throughout the course
of the Ottoman Empire many expatriates leaving Greece-
space due to repression, persecution and the number of settlers
Muslim settlers, especially in the lowlands and fertile parts, found
shelter in the familiar hospitable ancient Greek Thracian and Danube
residential centers. In these safer areas there were not a few who
they managed to grow and succeed in all areas.
The imposing presence in the Black Sea of ​​Greek shipping according to him
19th century, especially after Russia's naval blockade, reinforced the
economically, spiritually, commercially and demographically the pre-Black Hellenism.

shipowners, shipowners and merchants, which was crucial

The peaceful multinational climate was maintained until the Treaty of Berlin,
in 1878. The violent Bulgarianization of administrative and judicial power, the
violation of the "Organic Law", signed in 1879 and referring to
When it came to the equality and equality of national minorities, the economy
extinction by unbearable taxation and especially linguistic and
Religious oppression facilitated the process of its eventual extermination
Hellenism of Northern Thrace. The anti-Greek climate of the period 1885-1906
inevitably contributed to the ethnological assimilation of Hellenism and to
his final severance from his ancestral homes 23 .
At the same time, until the beginning of the 20th century, the course of Hellenism was parallel
of Wallachia, Moldavia, Dobruja and Bessarabia. Braila, the
Iasi, Galatsi, Constanta, Tulza, Sulina, Ismail and Buku-

239
Resti had organized Greek communities with strong economic, commercial,
shipping and spiritual presence. The establishment of the Greek Academies in
Danube hegemony created hotbeds of progressive spirit that
covered the gap of higher Greek education throughout the southeast-
Europe. The participation of Greeks, Romanians and Bulgarians in them
of actors played a decisive role in the evolution of spiritual and political
situations in the Balkans. But political and national reasons contributed to them
beginning of our century in the decline of Greek culture and the Greeks-
communities.
The tension in Greek-Romanian relations due to the Koutsovlachian Life-
In 1905 he negatively affected the position of the Greeks. Many Greeks
were forced to flee to Greece or seek refuge in other countries
better conditions for professional rehabilitation. Despite the difficult co-
cases, until Romania was declared a people's democracy (1948),
more than 100,000 Greeks continued to live there. After 1948 for one
for a long time, the policy pursued by the Romanian state
contributed to the reduction of the presence of Hellenism in Romania.
With the fall of the city in 1453 and Trabzon in 1461, it begins
and for Pontic Hellenism the period of Ottoman rule.
The palace of Komnenos was turned into a janissary barracks, where eight
young people became janissaries. A large part of the population was displaced
to Constantinople. The metropolis of Komnenos, Panagia Chrysoke-
falos, became a mosque, while many Greeks of the rich coastal cities and
of the villages took the road of exit and refuge. Others moved
on the shores of southern and southern Russia, others on the Danube
areas and others in the inaccessible mountainous areas of the inland Pontus, building-
living new Greek villages and cities, which developed into a cultural-
centers and became a refuge for those Greeks who were persecuted 24 .
Internal and external displacements may have altered the multiplicity.
social and economic structure of Greek society, but not-
they were able to fatally injure her, because the permanent weapons of Hellenism: the
religion, language and the long-standing Greek cultural tradition resist-
were subjected to Ottoman violence. So the Pontians of the Diaspora, despite the adverse
conditions of their relocation, prominent personalities such as
was e.g. the leader of the Friendly Society and pioneer of his Revolution
3. The Ottoman rule in Pontus
Page 241
GREEK GOVERNMENT
240
1821, Alexandros Ypsilantis and his brother Dimitrios Ypsilantis 25 .
The period of Ottoman rule was, in fact, for the Greeks
of Pontus particularly painful. The suffocating pressures of the conquerors forced
like many to convert, to save life, honor and
their property and that of their families 26 .
In the difficult years that Pontic Hellenism went through, there were many
who did not give in to pressure, defied the risks and paid
with their death this attitude of theirs. These are the New Martyrs , who
were executed dishonorably because they refused to convert, as well as for
the thieves and guerrillas of Pontus, who took refuge in the inaccessible
mountain peaks (Santa, Matsouka, Nikopoli etc.) and developed with great influence
View of the shipyards
of the City of Pontus
Page 242
GREEK GOVERNMENT
241
any armed action against the occupiers 27 .
In the first centuries of Ottoman rule, not only were they expelled
Greeks of Pontus but many times the culture was seriously endangered
their. So in 1764 Kerasounta, due to the civil war of the locals
tyrannies, completely destroyed. The same fate befell the town of Ko-
rala in 1811, while Trabzon was constantly shrinking from hunger and
misery. The harsh living conditions under the Ottoman regime-
administration, forced most Greek families to move-
to the mountains of Pontus.
The leveling catastrophe inflicted by the Ottomans on the conquered
areas and the depletion of booty gradually led to economic
and social reversal of Pontic Hellenism. Lack of labor
potential and administrative disorganization forced the conquerors to
tolerate the Greek Christians who remained in the countryside and the small ones
cities. So close to the craftsmen and other representatives of the production-
Relatives and fellow villagers took refuge in classrooms.
From the beginning of the 17th century, then, the Hellenism of Pontus began to
it takes root again, finds itself again and uses it
his spirit and abilities. The position of the Greeks was greatly strengthened by the monks.
poles and mines of Pontus, which were known from the early Byzantine-
era. The systematic exploitation of the mines had begun in the beginning
of the 16th century. Greek miners had acquired an almost monopoly-
retail position in all mining sectors. For this reason they were re-
revolutionaries in the empire and the Gate immediately recognized the importance
which had the silver, lead and gold mines in the Pontic hinterland.
The sultans, who needed money to continue the conquests
their wars, put all the mines and metallurgy under their supervision.
Murat I (1574-1595) was the first to nationalize galleries and facilities.
processing, thus weakening their power economically and politically
local tyrants, whose arrogance and greed were at stake
towards the life, personal freedom and property of the Greeks 28 . The
Privileges granted to miners led many Christians
in the Pontic mining communities, while they also had similar privileges
those who worked in shipyards.
Page 243
GREEK GOVERNMENT
242
The vast majority of Pontic Hellenism continued to live below
miserable and humiliating conditions, which fatally forced-
on the path to Islamism.
During the long period of Ottoman rule many Christians opposed
they were under pressure to convert. They were
the Crypto-Christians or Klostoi or Kryfoi or Gyristoi or Tenesourides. Was going
for poachers who were forced to accept externally only
Islam, maintaining in the depths of their souls the Christian faith and,
where conditions allowed, the Greek language. They thus maintained the religion.
their constructive faith and their Greek identity, with all the dangers
which implied this for themselves and their families. The biggest
part of the Crypto-Christians lived and still lives in Pontus, while in smaller-
The phenomenon of crypto-Christianity was also observed on a large scale
Albania, Cyprus, Crete, Istanbul, Cappadocia and others
Aegean islands.
Preservation from generation to generation of their secret Christian status
is a historically admirable phenomenon, given any revelation
he withdrew severe punishments from the Ottoman side.
4. The crypto-Christians of Pontus
Post-Byzantine miniature depicting
the violent relocation of the Greeks of Pontus
during the Ottoman period
Page 244

243
It should be noted, however, that the crypto-Christians, like the New Martyrs,
They had the full support of the great monasteries of Pontus.
Thanks to the diplomacy of their Leaders, these monasteries saved many
Sometimes morally, spiritually, nationally and physically the persecuted Christ-
stianos 29 .
The phenomenon of "occultism", which continues to this day, reveals
It was first officially established in 1856. The Crypto-Christians of Pontus
benefiting from the issuance of the sultan's decree "Hati Humayun", which
it promised religious and political freedom to all its citizens
Ottoman Empire, gathered in March 1857 at the Monastery
of Theoskepastou and there they swore to fight until the final victory,
defying exile, death and the other tortures with which they were tortured
the Ottoman authorities were blackmailing. The representative committee, appointed
by the crypto-Christians, in a letter to the embassies of the Great
Forces, to the Patriarchate and to the High Gate succeeded in recognizing
The first Crypto-Christians to officially become Christians.
In 1856 the on-site research carried out in the area of ​​Pontus for the cat-
Writing of the hidden Christians resulted in an Exhibition, which today-
It is in the files of the Foreign Office and certifies the large number of them
Crypto-Christian inhabitants. Despite the cessation of research by the Ottomans
principles, due to the fear that Christianity and Hellenism will expand
of the area, the inhabitants of many areas (Kromnis, Matsoukas, Sourmenon,
Santas, Imeras) raised the flag of the national religious revolution 30 .
In 1857 the committees created recorded 30,000 secrets
Christians, while entire villages one after the other revealed the mysti-
their 31 . This was the first diplomatic victory of 1857, in which they participated
actively and the representatives of the Great Powers, caused the formation of a new one
hostile climate towards Christians, as described by Exhibition
of the sub-ambassadors of Trebizond Kypriotis and Synadinos to Ypour-
Foreign Ministry of Greece and to the Metropolitan of Trebizond Constanta
δίο.
The Ottoman authorities, disturbed by the possibility of the generalization of the ek-
Christianity and Hellenism throughout the Pontus, took measures in
weight of those who had been recognized as Christians. The heaviest of the measures
these were the recruitment, which was equivalent to crypto-Christians
with a death sentence in the Ottoman camps, where they were treated
as non-religious. For this reason most Crypto-Christians re-
they fled to co-religion Russia. In the files of the Ministry
Page 245
244
GREEK GOVERNMENT
Russia's Foreign Ministry in Moscow has many reports
in the drama of the crypto-Christians 32 .
In 1910 the neo-Turkish parliament was forced to recognize a large cat-
crypto-Christians as true Christians. But most of them
they failed to take advantage of this recognition as well
trapped in complex bureaucratic processes.
The unexpected outcome of historical and political events, such as the Cretan Life-
and the Balkan wars, which brought Greece face to face
Turkey and, finally, World War I, the Asia Minor campaign
and the forced exchange of populations found themselves unprepared
crypto-Christians. The right they had won under the 1910 law
they did not manage to take advantage of it. The terrible persecutions and the methodical one
extermination of Pontic Hellenism during this period forced them
crypto-Christians to postpone the revelation and change of names-
of them and their religion for calmer days, which, however, did not come
never. For this reason, the exchange of populations, which was done only on the basis
religious beliefs, he found them on the other hand, since they were cat-
inscribed only with their Muslim names.
According to the reports of the Ecumenical Patriarchate, but also of the Assistant
of Greece abroad, in 1914 officially recorded were 43,000
crypto-Christians 33 .

GREEK GOVERNMENT
D. THE PRESIDENTIAL HELLENISM
THE 19TH AND 20TH CENTURY
T the unfavorable climate for the enslaved Greeks who stood
in the Ottoman Empire, during his Revolution
1821, gradually began to decline after the concession of special pro-
prefectures known in world history under the legal terms "Hatti Sherif"
(1839) and "Hati Humayun" (1856).
Theoretical equality and religious freedom along with its development
trade and the economy led to the demographic growth of Pontia-
population, in the cultivation of Greek education and in development
of modern Greek consciousness 34 .
Pontic Hellenism abandoned its hideouts and descended to
coastal areas, where he built new villages, churches and schools. In
In a short time he regained control of his entire trade
Black Sea and hinterland, while Trabzon rediscovered the old
her glories.
1. Economic and spiritual development
Transfer of Bafra tobacco with camels
Page 247
GREEK GOVERNMENT
246
The future of the region was predicted to be auspicious, thanks to the fertile country with
rich vegetation, vast forest areas with firs, plane trees, pine-
and other trees that covered the areas of Sinope, Tripoli, and
Kerasounta, Trebizond and Sourmen. In Kerasounta they had
steam locomotive factories were established to produce fir wood. Great-
Also important was the fine-grained oil exported to Hamburg
Trieste, New York and Russia.
The agricultural economy relied mainly on wheat, corn, barley.
ri, legumes, oranges, potatoes and excellent tobacco, especially
areas of Amisos and Bafra. Pontian cheese products
was and is also popular in the markets of Istanbul and others;
of big cities.
To the north, the Paryadrou mountain range, rich in mineral deposits,
enabled the creation of silver, copper and lead mines
in the regions of Argyroupoli and Tripoli. It was just as developed
the craft in the field of goldsmithing, blacksmithing, and coppersmithing,
as well as the shipbuilding industry.
The main source of wealth on the shores of the Black Sea was the
transit trade with main ports Amisos, Trabzon,
Kerasounta, Odessa, Braila, Novorossiysk and Sevastopol.
During the war the Neo-Turks tried in various ways
they wanted to remove and restrict the trade of Christians, the
who, in order to survive, collaborated with the local Muslim nation-
. Until 1869, Trabzon controlled 40% of Persian trade
and the transit trade made a profit of about 200,000,000 francs
time 35 .
Greek companies had commercial branches and agencies.
transport in Russia, Persia, England, Istanbul, the
Marseille and other major European cities. Trabzon is
at the crossroads of trade between West and East to
1869 - The Suez Canal is completed
gradual decline of its port. However, for a long time after
1883, four major Greek banking and commercial houses in Trabzon-
They together with the branch of the Bank of Athens controlled almost the whole of it
economy of the eastern Pontus.
The economic movement of the Greeks in the other cities of Po- was similar.
shower: large quantities were exported from the commercial port of Amisos
tobacco and other domestic products, while in 1869 in Amisos by

214 businesses in the city, 156 belonged to the Greeks. In Kerasounta the

and Europe.
The economic prosperity of Hellenism in the wider region of the Black Sea
Pontus resulted in spiritual and artistic rebirth. The
representatives of the business world generously offered a respect-
in the amount of their profits in favor of religious, teachers and philanthropists
human rights institutions and notable scientists were sent to specialize in
various European universities, to transfer to their homeland
new scientific teaching methods.
The Trabzon Tutoring Center , founded in 1682 by the great
Trabzon teacher of the Genos Sevastos Kyminitis and it worked
despite adversity until 1922, it played an important role in the spiritual
and moral regeneration of the Hellenic Pontians and in the development of their national
consciousness 36 .
At the beginning of the 20th century, there was no Pontian village without its own school
and his own church. According to the statistics of Panaretos, in 1913 in
provinces of the six metropolises of Pontus were inhabited by 697,000 Greeks, while
during the same period, according to G. Lampsidis, there were 1,890 churches,
22 monasteries, 1,647 chapels and 1,401 schools with 85,890 students.
The Greek printing house, which was established in 1880 in Trabzon-
He decisively contributed to the development of national consciousness and
preparing a competitive climate to replace the Ottoman-
regime by a free and democratic state.
The Greek-centric orientation of this climate was primarily
the emerging bourgeoisie, which developed patriotic action
at every opportunity. Thus, for example, from the Russo-Ottoman war of 1828-1829
until the Cretan uprising of 1866-67, the Greeks of Pontus were pa-
rondes.
But also in the ensuing Greek-Ottoman wars.
The volunteer participation of the Pontian fighters and the economic
support provided in favor of the games. For example, we mention the
an offer of .000 12,000 made by the Greeks of Samsun in 1912
in the Greek Navy 37 .
The 20th century found the Hellenism of Pontus to have a spectacular lead-
compared to the other ethnic groups in the wider region in the economy
and the spiritual realm.
However, the policy pursued by the neo-Turkish governments to the contrary
Page 250
GREEK GOVERNMENT
249
of the Greeks was extremely hostile and involved unfavorable financially,
educational, military and religious measures imposed
yachts in the Christian nationalities of the state. This policy, which bri-
contrary to the statements of the President of the United States.
U.S. Secretary of State G. Wilson, on the self-determination of peoples, led
the Pontians, mainly of the Diaspora, in the great decision to fight for
the creation of an autonomous Pontic Republic .
The Greeks of the Diaspora became leaders in the struggles for
the creation of an autonomous Pontic democracy with basic ec-
persons K. Konstantinidis from Marseilles, V. Ioannidis and Th. Theofyli-
lactou from Vatoum, I. Passalidi from Sochoum, L. Ioannidi and F. Ktenidi
from Krasnodar. The two stand out from the Greeks of the historical Pontus
Respected figures of the Church, the Metropolitan of Trebizond Chrysanthos
and the Metropolitan of Amasia, Germanos Karavangelis 38 .
A few days before the Russian occupation of the city, in April 1916, it took place
the surrender of Trabzon by the Turkish Wali Mehmet Jemal Azmi Bey
to Metropolitan Chrysanthos, who due to his prudent policy towards
to the Muslims of the region, it was accepted by the Russians but also
by the consular representatives of the other states, as a leader in the right-
Stable area, where the memories of the massacres were still fresh in the residents
and hostilities. Chrysanthos' two-year presidency was a real one
break of democracy and harmonious coexistence of Christians and Muslims
νων. In February 1918 the situation had changed radically since then
since the Bolsheviks prevailed in 1917, the Russian army has abandoned
Trabzon and the area was again occupied by the Neo-Turks.
In those difficult times, thousands of Greeks in the eastern Pontus and
of Kars, in order to escape persecution by the Neo-Turks, they took it
way of escape to Russia, which was then tested by civil war-
mo. The uprooting of the Greeks of Asia Minor sensitized the Greeks
of Russia, who already from the First Panhellenic Congress, in July 1917
in Taiganio decided to elect a Central Council for the creation
of the independent Pontic State, with temporary seat in the city of Rostov 39 .
For the first time, the Pontians of the Diaspora organized in all the big ones
cities of Greece (Athens, Thessaloniki, Kavala, Volos), as well as in
cities abroad.

Autonomous Republic of Pontic (1917-1922)

In Europe, the leader of the struggle was K. Konstantinidis, who
from Marseilles with successive memos informed the allied forces-
for the tragic situation in Pontus. He too
printed and circulated a map defining the boundaries of the proposed po-
democracy. This map was also printed in plain mail
bulletin (postcard) with written text in French: “Citizens of Pontus
get up! Remind liberal nations of their highest rights to life and
independence ” 40 . The Russian revolution upset the Greeks of Pontus
for their own national struggle, while in the first world Pan-Pontian Sy-
Neanderthal, organized in Marseilles in February 1918, K. himself.
Konstantinidis, with a telegram he sent to A. Trotsky, formally requested
the support of the Soviet Union 41 .
Eleftherios Venizelos' government initially agreed with the struggle
and the national claims of the Pontians. But at the Peace Conference in Paris,
which began in December 1918, El. Venizelos was pressured by the allies
forces and did not include Pontus in the Greek claim file-
and, despite the strong protests of the Greeks of Pontus, he agreed
to cede the area to the Republic of Armenia.
The proposal of El. Venizelou caused great disappointment to the Greeks

He visited Yerevan and negotiated with the Armenians, as well
also with the Muslims of Pontus, a form of confederation 43 .
However, mutual suspicion led to the loss of valuable time, which
proved fatal due to rapid political developments. The political
which served as the tombstone of the Pontic question was the co-
friendship and co-operation case signed in March 1921 between
to the Bolsheviks and Kemal. This treaty gave the weak as
then Kemal the economic, military and moral ability to continue them
his operations against the Pontians and even to appear at the Conference
of London with excessive demands, which due to the historical circumstances
