The last attempt at Ponto-Armenian cooperation began late-
to the beginning of 1922, when the interests of the Great Powers were at stake
change side. Taking advantage of the favorable situation, Kemal Pasha, with the
obvious support from the Bolsheviks, Italy, France and the tacit
England's partnership, began the counterattack that brought about the collapse
of the front.
The Pontic Republic remained a dream, while the death sentence was handed down by it
Kemalist government of all the leaders of the struggle sealed the national
misfortune of Pontic Hellenism, which is associated with general luck
of Hellenism in Central Asia.
During this period of genocide and even earlier, a second po-
Greek Hellenism lived and flourished in Russia. More than
500,000 Pontians lived in Russia, while in 1918, with group residences.
persecuted Pontians, especially after the withdrawal of the Russians
troops, exceeded 750,000 45 . Today it is estimated that in the first
more than half a million Pontians live in the Soviet Union
who retain, to the extent that the Independent authorities do not intervene-
of the Republics of the Commonwealth, the traditional Greek-Pontic
their traditions.
In the historical Pontus, however, the end of the history and culture of the Po-
It was extremely tragic and violently stopped with the forced exchange.
population growth defined by the Treaty of Lausanne in 1923.
E genocide of the Armenian people in 1915 t is known by Neotour-
but the methodical extermination of his Greeks is not known
Pontus that had the same proportions quantitatively and morally as their genocide
Armenians in the period 1916-1923.
Of the 697,000 Pontians living in Pontus in 1913, more
of the 353,000, or more than 50%, were killed by
1923 by the Neo-Turks and Kemalists in the towns and villages, in
exiles and prisons, as well as labor battalions, the so-called “careless
tabourou ” 46 .
3. Methodical extermination
(genocide) of the Greeks of Pontus
Page 255
254
GREEK GOVERNMENT
The nature and method of launching systematic prosecutions against El-
of Pontus by the Neo-Turks and Kemalists, while it has many
common features with the genocide of the Jews, it has two main differences,
according to P. Enepekidis. It has no ideological, worldview or pseudo-level.
static foundation on genetic, eugenics and aria or Semitic race.
It only served the specific practical political purpose of the ec-
clearing of Central Asia from the Greek element. The exiles of the inhabitants all-
lottery villages, those devastating trekking in the women's snow-
children and the elderly - the men were already in the labor battalions or
in the army - they contributed to the death of many from the hardships 47 .
The situation in the wider Black Sea region has deteriorated,
when the Greek army on 15 May 1919 captured Smyrna and a m-
inland. Kemal himself organized the second on May 19, 1919
phase of persecution when he landed in Samsun.
With the Treaty of Lausanne on July 24, 1923, it was defined as the border with
between Turkey and Greece the river Evros. Already on January 30 of the same
The agreement on the exchange of liabilities was signed in Lausanne this year.
-organisms.
However, the vast majority of Greek refugees had already settled.
leave the area before the contract, while many resorted to para-
retail cities to board ships for Greece. Overall, the present-
Hellenism of Central Asia was exterminated during the period 1914-1924 or
followed the path of dispersal to Europe, America and the
Persia (Iran), the Soviet Union and Greece.
The Archives of the Ministries of Foreign Affairs of Europe and America, as well
The reports of international organizations also certify the size and type
of the persecution suffered by the Greeks of Pontus.

GREEK GOVERNMENT
E. THE PRESENCE OF GREEK GREATING
IN MODERN TIMES
The events of 1922 resulted in the uprooting of its Hellenism
Central Asia. More than 1,300,000 Greeks were forced to emigrate
they violently abandoned the beloved dead, along with their possessions
them and the culture of their long creative presence there.
The war-exhausted, morally, politically, socially, demographically and
financially Greece was forced to accept hundreds of thousands-
see refugees, without any specific reception plan.
The Asia Minor catastrophe brought to the fore the troubled inner self-
political situation. The incompetence of the alternating governments
forced General Plastiras to take power, to dethrone him
King Constantine and mobilize all state services for it
solving refugee problems.
The vast majority of the refugee population, 638,252 people, i.e.
53%, settled in Macedonia, initially in the regions
abandoned by exchangeable Muslims.
1. The refugee problem
from 1922 until today
The refugee camp of Harmankios (Eleftheria) in Thessaloniki
Page 257
GREEK GOVERNMENT
256
The main problems faced by the state in this first period
The refugees were repairing abandoned settlements
the Turkish and Bulgarian populations, the construction of new houses and
settlements, the construction of transport projects, the distribution of agricultural lots
to refugee farmers and their supply of basic tools
and agricultural seeds for the cultivation of the estates. The Greek
government, to continue the work of rehabilitating refugees Po-
He requested the mediation of the League of Nations (CC), which approved
lending. Nansen's famous exhibition played a positive role, so that in
late 1924, after persistent negotiations and strict commitments,
the loan was signed between the Greek government and its Bank
England with a nominal capital of 3 12,300,000.
The management of the loan following a proposal by the League of Nations that
was accepted by the Greek government assigned to the autonomous and
independent organization, the Committee for the Rehabilitation of Refugees (E.A.P.), which
was established on the basis of the protocol of 28 September 1923 of Geneva.
The E.A.P. with its excellent administrative, financial and technical organization
to proceed with the implementation of their rehabilitation program
refugees. The success of the program was also contributed by the pros themselves.
pulses with hard work, ability, honesty and experience that
had in the economic and cultural space. 2/3 of the expenses of E.A.P.
were spent in Macedonia resulting in a radical change in the region.
so much so that, according to the statements of the vice president of John Campbell,
in 1930 it was difficult to recognize the desert place of 1923 48 .
Agriculture, livestock, sericulture and fishing were highly developed.
refugees, resulting in the wider development of agriculture
economy.
Venizelos' social policy has permanently helped the permanent establishment-
of rural populations, while various privileged measures, which function-
as temporary for refugees in the border areas, they contributed
decisively in the manning of the remote villages. The refugees became
once again vigilant border guards.
Along with the partial restoration of rural populations, the Greeks
governments have tried to resolve, even temporarily, the complex ones
problems of urban refugee populations. The state dropped the weight
in the solution of the housing problem, while the E.A.P. spent 2,422,961 li-
about 165,000 urban refugees. 50% of it
urban population gathered in Athens and Thessaloniki 49 .

GREEK GOVERNMENT
257
Among the other problems faced by refugees during
Their settlement in Greece was also their relations with the native Greeks.
who initially had many reservations about them. Issue
This occupied politicians, such as P. Kanellopoulos, but also logos-
such as G. Ioannou, who tried to interpret the phenomenon.
enon 50 .
Despite the difficulties, the refugees did not lose heart, but enlisted
all survival mechanisms acquired during co-
their experience with the Ottomans. Of course, this category does not include
tens of thousands of wealthy Asia Minor refugees are being taken
without state aid, thanks to the investments they had in Greece and in
abroad, they solved their problems alone.
However, the odyssey of pre-Black Hellenism does not stop at Asia Minor
urban destruction. It continued immediately after the Russian Civil War
during which tens of thousands of Greeks were unjustly lost. According to the gen-
1928 census, during this decade they settled in Greece
58,500 Greeks in Russia. As early as 1918, as mentioned above, a resident-
as more than 750,000 Pontians in the Caucasus, Anti-
Caucasian, Mediterranean Russia and Ukraine 51 .
During the period of the Stalinist persecutions (1937-1939) about 20,000 El-
were expelled from the Soviet Union to Greece, beyond
Tens of thousands of people have been displaced in Kazakhstan
Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, the steppes and other inhospitable areas
Soviet Union. Another 13,500 also took refuge on the road
1965.
The refugee issue worsened again in March 1988, when the so-
Vietnamese authorities open borders to the peoples of the Socialist Republic-
and a large wave of young refugees was created.
from Russia to Greece, which has now exceeded 180,000.
The Greek state has faced great difficulties in integrating
of young Pontian refugees within it. It is a fact that from
1923 no other wave of refugees had such a size as to force-
Greek state to pursue a policy of reception and restoration
refugee status. Their installation took place mainly in Athens and
Thessaloniki. In December 1990, the National Reception Foundation was established
Restoration of Returning Expatriate Greeks (E. I.Y.A.P.O.E.).
The difficulties of the state in solving the problem of its restoration-
The refugee camp led the refugee unions to ask for it
Page 259
258
GREEK GOVERNMENT
establishment of small settlements in Thrace and the creation of a traditional po-
of a city called "Romania", to accommodate several newcomers
Pontian refugees in the extreme positions of northern Greece.
The refugee population in the decade 1922-1932 contributed to the resolution
Demographic problem, in the development of agriculture, its
handicrafts, industry, trade, shipping of Greece and ep-
now promoted the creation of a new Greek spirit by the compos-
of Asia Minor with the Greek.
The struggles of peasants, workers and bourgeoisie strengthened resolutely
and the modernization of social and political life in Greece. The
refugee social struggles for a fairer distribution of the national
revenue became the reason for the creation of new political formations and
parties.
Above all, refugee Hellenism was widely distinguished and distinguished.
for his deep love of the arts and letters. The developed spirit-
infrastructure of most refugees, who were particularly distinguished
for their language proficiency and versatility, contributed to the rapid pro-
their adaptation to the Greek climate but also to their substantial participation
in the cultural progress of the whole of Greece. Specifically in the speech-
The generation of the '30s drew thematic stimuli from their lives and customs.
refugees, while the extremely critical and historical songs of Pontus, the
religious songs of Cappadocia, the rebetikas of Ionia became rich
and renewed Greek music with their Byzantine tone and color.
Pontian war dances, cultural associations, refugee bodies
Today, their books, newspapers and magazines are still there
an important part of the cultural heritage of pre-Black Hellenism.
The Greek Christian tradition was preserved by the refugees of 1922
but also from the next generations until today both in Greece
as well as abroad. Religious symbols and historic monasteries
(Panagia Soumela, Agios Georgios Peristereotas, Agios Ioannis Vazelonas,
Theodoros Gavras, Panagia Goumera, Agios Vassilios Lagkadas), which
they set foot in various mountains of Macedonia, they also signaled-
to this day the Greek refugees of the Black Sea.
The modern historical scholar discovers the common cultural thread that
unites generations of refugees from 1922 to the present day both nationally

modern Greek society.
This mass influx strengthened the refugee communities of Greece and
of Russia, resulting in the creation of a permanent transport network if-
people, goods, ideas between the Greek and Russian poles
of the Pontic Diaspora.
Thessaloniki remains the main center of concentration and organization
of the world pan-Pontic and pan-Asia Minor conferences, as the
Macedonia and Thrace constitute the main geographical area of ​​installation
of refugees in Greece.

"The plain is full of coolness and greenery. It can and does feed herds
oxen and horses. It has crops of millet and sugar in endless
the quantities. The rich waters of the area do not leave drought anywhere.
Not once has it been reported that there has been a famine in these parts. There are so many
the fruits of the hilly country, native and wild, grapes, pear-
apples and walnuts, so that every season of the year those who go out in the forest
find fruit in abundance. The fruits are sometimes hung on trees
and sometimes in the foliage that has fallen to the ground, from below, fallen on
large quantities. Too much food also creates the conditions for too long
good hunting ". (Strabo, Geographically, Cappadocia-Pontos, Athens (1994) vol. 12, p.

"They are Greeks who were forcibly converted to Islam during the dark ages.
of slavery, and still embrace Islam today, but we have
They spoke Greek as their mother tongue, recognizing it as Greek, violence
of Slavic origin, and retain their Greek customs and traditions,
largely. These keep the sacred ecclesiastical utensils, books and vestments
of their fathers, as heirlooms, and for no reason do they consent to
expropriation of them. Turkish, mantanousin in schools, and
speakers of the most eloquent Greek language. And this, while environment-
are under Turkish populations. " (A.Y.E., K.Y., A / 1920, The Hellenism of Pontus,
Exhibition of Archimandrite Panaretos, p. 11).

265

9
"In those years of the atheists Agarines, a great disturbance was inflicted on the
Our Holy and Holy Monastery of the Holy Forerunner of Zavoulon.
Seventy holy fathers were sent to mourn the poor
Christians disappeared and the wreaths were laid. See
He captured the elders, for those who returned, and reluctantly reigned
in Monastirio, he had opera out of three hundred and ninety, only one hundred
Thirty numbers of brothers, if I return to the foreign sufferers-
forty in favor. May the almighty God have mercy on us and give
let go of this people. Amen". [Panaretos (Topalidis), History of the Holy Monastery
of the Holy Forerunner and Baptist John Zavoulon or Vazelon, Trebizond
1909, p. 107].
10
Zion, do not oppress me, and with a heavy heart
You will change the golden name to Turkish and you will put it
you will get a man of all gold, a Christian child
Apparently Mahmoud aga and secretly Nicholas
You will go to the monastery at midnight. " (Hatzopoulos G., “From the
nightmarish life of Pontus threads ", Pontian Stories, vol. 1, Athens
1966, p. 8 et seq.).
11
"During my stay in Kerasunda, I was visited by Muslim.
mother Suleiman. If he didn't insist so much on talking to me, I would
I felt like accepting him, because I had neither the time nor the mood to argue with him.
a Muslim on Qur'anic subjects. But when the pseudo-hero
Muslim Suleiman informed me that he is also Greek.
A priest named Parthenios, I was very surprised. That's exactly why
he had decided to bother me. He begged me as a Christian to him
help him get out of a terribly difficult situation he is in:
"I need help," the old man told me, and a big tear rolled down my face
in his white long and silky beards. I didn't have much time left
live and can secretly continue to serve my God as I am
I have been serving him for almost 70 years. But I have a daughter in front of me
Page 267
266
In the world I call her Fatime, but when the two of us are together, I squeeze her in
my chest, I caress her and tenderly pronounce her name Sophia. I must
tell me to save this pure creature. It's time to get married and not
I can still refuse to give it to the Muslims for a long time
they heard a lot about her beauty. There are almighty people among them
Muslims. I feel that I will not survive that day when the Turk
who will marry her will close my angel in the harem. Please
help my poor Sophia and a related companion, and he needs
to move to Crimea, Tbilisi or some other Christian country
country. I will give him money to ensure the existence of my daughter and
I will dedicate the rest of my life to prayer asking God to
reward your kindness ".
The old man's words moved me deeply and I hurried to do what I could
and what my position allowed for the daughter of the priest Parthenios ”(Tchigatcheff
P., Lettres sur la Turquie, Paris 1859).
12
"For the time being, we have a stamped letter from the Commissioner.
but we are from the provinces of the two metropolises of Saint Trebizond and
Chaldias, residents of the villages of Kromni, Santas, Kovasis, Partis, Giagliteres,
Stavris, Mouzenas, Stylos, Havaras, Tantourlou, Sise, Pontilas, Thersa,
Agoursas, Larahanis, Kapikioglou, Galianas, Hatsaveras, Kavaras and others
say, that public opinion and in a sympathy and similarity we restored from
All of our commissioners are Mr. Tosunoglu
Mustafa Yazizin after his escort Mustafa Tursunoglu
and Suleiman the Magnificent, to apologize and give them an apo-
giving reasons for any questions that may arise
sent to Constantinople.
To these gentlemen we have acknowledged our firm decision.
and the public opinion on how to act in this way can
discovery of our hitherto hidden religion. Therefore, please
the eminent ambassadors of the Imperial forces of England, France,
Austria, Russia and Greece, as recognizing them by force
of the seal of our committee letter of genuine commission-
and lead them in the right direction for the discovery of religion
and our freedom.

Page 268
For this reason, the present in their hands became proof and the seal-
gidi of each seal of a commissioned letter and given to them
to show in any place and court of necessity.
July 15, 1857 in Trabzon. (The original document is available today
in the archive of the Pontian Studies Committee).
13
"The 1950s. My blessed father, a young girl at the time in the church
of the Twelve Apostles in the Ferricas of the City. I'm a child too ... but I remember
who came late at night and knocked on the door.
see also small children in your arms. They came from the East and asked
to baptize their children. We secretly put them in the church, locked them
the door and the sacrament of baptism began. Silently. Low-pitched. That too
it happened almost every night. For many years". (Eph. Right, no. Sheet 13,
June 1992).

GREEK GOVERNMENT
Page 272
271
Harvesting: The alternation of cultivation in the same soil (eg one year
cereals, the next legume), to ensure better agricultural
odds.
Naughty (common. Chets): Turkish guerrillas who suddenly hit the el-
Greek military detachments and committed atrocities against them
of the civilian population.
Gulhane: A suburb of Istanbul from which it took its name
Imperial decree "Hatti-Sherif of Gulhane", November 3, 1839.
The decree included essential declarations for its citizens
Ottoman Empire.
Giritlis: Cretan (Turkish). The nickname was given to Mustafa Nailis
Pasha for his long stay in the administration of Crete.
De facto et de jure: Latin terms. De facto: Status formed
of course. De jure: A situation arising from the Law.
Equal rights on earth: Different rights exercised
simultaneously on the same ground by different natural or legal persons
(eg right of small ownership, right of possession, prefecture, rent, etc.).
Zourides: In Crete, zourides are called weasels.
Thira land: Petroma, a product of a volcanic eruption, mined in
island of Thira.
Karavanades-Barefoot: Characteristics of the Cretan parties that anti-
they were ideologically distinct. The liberals and Mr. were barefoot.
Conservative Ravanades. The nicknames were given by the leaders
of opposing factions.
Great predator: (Turkish arbede), attitude, rebellion, great evil, calamity.
GLOSSARY
glossary
Page 273
272
Our Lady of Kleftrina: Virgin Mary-protector of thieves = pirates.
Praetorians: Selected corps of the Roman army. They had as their main task
their security of the emperor. They intervened in various ways in the pol-
things of Rome. They regulated the imperial power and several
times caused political crises. They were dissolved by M. Constantinos.
Selbesia: Turkish word meaning abduction, domination.
Social Democracy: Party tendency, which seeks the combination of no
of socialism with those of democracy.
Sphere : A small ball of pencil, used by voters
instead of a ballot. For the last time bullets were used in
elections of November 1, 1920. The expressions "he ate black" and "I threw it away
bitten ”are related to the use of beads during its process
voting.
Class Party: It is the party that primarily or exclusively represents
the interests of a social class.
glossary
Page 274
273

Refugee testimonies about settlements in Asia Minor, the exit
from their homes in 1922 and their settlement in Greece have
Gathered in the Oral Delivery File of the Center for Asia Minor Studies-
see. Collaborators of the Center from 1930 to 1970 collected information on
all parts of Greece where refugees had settled. This taxi material
It was inhabited by settlements and wider areas of Asia Minor and consists of
from 150,000 pages referring to 1,375 settlements. At the same time, the Center
Asia Minor Studies has a photographic archive and a special library.

5. The jurisdiction of Alexandros Zaimis (1906-1908). . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 216
6. The abolition of the Commission in Crete. The first union
Resolution of the Cretans. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 217
7. The events of the years 1909-1913. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 218
8. The transfer of Venizelos to Athens and the consequences
in the Cretan Question. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 219
9. The final solution of the Cretan Question. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 219
PRESIDENTIAL GREEKNESS
A. Ancient Greek colonies of Pontus . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 223
1. Geographical identification. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 223
2. Reasons for the creation of Greek colonies in Pontus. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 223
3. Social and cultural identity of the colonies. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 226
B. The Black Sea Hellenism during the Byzantine period . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 229
1. The spread of Christianity. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 229
2. The state of the Great Komnenos of Trabzon (1204-1461). . . . . . 232
contents
Page 288
287

1. Non-Turkish occupied Hellenism. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 235
2. Northwestern pre-Black Hellenism. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 237
3. The Ottoman rule in Pontus. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 239

2. Games for the creation of an autonomous Pontic
Democracy (1917-1922). . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 249
3. The methodical extermination (genocide) of the Greeks of Pontus. . . . . .253

1. The problem of refugees from 1922 until today. . . . . . . . . . . . . . 255

until today . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 258
EXAMPLES. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 261

GLOSSARY. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 271
BIBLIOGRAPHY . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 273
CONTENTS. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 282

the "Center for Asia Minor Studies",
the "Gallery of the Municipality of Athens" and
the "Gennadius Library"
that allowed us to use
images and maps from their Publications,
for the needs of book teaching.

Based on Law 3966/2011 the textbooks of the Primary School,
of the Gymnasium, of the Lyceum, of the EPAL. and EPA.S.
are printed by ITYE - DIOFANTOS and distributed
free in Public Schools. Books can
available for sale when brought to the bottom right
front corner corner indication “READ WITH
SELLING PRICE". Any copy available to
sale and does not bear the above indication considered
stolen and the offender is prosecuted according to
provisions of Article 7 of Law 1129 of 15/21 March
1946 (Government Gazette 1946,108, A ').
Reproduction of any part is prohibited
of this book, covered by rights
(copyright), or its use in any form, without
the written permission of the Ministry of Education, Research and
Religions / ITYE - DIOFANTOS.
